this game is very fun and enjoyable if you are having a good day before you start playing and if you are playing during the day! :D But if you play after a bad day and have maybe 1 or 2 bad games you will feel the anger bubble up inside of you until after your third bad game you break. You go to killer and you choose skull merchant with knockout, bbq, grim embrace and uw with a rpd offering. You then find your first victim that give up after hearing your terror radius and slug them, after that you watch as their solo q teammates try to pick them up, but you place all your drones on this person and stalk from above as they desprately try to remove your drones. 

Some run straight into your drones with the intention to pick the slug up as fast as possible, getting deep wounded while doing so and being swiftly downed, others try to hide at the sides but with UW you make them scream and fill their bodies with dread. From around the corner one of them hides and you stalk your undetectable body to them. You round the corner and make them scream from terror as you shove your blade into them. The two other slugs try to crawl away towards the non chased person but you realize what they are doing and with your UW cooldown being gone you swiftly open a locker and hear the person scream and you damage them too. You turn around and see the person you chased before trying to sneak back to recover their teammates and you down them too. 

One person left and you hear a disconnect. Your first slug cant be bothered anymore and you smile knowing not only your games have been bad. Opening a locker for the last time you hear the person scream, slowly but surely you stalk your way to them placing a drone to become undetectable. You smile to yourself, this time im the one bleeding people out instead of being bled out. This time i am the one causing the pain instead of experiencing it. THIS TIME. i win. I WIN THIS TIME.

you see them standing infront of a hook, they have given up. You go to them as you hear your bot slug bleed out and die, the second one only some seconds behind from experiencing the same fate. 

You smile to yourself as you down the person, crows being heard from your second slug as they too have given up long ago. 

The survivors then expected you to hook them, but you dont.

You instead stand up from your chair your job being done and go do something else. As you take off your headphones you see the third slug realize whats about to happen and a disconnect sound is heard. The second slug bleeding out as well.

Your fourth slug with pain in their eyes looks up at you quietly begging to be hooked. This is will be their fourth disconnect and they dont want to wait an hour to play, but you laugh to yourself and turn around from the computer, the third slug bleeds out and the fourth slug hears the hatch spawn in the middle.

You arent there to witness it, but you can feel it inside of you as the last slug try desprately crawling to the hatch, their time is almost up. 3 metres, 2 metres, their hand reach up to the sky begging for mercy, begging for only some seconds more to reach escape. But its futile, their hand falls down and so do their face too. All four survivors have bled out.

You come back to your computer after 3 minutes and read an endgame chat that could only be described as hell itself.

With all your anger being taken out of you, you quit to the lobby and press survivor, not knowing what awaits you.

In recent months developers are making the game worse and worse.

Releasing bad DLCs with terrible concepts, design and execution of DLC in general.
Skull merchant, xenomorph are only some of terrible killers.
Nurse is still not being dealt with, extremely overpowered killer. People saying things like "she is fair because it takes time to learn" are ridiculous, something that takes time to learn must be strong, not overpowered, and nurse is overpowered, the are hundreds of possible scenarios where you cannot do anything against her.

Developers are nerfing balanced perks because a lot of people use them, they are making these perks absolutely unusable.
I might agree that deadhard was quite boring, because perks that make you outwait something are not really fun, but it was balanced, now it is unusable.

Suffice to mention the huge amount of unfair and OP perks developers decided not to to nerf (because who would nerf unbalanced perks when you can completely ruin balanced ones), does not matter what anyone says, both sides have plenty of them.

Ridiculous bugs, terrible (ABSOLUTELY DISGUSTING) htiboxes, all present in the game.

Reworking bad map and make it good? No. 
Rework bad map without fixing the reason why it is bad? Yes.

Why would developers rework good maps and make them complete trash?
No idea, but it is what is happening to the game.
Macmilan, coldwind, bargo and many others, why?

Seems like they are trying to make the game work and make you forget about all the problems by adding tons of skins no matter whether it is big content update or small patch.
Also, skins that are being released fit "really great" in the game.
We are developing horror game, what skin should we add for clown killer to make people feel like they are playing a horror?
Pink elephant is the way to go!
KPOP star killer that looks goofy rather than scary and make neon skins for him, cool.
I agree that DBD is not scary no matter what after first 10 games, but if the game has its own atmosphere, everything needs to be done sticking to it.

Huge amount of problems in the game and insufficient solutions by devs.
Camping, how did they try to fix this?
By creating bar that after filling lets you unhook yourself, sounds cool?
Yes, but it fills only if killer is face-camping you, if he is a little bit further from that small range it will not help.
Proxy camping is 95% of camping and this problem is not solved by this.

Not being able to fix something without completely disabling it from the game is great.
Remember when they had to remove cenobite, clown, wesker for a few weeks before they managed to rework them.
What made devs disable them and not just let it be while reworking them?
Who knows.

Probably the best asymmetrical game out there and has gotten better over time, so I would at least recommend trying it (and getting a DLC chapter you'd want), obviously best if you buy base game and DLC on sale with the amount of content you can buy in game or through the DLC chapters. I would say even though it's easier now, trying to get characters or perks can be quite time consuming, and by the time you get there, you might already get tired of the game, cuz theres always gonna be a new DLC to catch up to.

Main Issues:
Survivor gameplay can get stale quickly, especially when facing repeat killers or getting repeat maps, and there is not maybe unique and fun survivor perks to combat this, (considering survivors don't have unique abilities like killers, but I don't think they should). Since the (necessary) Dead Hard change (from the dash), (necessary) nerfs to boons, and not many unique and good perk ideas (with some exceptions), has also added to the staleness factor.

The survivor objective has gotten rather stale, but this can be aided by the fact that they are now experimenting with new game-modes.

One of the other big issues is perks (on both sides), most perks seem rather weak (needing buffs) compared to meta/good perks, and many perks are rather boring (even the meta ones). I think they have also lost some of the interesting gameplay incentives they've had when the removed bloodpoint bonuses from perks.

Obtaining perks is also still an issue as well, while it's been made "easier/faster" in recent years, there is still issues for casual players to get perks they would want, and it can still be overwhelming with the amount of perks and characters now. The main problems being the shrine and lack of variety for general perks. For example when trying to play with more casual friends on survivor, they usually lack perks they would need/want to make the game more fun/enjoyable. I also think there should be some kind of "welcome back" bonus (that wouldn't be better than just playing) for casual players.

it doesn't feel particularly rewarding for playing more frequently (besides leveling goals) with daily rituals system being very limited and the grades/ranks are not really that easy to to get through, since it's sorta based on your skill/performance so they can be a bit frustrating. Tome challenges are fine, but I don't think it's enough to feel rewarded anymore.

it is also hard to tell what your next match is gonna be like (because you can't see your matchmaking rank score) so you might have a fun match or a really frustrating one and there's no way to prep for it well and adapt (even mentally).

This game is just not fun anymore. I‚Äôve played over 1000 hours on steam and a few hundred on ps4 before moving to steam. This game is so unbalanced now in favor of killers. I have played killer from time to time, but I consider myself a survivor main. This game's been slowing changing towards that overtime, but now it‚Äôs at a point where it‚Äôs just not fun to play as a survivor anymore.

Most of the time, killers camp the hook or tunnel the same survivor and then they end up disconnecting or killing them-self on the hook. And while the devs brought a "system" that's supposed to help with this, it doesn't. You get yourself off the hook only if they're basically standing in your face. Then, assuming you do get off the hook, they just chase you down until your endurance timer runs out and kill you. So, doesn't FIX anything. Killers, being so overpowered, still continue to play try-hard despite the imbalance and there are more buffs coming to killers in a recent development update. I really don't understand.

There have been many times during the games life where the devs nerf survivor perks, but the most recent perk nerfs really hurt the game. The aura reading has also gotten out of hand and you can‚Äôt really hide from killers anymore, even when using perks like distortion that hide you from some of the aura seeing perks. 

I‚Äôm just about at the point where I‚Äôm ready to uninstall this game because it‚Äôs clear that this game is very killer preferred and not fun for survivors anymore. It‚Äôs sad because of how many hours and money I‚Äôve invested in them over they many years. So, I don‚Äôt recommend this game as I would‚Äôve years ago. Best to find something else for your horror game craving; unless you're going to play killers... then it's literally made for you to win and have the most fun.

As an avid Dead by Daylight player, I have thoroughly enjoyed the game's immersive and thrilling experience. The asymmetrical horror genre, with its blend of survival and killer gameplay, has kept me hooked for hours on end. (No pun intended)  However, I can't help but feel a sense of exclusion as a straight player when it comes to the game's cosmetic choices.

One of the game's charming features is the variety of cosmetic items, including charms that allow players to personalize their characters. Dead by Daylight has admirably embraced diversity and inclusivity, evident in the availability of Pride charms representing different sexual orientations. While this is a commendable step towards creating a welcoming atmosphere for all players, it seems there is a missed opportunity to extend this inclusivity to the straight community.

As a straight person, I can't help but notice the absence of a charm representing the straight flag or heterosexuality in general. The game's commitment to recognizing and celebrating various sexual orientations should ideally extend to all players, regardless of their sexual identity. Including a straight flag charm would not only provide a more comprehensive representation but also reinforce the game's commitment to inclusivity.

It's important to note that advocating for inclusivity is not about diminishing the significance of any group but rather ensuring that everyone feels acknowledged and accepted. Dead by Daylight has taken commendable steps in this direction, but expanding the range of charms to include the straight flag would make the game's cosmetic offerings truly representative of its diverse player base.

In conclusion, while Dead by Daylight has successfully fostered an environment that embraces diversity, there is an opportunity to further enhance inclusivity by introducing a straight flag charm. This small addition would go a long way in making all players feel seen and valued within the Dead by Daylight community.

I have gone back and forth with this game for a long time. I originally got into it because Cheryl/Heather Mason was in it, but I stayed for the addicting game play. As time went on the experience got more and more tiresome and dull as issues began to pile up.

There is a lot wrong with this game, but on top of it all stands the developers themselves who have only recently begun to care again. They have started to make the game better and maybe in the future it will be good, but I cannot recommend this game in its current state. Getting to high ranks is a hollow experience as is most of Dead by Daylight. There are definitely fun and exhilarating moments, but they are washed away with all the garbage in the end. Even the atrocious rubber banding is still in the game.

As a positive note, the classic characters from other franchises are fantastic! They do make me wish they had their own modern games, however. The original characters are quite nice as well so there definitely is hope for this game in the future. The Roots of Dread DLC is really good and it introduces Haddie, a Survivor I grew to like.

Hey there, fellow gamers! Let me tell you about my absolute obsession: "Dead by Daylight." This game is an adrenaline-fueled rollercoaster of horror and excitement that I just can't get enough of.

First off, let's talk about the concept. It's brilliant. You've got a group of survivors trying to escape a nightmarish killer, all while trying to repair generators to open the exit gates. The tension is palpable as you try to stay hidden, avoid the killer's gaze, and coordinate with your teammates to make your escape.

And speaking of killers, the variety is insane. From classic horror icons like Michael Myers and Freddy Krueger to original killers with their own twisted backstories, there's something for every horror fan. Each killer has their own unique abilities and playstyle, keeping every match fresh and unpredictable.

But it's not just about surviving. Playing as the killer is a whole other thrill ride. Stalking your prey, setting traps, and unleashing your terrifying powers on unsuspecting survivors is an absolute blast. And let me tell you, nothing beats that rush of adrenaline when you finally catch your target.

The gameplay itself is smooth and polished, with intuitive controls and stunning visuals that really immerse you in the horror-filled world. And with regular updates and new content being added all the time, there's always something new to discover and explore.

Overall, "Dead by Daylight" is a masterpiece of horror gaming. It's intense, it's addictive, and it's guaranteed to keep you coming back for more. If you're a fan of horror or multiplayer games, do yourself a favor and give this one a try. Trust me, you won't regret it.

Some may call DBD the best game they've played. 
Other will refer to it as a broken, unbalanced mess of spaghetti code. 
Here's the thing: neither viewpoint is wrong.

Objectively speaking, understanding this game is a long journey. It will demand many hours from you. I've sunk 1.2k hours into this game, and there's still a lot I don't understand; how to loop efficiently, how to hug walls tightly without thinking, even hitting Great Skill Checks with any consistency is a challenge unless I'm using a perk build centred around doing it.

However, if you're the kind of person who doesn't have time to learn each of the game's mechanics, this can still be a game for you. This is still a game that you can play casually, without wanting to win every game.

Dead by Daylight is a game with a repetitive gameplay loop, a playerbase as likely to type "unalive yourself" in the endgame chat as the average MOBA fanbase, and it's likely going to remain completely impossible to properly balance, to boot. 

And yet, I can't bring myself not to recommend it, because when you put the time into understanding what you need to, it's a fun game. 
For Survivor, that fun could come from looping a Killer so well they leave you and go for someone else, or getting a 4-man escape against all odds. 
For Killer, it could come from hitting a seemingly impossible shot as a ranged Killer, or getting your first 4-kill.
For either , it could come from just using the stupidest, most meme-centric build, and somehow still winning a match.

If you decide to try it out, I'll see you in the Fog. 
If not, no problem.

(Bonus: Go to the store and type "WARRIORPUPPERS" in the "redeem code" section. It'll give you a cosmetic charm that was made as a tribute to a DBD player who passed away from ALS. RIP Max.)

So this is a game that is heavily balanced towards one side, the survivors. Though you may hear different, this game has a massive cult-like following with consistent gaslighting. The objective speed for survivors is significantly faster than objective speed for killers (on average 50% of their objective complete vs 8.3% for the killer) which leaves alot to be desired at top MMR gameplay. If you are competitive you will be in for a rude awakening when you find out the game isn't balanced towards the top players, its balanced towards the mid-tier players. This makes certain perks and add-ons for survivors HEAVILY abusable, and the better you get at the game the more vast this gap becomes. It has an amazing concept but unfortunately, the lack of proper balancing turns this game into a dopamine trip for bad players that want to flex and belittle killers. 

BE WARNED: It is a  fun game for survivor; you are in complete control and can bully the killer which makes alot of bad players seem better than they are.

It is TERRIBLE for killer because no matter what you do you are demonized in the community and you will be hit with constant nerfs which make no sense at all.


Edit: I have 10k hours between ps4/xbox on top of what I am accruing on steam. If you have any questions about any of the statistics I have listed feel free to send me a friend request and I can dm you, and don't get me wrong, I love this game. Its just a far cry from what it could be.

I love the thrill that comes with playing this game! I began playing this game years ago and stopped playing for a couple of years. Now that I am back I am still experiencing the same magic I was experiencing when I was playing before. If you love a little bit of spook in your game play, I highly recommend this game!

Game is fun and the licence power behind it make it essentially a one of a life time experience. Balancing can be all over the place but that's fine and to be expected from a game that is essentially just a party game with aspirations for a potential competitive future. 

It's unfortunately the community that ruins the game in the end. I met so many fun and lovable people on this game who I still consider some of my closest friends to this day, but those are few and far between. Most games will have either side (Killer or Survivor) be toxic to the other or both sides decide they want to just be jackasses to each other at the same time. It's so common. I used to have a group of like 10 people, where we would all rotate and play this game together, loving the time we all had with each other. But the more we played, the more the game drained us.

None of us play anymore. The toxicity, the sweaty attitude of like 80 % of the people you'll run into on either side, is just too much for a game like this, that can so easily go to a horrible experience for a person. While chatting isn't an option, the in game behavior is more than capable of being disruptive. As someone who's played League of Legends since 2010, this game's grieving methods have frustrated me far more than that game. 

Give it a shot. If you got excited by seeing a licensed character you love in this game, that's understandable. That's the point. Play it for a bit, see if it's for you. But if you end up feeling like somethings off, like you feel wronged, or grossed out by what you experienced through the gameplay, that's valid. On both sides. Both teams have equal opportunity to be dicks. 

Just be kind to each other guys.

Do not buy this game unless you are very competitive. It is not a "party game" anymore and most (if not all) fun elements of the game have been removed. This game is nothing compared to how it was in 2021 and before, it is unfortunately boring af now. The game has the most toxic and horrible communities you will ever come across. Entitled killers/survivors everywhere that you send you death threats if you don't follow their rules and play how they want you to.

For 3 years the developers have been prioritizing balancing over how fun the game at it's core is, from removing fun techs, adding new killers with copy paste powers from older killers (or just adding anti-loop snooze killers), patching harmless things like killers flying by adding invisible walls literally everywhere, nerfing survivors into the ground constantly, "balancing" maps (wtf) and adding clutter/trash everywhere, encouraging competitive playstyles and boring strategies, etc. This game has no real fun to it anymore, unless you want to play like you're in a tournament every match going against the same 3-4 killers with the same gen slowdown builds. This game is not what it used to be and the "Mostly Positive" reviews you see on this game is misleading and are reviews from a time where the game was great (<2021).

A decent multiplayer game.

While its balance could REALLY use some changes, the game offers a large variety of playstyles, having several Killers, including icons like Myers or Leatherface to choose from, even Chucky. 

Each character comes with their own 3 unique perks, which later on can be used on the other characters, this allows to change how you play the game, from being a stealthy survivor, to one centered around teamwork for example. 

The game unfortunately can be a bit overwhelming for newcomers due to the large amount of DLCs with content locked behind them, including the perks, some often being among the best.

The game while not free of bugs, runs smoothly for the most part, i rarely run into issues. 

The atmosphere of the game is also good, like mentioned earlier, each match can be a different experience since theres a large roster of killers, and each survivor can bring their own tricks to the field, so you have to be ready for whats coming. 

For those likely wondering, the matches are essentially a 4v1, 4 survivors and 1 killer, the survivors have to repair 5 Generators to power up the Exit Gates and escape the trial, the Killer on the other hand, has to protect said generators and find the survivors, down them, and hook them to be able to sacrifice them.

Thats pretty much it on a nutshell.

While the game can be fun, its hard to recommend to a newcomer due to all the progression needed to get even with an active player, plus having to buy all the DLCs

I give it a 7/10

[h1]Welcome all to my Dead by Daylight review.[/h1]

[i]Well, I'll comment on a few things to make it clear. I hope that with this analysis, people will understand what they can expect by joining the game.[/i] 

[i]Well, let's start by talking about the game's survivors.[/i]

[i]The game has several survivors, but they all have practically the same mechanics, which in this case is nothing more than running away, but it's not just running away, you can use things to delay the killer, make the killer lose time and give your partners time to do the survivor's objectives.[/i]

[b]What are the survivors' objectives in the match?[/b]

[i]The survivors' main task is to repair the generators so that they can escape the nightmare. Once they have repaired at least 5 generators scattered around the map, you will power up the map's exit gates, so you must go to the gate that has already been powered up, pull the lever, wait a while and open the gate so that all the survivors can escape.[/i]

[i]During this time you will have Killer, who will do everything to stop this process.[/i]

[b]What is Killer's objective in the match?[/b] 

[i]That's simple, stop the survivors from turning on the generators, knock the survivors down and put them on hooks so that they die over time, and of course, kill the survivors and keep them from escaping.[/i]

[i]The mechanics of the match work as follows. The survivors make the generators, some of the survivors spread out to make the Killer waste his time while his partners make the generators, and the Killer will follow these survivors, give them two attacks, knock them down and hook them. But you ask me, once they're on the hook, is it over? No, when the survivors are put on the hook, they need to be saved by the other survivors in the match. While the survivor is on the hook, he will lose life over time, but as far as I can tell, the life the survivor has on the hook is separate from the life he has off the hook. To put it simply, if the survivor is on the hook for the first time, his life on the hook will be at maximum, the second time on the hook it will be at half and the third time he will die.[/i]

[i]Now let's talk a bit about the killers in the game. This game has different Killers, each with their own skill and way of playing, as well as some that are taller and shorter, with a larger or smaller terror radius, as well as more speed when walking and less speed. The standard for those with 4.6M/s is to have a terror radius of 32 meters, but there are exceptions within the game, such as the famous Killer Michael Myers, who has a speed of 4.6 M/s, but his terror radius is 6 meters, quite short.[/i]

[i]The game also has Killers whose movement speed is 4.4M/s. These Killers in particular can be of medium or low height, as well as having a terror radius of 20 meters. These types of Killers are very different, but they are more difficult to play as they are slower than the survivor. You'll have to use your brain as much as possible to make good moves with these slower Killers. One of the most famous examples of Dead by Daylight is the Huntress. She's tall, has a medium terror radius and is slow compared to the other Killers, but she does have a long-distance ability. She can throw hatchets almost infinitely far, just use your head and you'll be able to make good moves. But there's a catch in the game, there's no crosshair in the middle of the screen showing you where to aim and "shoot", you'll have to learn that by playing, which means she's an intermediate/difficult Killer[/i]

[i]There are also those Killers who have more complex abilities that require a little more training time to master in-game, such as the Nurse who has the ability to teleport short and long distances, and can also go up and down floors, as well as pass through walls, but she is a Killer who, after using teleportation, gets fatigued for a short time. In her first teleport (1/2 charge), the fatigue is less compared to her second teleport (2/2 charge).[/i]

[i]There are also famous Killers from old movies like Freddy Krueger, PinHead and famous horror games like Nemesis (RE), PyramidHead (SilentHill), among others. Each with their own abilities, heights and terror rays.[/i]

This was my favorite game for 5 years straight.  Bought it 3 times on multiple consoles, thousands of hours.  However, the game is completely unplayable and I would never recommend this to anybody.  The decided the change EVERY single aspect of the game and it is now an empty husk of what it once was.  Additionally, if you plan on playing survivor by yourself, you will not win a single game. The game, Dead by Daylight, has been a source of great joy for me ever since I started playing it on PlayStation 4 a few years ago. Recently, I got the PC version of the game and although I didn't play it initially, I was amazed by the constant updates that the game received. I decided to give it a try and I was thrilled to see that the game still held the same charm for me. The game requires constant strategizing while being chased, which keeps me engaged and excited. It challenges me to think quickly and improves my cognitive abilities in all aspects of the game. The updates keep the game fresh and exciting, and the community is inclusive and supportive. Overall, my experience with Dead by Daylight has been incredibly positive and I look forward to playing it more.

[h1]Note: This review was written in 2020. Aside from a few outdated mentions of "upcoming" or "future" content, the rest of the review still reflects my opinion on the current state of the game, and thus won't be adjusted.[/h1]

[b]With the upcoming DLC being forced out prematurely, Behaviour Interactive (BHVR) have made it abundantly clear that community feedback, quality gameplay, and a satisfactory user experience all come second to routinely grabbing at our wallets.[/b]

For context, every year there are a total of 4 DLC's released, usually consisting of a new Killer, new Survivor, and ~50% of the time, a new map too. This 3 month development period between DLC's has consistently proven itself to be detrimental to the game's health, resulting in fundamentally broken and mismanaged content, and nowhere near enough time for the [i]unbelievably[/i] incompetent dev team to fix issues to any satisfactory degree, let alone take community feedback into account. Every new release breaks the game a little (or a lot) more, sometimes on such deeply integrated mechanical levels that it renders the game nearly unplayable for one or both of the game's roles. 
[b]Killers, perks, maps, and audio are just 4 of the extremely important elements of the game that are routinely broken and left unpatched for anywhere between days and months at a time.[/b] And just to be clear, I mean "broken" in the true, "This is not functioning as it should be," sense, not just little bugs that lead to funny moments.

[b][u]The upcoming DLC, "A Binding of Kin", is the first paid(!) DLC to be released with a log of bug fixes the content will be receiving in future patches. BHVR is selling an unfinished product with the full price tag, just so they can maintain their 4 paid DLC's per year quota.[/u][/b]

This is completely unacceptable. This company has repeatedly shown utter contempt for their community, and simply do not deserve the passionate fanbase they've somehow amassed. 

As someone who has wasted far too many hours, and dollars, on this game, I will not give BHVR one more cent until there are serious amendments made to the way this company treats its content, and its community. I strongly urge you to take a similar stance.

We absolutely deserve better.

For those considering the game, let me make one thing known: Without DLCs, your experience will be subpar at best. Perks which are used to counter toxic behaviour are locked and spread between multiple DLCs, some original (which can now thankfully be acquired relatively quickly thanks to the new Prestige system), and some licensed which can only be bought with money or getting lucky on the Shrine of Secrets. Furthermore, despite some of the newer killers being flawed (Chucky being able to traverse the map quickly by never breaking pallets, buggy Xenomorph tentacle etc), most of the balance patches and reworks BHVR has done within the last year or two have been great!

There is still the issue of many killers ignoring pallets and the fact that for a killer to be good these days they have to come with a teleport/roaming ability, but survivors do have access to some pretty good perks to help them in chase

Problematic killers and play-styles (3 genning, camping, tunneling, holding W as survivor and the Skull Merchant) are slowly being addressed, but most of the effective counterplay is still locked behind DLC

New balance patches and QoL improvements are still being pushed out, and DBD is looking better and better as time passes by. I will however say that the latest event gamemode, that being Lights Out, was an unbalanced nightmare that did not retain my engagement for longer than 3 matches before it became miserable to play. Also, SBMM still sucks, and has recently gotten worse for those who are good enough to be in high MMR but don't want to sweat it out every game

TLDR: Game has slowly improved since my last review, but still has a high barrier to entry that makes soloQ miserable without certain DLCs and fundemental understanding of game mechanics. Worth a buy these days, but only if you're looking to invest significant time outside of the game to understand the gameplay loop and mechanics

Dead by Daylight is an attractive and addictive game. It has the potential to be a great game. Sadly, because the developers are lazy and have no clue (or care to find a clue) of what they want this game to be, it has no business being a great game. This is pathetic and frustrating for anyone who devotes time and/or money to any game, but after over 1350 hours of game time, I can confidently say that this toxic and mean-spirited game is not worth your time. The developers always seem distant and do not care about the future of the game beyond how much money they can fleece from the gaming community with lackluster chapter releases and flashy new cosmetics. While I am still playing the game occasionally, I have decided to not spend another dime of my own money on it because of this game's condition. Dead by Daylight is a buggy, embarrassingly glitchy, grossly unbalanced game that encourages the worst in people and is little more than BHVR's shameless cash-grab disguised as fun. The developers do not care about you or your opinions; they do not even care about maintaining the basic functionality of their own game. My recommendation is to save yourself the time, money, and disappointment. Invest in games that actually deserve it.

"Dead by Daylight" transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, offering an immersive and adrenaline-pumping experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats. With its innovative asymmetrical multiplayer gameplay, the game delivers endless thrills and challenges that captivate audiences worldwide.

At its core, "Dead by Daylight" is a masterclass in tension and suspense. The game's atmospheric environments and spine-tingling sound design create an immersive experience that plunges players into a world of palpable dread and uncertainty. Every match is a heart-pounding race against time, as survivors must outsmart their relentless pursuer while the killer stalks their prey with ruthless determination.

What truly sets "Dead by Daylight" apart is its dynamic gameplay and deep strategic depth. With a diverse roster of killers and survivors, each with their own unique abilities and playstyles, every match offers a fresh and exhilarating experience. Whether you're hunting down survivors with supernatural powers or evading a merciless killer through cunning tactics, the game constantly challenges players to think on their feet and adapt to ever-changing circumstances.

Furthermore, "Dead by Daylight" boasts a thriving community and robust multiplayer ecosystem. From intense 1v4 showdowns to collaborative team play, the game fosters camaraderie and competition among players of all skill levels. With regular updates and new content additions, including iconic characters from horror franchises like "Silent Hill" and "Resident Evil," the game continually evolves and keeps players coming back for more.

Despite its undeniable strengths, "Dead by Daylight" is not without its flaws. Matchmaking issues and balancing concerns occasionally mar the experience, frustrating players and disrupting the flow of gameplay. Additionally, the game's reliance on microtransactions for cosmetic items and certain characters may alienate some players, detracting from the overall enjoyment of the experience.

In summary, "Dead by Daylight" is a tour de force in multiplayer horror gaming, offering a pulse-pounding experience that is as exhilarating as it is immersive. With its innovative gameplay, deep strategic depth, and thriving community, the game stands as a testament to the power of interactive entertainment to captivate and thrill audiences. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the genre, "Dead by Daylight" promises endless hours of heart-stopping action and unforgettable moments, making it a must-play title for any gaming enthusiast.

Dead by Daylight is a gripping and intense gaming experience that brings a unique twist to the horror genre. The asymmetrical gameplay, where one player takes on the role of the killer and others as survivors, creates an atmosphere of constant suspense and excitement.

What sets Dead by Daylight apart is its roster of iconic killers and survivors, each with their own distinct abilities and backstories. The game's attention to detail in bringing these characters to life adds an extra layer of depth to the overall narrative.

The ever-evolving nature of the game is commendable, with regular updates introducing new content, killers, and survivors. This commitment to keeping the gameplay fresh and unpredictable ensures that Dead by Daylight remains engaging even after countless hours of play.

Whether you're working together with friends to outsmart the killer or testing your survival skills in solo play, Dead by Daylight offers a thrilling experience. The game's chilling atmosphere, combined with strategic gameplay mechanics, makes it a standout choice for horror enthusiasts and multiplayer fans alike. If you're ready for heart-pounding moments and strategic gameplay, Dead by Daylight is an excellent choice that consistently delivers on its promises.

Its a good and strangely addictive game worth picking up, so why not give it a shot?

I got this game bc I'm a horror fan and pretty new to playing video games (at the time of purchase). I love the customization options and all of the wonderful killer crossovers as well as their original creations! Really great stuff.

On the other hand, they are constantly changing survivor perks and how they work due to killer mains complaining. It is a 4v1 game, instead of changing what they have already released, why not add counter perks instead? Stop changing Perks every few months and then wondering why the community is annoyed and upset. 

It's a fun challenge creating the right build for your play style, but at this point, they've changed so much I don't even get to be creative with the builds anymore. I just have to use what few perks(most of which have been nerf'd beyond belief) I can to survive all of the tunneling and camping killers. 

I've lost count of the amount of games that I've played where the killer tunnels out each survivor because "It's the only way to win" for them. There is no point in playing as a survivor if you get tunneled out before your team is even able to get one Gen done.  

On the incredibly rare occasion that I have come across a killer that doesn't tunnel/camp, it's an incredibly fun game! Most of the time they still get a 4k and I'm not even mad because the challenge was fun!

It has gotten to the point that even the Killer mains are creating videos showing how impossible it is to go against them using certain perks. 

I want to love this game the way that I did when I first started playing it, but every update seems to make me want to play it less and less. I know I'm not alone with this, the Behavior Devs gotta just listen to the community.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[h1]Wasted potential[/h1]
[b]TL;DR[/b] Fun game for a while. Unfortunately plagued by greedy microtransactions, obvious imbalances, and some clunky mechanics.

Was peer pressured into buying this game, and we've played intermittently for years, especially when Halloween comes around. However, after playing some on my own and really seeing what the game has to offer, I cannot recommend the game as a whole.

Don't get me wrong - I have a lot of hours in the game, almost entirely as a survivor, and have generally enjoyed most of them. But this has been a trickle of hours over the years, during which I've only seen the game continue to double down on my complaints.

[b]The good[/b]

This game does a lot of things well. The general pace of the game is nice, and it's clear the concept was well thought out. Gameplay [i]usually[/i] feels smooth enough, and the game is graphically pleasing. I love the feeling of dread and while repairing generators and hearing the terror music get louder, shortly followed by a panicked decision making process on whether to hide or run.

My favorite thing from this game is that almost all your bloodpoints, used for level progression, are based on your personal performance rather than wins/losses. Sure, you can get unlucky in a game and die pretty quickly, but its easy to just hop in another and try again. Overall, concept is cool and there is lots of potential.

However...

[b]The bad[/b]

First and foremost, the He-Who-Shall-Not-Be-Named of PC gaming, [b]microtransactions[/b]. And I mean [b]a LOT[/b]. You should not release a game where literally 3/4 of the released characters cannot be unlocked without spending more money on a, excuse the emphasis, [b]PAID!!!![/b] game. Since I've started playing over the past few years, they have not released a [i]single[/i] new free survivor or killer. This is obviously a money grab, emphasized more with the incredible imbalance of some paid features, primarily killers & their perks.

Aside from greed and lack of care, the game just feels repetitive after a while. Short of the (admittedly, quite cool) collaborations providing lots of new maps to see, the gameplay loop doesn't really change. Perhaps the most interesting part of the game is building out your survivor/killer and trying new tactics, but when most of the options are behind a paywall, that kind of defeats the purpose. And in the same vein, leveling up & getting what you need is a bit of a grind, so it'll take a while before you even get any meaningful options for your build.

The game feel for me is [i]fine[/i], but a bit awkward. Movement can be wonky, and hitboxes on survivors are super strange at time. You'll find a lot of situations where the game is clearly favoring the killer.

Also, lobbies take a little while to find as survivors, but are [i]near impossible[/i] to find as the killer. So if being a killer is what excites you most, just go in expecting 7 minute breaks between each of your games while you wait to find a match. But to be fair, this might ease up as your killer rank improves, and I haven't given this a real good shot again in a few years.

[b]In conclusion...[/b]

[i]Maybe[/i] buy the game on sale, if you get the chance.

This is a very shaky "not recommended" review. I like the core game and will probably keep playing as long as my friends keep inviting me, but the awkward game feel, killer imbalances, and mass amount of paywall-locked characters mock me just a little too much. Consider this less of a "this game sucks" and more of a "this developer sucks".

Stop supporting predatory low life companies. This company has proven time and time again they haven't the faintest idea of how to develop or market a video game product. Let them rot and go under.

A game all about being chased by your favorite thriller killers!
Honestly, some of the most fun I've had in a long time and a really creative idea. Many of the killers I've come across are set to win but willing to be a little silly too. I don't know why but that really makes the game for me. 
Even loosing is a good time, as I love horror games and being scared and startled is part of the fun for me. With that though, if you don't like being scared and the intensity of being chased or having to hide, then this definitely isn't a game for you.
Wish I had picked this up a long time ago. Of course, I may be looking through rose-tinted glasses but I like the game for what it is at it's core. its spooky and it's fun, I don't intend to take it so seriously.

Add on: What really hooked me was the addition of Resident Evil and Silent hill characters. I really like the cross over characters, I think that's a really fun idea and look forward to more!

After playing 78 hours of Dead by Daylight, I can honestly say that this game is fundamentally broken.
While running around as a serial killer and killing the other players is fun, there are some huge minuses to the game.
One of them being that I have to hold back when I play killer, most of the times I'll pretend I didn't see that guy and let him save his friend.
The only way for Survivors to actually beat me fair and square is to be sneaky and make noises on the other side of the map to trick me away from the other Survivors.
Something that is seen as cancerous by the Killers, such as "Flashlight blinding the Killer mid-animation", "Looping" around an obstacle forever or until I give up and "body blocking me until the Survivor manages to wiggle free" is the only other way for Survivors to actually counter a Killer.
The only response I have to any of the above is to Alt+Tab out of the game or kill one of them and camp their hooks.
But Survivors hate being camped, it essentially removes them from the game and if they fuck up early, they can end up being an Observer for 10-20 minutes.
There is no reason for me to not hook and camp a Survivor, there's nothing in the game preventing me from doing so, I just have to "be a good guy and play 'fair'" for it not to happen.

This game is like Hide and Seek, except we don't have many furniture, I already know the hiding spots and I have to pretend that I get shit in my eyes every 3rd minute.

But killing people is fun so it gets a pass. Edit: It doesn't.

"We can't keep this up" A quote from the devs about the health decline of the game getting worse due to lack of attention. Instead of giving the health of the game attention, they aim for more money. The game will continue to decline. Has been for years now and they've said they know why, we've told them why, and they refuse to change.

I used to love this game. Unfortunately the developers don't listen very well to it's player base. I'm a killer main, and I have loved Pyramid Head since release. There have been zero adjustments to him since release. I can't have fun with him because his play style, add-ons, and perk combos leave only 1 or 2 different builds and survivors know the builds. This makes for extremely boring play. New players don't get generator slowing perks without buying past the paywall. The fixes that they finally implement, have been fixes people have been asking for, for YEARS. There are so many more issues, but this post is already pretty long.
DBD is a money grab now, and that's at it's best. Don't buy it if you're new, it's wasted money. Just wait for the next asymmetrical game that will top it. It's been almost 10 years, so I'm sure something will come out soon

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding garlic bread recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients
4 cloves garlic, crushed
2 tablespoons butter
2 tablespoons extra-virgin :wink: olive oil
1 loaf crusty bread, split
3 tablespoons grated cheese, Parmigiano or Romano, optional
Chopped fresh parsley

Directions
Combine garlic, butter, and oil in a microwave safe dish or in a small saucepan. Heat garlic and butter and oil in microwave for 1 minute or in a small pot over moderate-low heat for 3 minutes.

Toast split bread under broiler. Remove bread when it is toasted golden brown in color. Brush bread liberally with garlic oil. Sprinkle with cheese, if using, and parsley. If you added cheese, return to broiler and brown 30 seconds. Cut into chunks and serve.

This here is an honest review. This game can be very FUN! You play Killer or Survivor both have ups and downs, like all games.  But this game, no the company intentionally has taken away all psychological safety while playing it for extended periods it becomes addictive in all the wrong ways the bloodweb is so much like gambling which is how you get items and perks it gives you tiny dopamine hits where you find yourself thinking, oh this time the perk will show up. If you have ever done hard drugs or ever had to go to AA, please don't play this game for your own mental health and personal safety, ask many players how many of them have quit and have found themselves coming right back to this game against their better judgment. Telling themselves this time will be different I promise. I can not blame the community for being so toxic, which it very much is. I feel sorry for them I mean they are strategically defending this game in hopes of otherwise convincing sound-minded folks to come in and play. This game is like a drug of course they would defend it with every ounce of their being creating false truths and character attacking to defend the game. I keep kicking myself the name of the company that made this game is called Behavior. So I can not with a sound mind recommend this game to anyone, I have played over 1,000 hours of this game on Steam and over 1,000 hours on PlayStation and unfortunately, I will probably keep playing this drug/game until the proper help becomes available. Careful thinking you are smarter than Behavior you are not, look at their licenses and the gameplay of Dead by Daylight they know what they are doing, so much of the game has remained the same. for how many years with tiny tweaks to the formula, no new game modes, the same strategies, the same maps, and the most fun killers you will have to pay for. Is it pay to win? That is up to you and how you view what pay to win means.

I only play this game because it's the only game me and most of my friends have. But if we're being honest, this game sucks. The devs don't listen to their player base, and they continue to nerf and buff perks when they're fine. Deadhard has been nerfed several times and it doesn't even work half the time. Pallets don't drop when you're on TOP of them. Hits that shouldn't hit, do hit. You will often get teleported to the other side of a pallet both as survivor and killer and get fucked because of it.
They released a killer that received the worst reception ever and still released her to the public despite the negative perception and "buff" and "nerf" her when she's just a bad killer concept. They nerf survivors into the ground and it feels more like you're playing a victim. The devs think that tunneling and camping are valid ways to play but it's the most boring game you will ever have and you will tier down because of that. Even when playing as killer it is not that much better. Hits that should hit don't.
The game is just unfair, broken, and not that much fun. You will run into the most selfish survivors when you're not with friends, and even when you are with friends you will most likely run into a tunneling or a camping killer. Because the devs think thats a good way to play. All in all. Just a horrible game with a horrible fanbase.

My main gripes:
1. The gameplay loop is dull and lacking. All you're ever gonna do is repair generators, or defend generators, with secondary fluff inbetween. I'd really like to see some other game modes, but after 5 years of no innovation I doubt I ever will.
2. Most of the characters are mute. I get that for survivors it's a stealth thing, but the dialogue wheel would've still been a nice way to flesh out characters. The game lacks personality badly, what's the point of all these brand names if you're not gonna let them speak? And there's no reason for killers not to have taunts. So much wasted roleplay potential. You'll never "you can run but you can't hide!" in this game.
3. Due to the nature of the game any slasher movie atmosphere potential that might've is wasted and tainted by gamification. The killer is disrespected like crazy, ran around in infinite loops (they really are infinite by definition) and generally isn't being avoided by skilled players. It looks a lot like Saturday cartoon with poor villain getting dunked on with pallets, blinded by flashlights, stunned by locker doors, etc. I swear, any day now they'll add survivor perk that lets you punch the killer in the honker directly.
At least Ghostface feels right at home given how inadequate he's portrayed in the movie.
4. Rampant cheating at mid to high ranks. Apparently "Easy" in Easy Anti-Cheat stands for  "easy to bypass".

Now the pros:
1. Tons of licensed characters and maps, from Silent Hill's infamous school to Resident Evil's Raccon City police station, from Ash Williams to Michael Myers. It's a dream team. If only the actual game was fun to play.
That's all for the pros.

This game is fucking horrible

I‚Äôve always had a love/hate relationship with this game. It is inherently imbalanced, which is a source of many frustrations, but there *was* fun to be had, especially with friends and alcohol. This game is heavily favored for killers. For some context, survivors had some tools to combat the imbalance, but they were heavily exploited: infinite loops, glitches, insta-blinds, hatch mechanics, etc. But over the years the pendulum has swung the other way. Every tool survivors had had, in-game mechanic, or otherwise, has been taken away. Gens take longer to repair, survivor perks have been nerfed, killer perks have been buffed, killers vault faster, ranks have been obfuscated, and match making has always been broken (i.e. players are *not* of similar skill-level), loops have been patched out.

One of the biggest sources of frustration are killer-strategies that ruin the experience: tunnelling (hyper fixating on one-survivor to get them out the game as soon as possible). Strategically, this makes sense, the sooner you can take out a survivor, the better odds none of the survivors will escape ‚Äì survivor‚Äôs survival is predicated on cooperation and distracting the killer. The problem: the survivor that falls victim of this strategy isn't afforded a change to participate in normal gameplay - this is compounded with the aforementioned nerfs/patches. One of the last mechanics that remained to combat this behavior was blocking ‚Äì you could block killers that intentionally ruined the experience, so in theory, you wouldn‚Äôt be matched against them again. But, a fairly recent update removed the ability to block players so now there is nothing being done about game-ruining strategies. Wouldn‚Äôt be as bad if the match-making ever worked, but it doesn‚Äôt. If anything, these strategies are encouraged and rewarded. Now as I write this, after having being in a full squad of friends, inebriated, and trying to play for fun, I just feel deflated. Fun was not had after our 6+ matches were fun. 1200+ hours in, and I‚Äôm done. 

Bottom line, this game is so imbalanced that is is just not fun ‚Äì I say this as player that uses unconventional perks and plays inebriated (i.e. I don‚Äôt take this game seriously): it‚Äôs so broken you can‚Äôt even make your own fun anymore. The devs have blatantly said through their actions/updates survivors are not meant to survive. The fun has always been in the glimmer of hope, and the unpredictability and ensuing chaos. Now matches are predictable ‚Äì killers will result to cheap tactics without penalty, and I will die on hook. I‚Äôve always said, ‚Äúif I‚Äôm going to get tunneled out in the first couple minutes of the match, why even bother loading me in!?‚Äù - this time, standing by my words. Good riddance.

I have a lot of issues with this game. I could tell you how fun it can be, or I could tell you what is most likely to happen. I'll go with the latter. If you queue survivor and the killer finds you and hooks you, they'll probably just wait nearby for someone to pick you up and put you back on the hook again. I think it's a horrible thing they've done where they don't separate Casual play and Ranked play unless you already have like 4 other friends who can play the game with you. I don't have 4 friends with this game. Additionally, I  think from the killer's perspective survive with friends is kind of unfair. There's literally perks in the game that let you know where people are. There's no voice chat or text chat, but if you're on Discord or Teamspeak you completely get around all of that. I think survivors can be really toxic, too. There's literally only about a minute of chat before and after the match and somehow survivors still manage to be toxic. It makes it kinda horrible inviting friends to play knowing they'll just get farmed and raged at in post game. Now, if you can get over all of that unbalanced gameplay, then this game is probably for you. It's supposed to be a team game, but I've found that if you're in a group on a call, it's unfair to the killer by a large margin. If you're a survivor and not in the group in the call, they'll probably be jerks to you and leave you to die and then talk shit at you in the postgame chat. It makes it pretty impossible to recommend this game to anyone. 

(EDIT: The new skill-based matchmaking is so broken that it can't even match you up at your proper rank, with rank 18 and 19 killers (ranked out of 20) often having to face survivors who are half their rank and therefore significantly more experienced or vice versa. At least before if you lost, you lost to someone who was your equal ranking or within 2 or 3 of you)


EDIT 11/22/2021: Still wouldn't recommend this game to my worst enemy. This game sucks for killers. I say this as someone who has hit Rank 1 Survivor and Rank 1 Killer.

EDIT 7/19/22: They added a prestige update which should have cut down grind, but has taken away teachable killer perks from me since I haven't prestiged every killer. This patch is terrible and I continue to not recommend this game.

EDIT 6/10/23: There is a rank reset every 13th that sets everyone back to the bottom, which is good. I didn't mention that before. There are also matchmaking incentives when one role is not as full to encourage people to switch. However, an issue that negatively affects match quality is that everyone is currently rage quitting when they get caught a single time or disconnecting from being caught once, pretty much dooming their 3 teammates.

They've got a cool event going on at least

In this game's dark world, I'm all alone,
Chased by shadows, far from home.
In Dead by Daylight, I'm always the one,
Targeted, hunted, no place to run.

The killer's focus, so harsh and keen,
Makes every moment feel so mean.
Tunnelled through the game, it's just not fair,
Alone with my despair, gasping for air.

Every chase feels like a dead end,
No allies, no help, just a trend.
The loneliness in this endless chase,
Brings tears I can hardly face.

The sadness of being the only target,
Is a heavy load, hard to forget.
Stuck in this cycle, no escape in sight,
In the darkness, I lose my fight.

It's not just a game, but a mirror of pain,
Of being left out, again and again.
The sadness of tunnelling, deep and real,
In this virtual world, it's all I feel.

So here I am, in the game's cold grasp,
My spirit fading with each clasp.
In the shadow of the chase, I quietly weep,
Alone, in this game, a wound so deep.

Some locations will send you into despair when playing as maniacs (when the map is full of rooms, and looking for hooks that are unclear where), or survivors (when the map is open, when there are no places to hide or make jumps/overturn boards). I may be a masochist, but I love this game. If you like horror or survival games, if you are ready to work like crazy or pay real money for your favorite maniac or survivor (yes! You pay for the game and for the characters from the game!), then I definitely recommend it!

Dead by Daylight: A Rollercoaster of Thrills and Frustration

First off, let's talk about the good stuff. Dead by Daylight is like that snack you can't stop munching on‚Äîit's addicting as heck. The rush of narrowly escaping death or pulling off a clutch save is enough to get your heart racing faster than a caffeinated chihuahua. Plus, the variety of killers and survivors keeps things fresh. I mean, who doesn't want to outrun a chainsaw-wielding maniac or play hide-and-seek with a ghost?

But here's the tea, folks: the game can turn sour quicker than expired milk. The community can sometimes be saltier than a bag of potato chips left out in the sun too long. From rage-quitting survivors to camping killers, it's like navigating through a minefield of bad vibes. And let's not even get started on the unbalanced gameplay. Ever feel like you're running a marathon with cement shoes while the killer's sprinting in Nikes? Yeah, me too.

Sure, we get it‚Äîthe killer's gotta kill. But there's a fine line between playing the game and being a total buzzkill. Some killers just don't get the memo that it's possible to have fun without ruining someone's day. But fear not, my friends, because amidst the sea of toxic players, there are a few shining stars‚Äîthe fun killers who make the game worth playing. Whether it's a spooky nurse or a sneaky pig, these killers know how to keep things interesting without making you wanna rage-quit.

So, is Dead by Daylight worth the grind? Absolutely. Just be prepared for a rollercoaster ride of thrills, chills, and the occasional urge to throw your controller at the wall. And hey, if all else fails, remember: there's always another match just around the corner. So grab your flashlight, sharpen your machete, and get ready for one hell of a showdown.

This game has come a long way. I really hope they bring cross progression into the game because plenty of players, including myself, have made the switch from console to PC and are missing out on some of those sweet, sweet Rift charms that we spent hours grinding for, as well as plenty of progress and items on several killers and survivors.

BHVR has just recently made the functionality with the Lights Out mode; we can expect to see new gamemodes with this new framework. This is some pretty exciting stuff for all veteran players.

Killer right now is very strong if you play your cards right. I know survivors will complain about tunneling and killers sometimes feel forced to do it with how competitive the game has gotten. I think there are some measures that can be taken to make changes to the problems that are presented in the game; however, I understand that BHVR is walking on thin ice when it comes to changes as sometimes it can become gamebreaking... example: old overcharge and call of brine.

With the recent Hillbilly changes and adjustments to other killers, playing survivor is progressively getting more fun. Some killers sincerely need an entire rework or change, such as Skull Merchant who has such a complex kit that it takes a f%cking dictionary to learn all of her capabilities... when compared to Hillbilly who is inarguably stronger and just "chainsaw go zoom grahhhh", y'know.

I think BHVR needs to continue to veer away from overly complex killers and continue in simplicity in strength. Every top tier killer has some form of counterplay in some regard that is related to their strength... i.e. Nurse is hit hard by stealth because she moves so slowly its slower to investigate every nook and cranny; Blight can be countered by good movement and understanding how his bumps work; Hillbilly can be countered with use of windows and the CTRL key (hahaha).

Anyways, that's enough yapping. If you are new to the game, there are plenty of content creators that can teach you the ropes in just a few videos for both killer and survivor. I strongly recommend picking up a killer you are interested in first, and then moving onto killers that you would like to get perks from. Same goes for survivor.

Having invested a substantial 882 hours into Dead by Daylight, it's high time I revisit and update my review to reflect the wealth of experience gained.

Dead by Daylight remains a stellar horror game, continuing to provide an immersive and entertaining experience. The core concept of four survivors evading a relentless killer persists, offering a consistently thrilling gameplay dynamic. The extensive playtime has only deepened my appreciation for the game's nuances.

One of the standout features is the extensive variety offered by both survivors and killers. The multitude of perks available for each, coupled with distinct abilities, adds layers of strategy and complexity to each match. The randomized maps, a feature I highlighted in my initial review, continue to impress by ensuring that no two encounters play out the same way, even on familiar terrain, because there are different layouts to almost all of the maps as well. That means that even if you play the same map, you won't be getting the exact same one!

Remarkably, with 882 hours under my belt, Dead by Daylight has maintained its stability and polish. The absence of significant issues over such an extensive period reinforces the game's overall quality and durability. Another aspect that I love, is the continual introduction of licensed killers and survivors. The inclusion of iconic characters like Wesker, Nemesis, and Michael Myers has significantly enriched the gameplay experience, creating a captivating blend of horror fandom and intense multiplayer action.

The infusion of these recognizable faces into the game not only pays homage to beloved franchises but also introduces unique abilities and playstyles that diversify the overall Dead by Daylight experience. Each licensed killer and survivor brings their own set of perks and characteristics, seamlessly integrating their distinct personalities into the game's evolving narrative.

Wesker, known for his sinister presence in the Resident Evil series, Nemesis, the relentless pursuer from the same franchise, and the infamous Michael Myers from Halloween all contribute to the varied and thrilling encounters players can experience. The familiarity with these characters adds an extra layer of tension, knowing that you're being pursued by some of the most iconic figures in horror.

The developers' commitment to consistently adding such renowned characters demonstrates a dedication to keeping Dead by Daylight fresh and relevant. It not only caters to the existing fan base but also attracts new players intrigued by the prospect of facing off against or embodying these well-known personas.

For those who share a passion for horror games and have dedicated significant time to Dead by Daylight, the enduring appeal of the game is evident. It not only captures attention but retains its grip, making it a worthwhile investment for any horror gaming enthusiast. I recommend it to all my horror fan boys and girls alike! 8.5/10

Well, let's start with parameters that will matter to almost any player: Gameplay
Overall, when you start playing this game you can have a lot of fun: you can experiment with different perks, open new survivors and killers, play with your friends. In your first game you'll be scared (100% sure). But after playing a while you will notice subtle [u]cheaters[/u] that ruin your game. "Behaviour" is not going to change this because they said they don't see a problem with that. Okay, moving to community.

[b]Toxic survivors or killers[/b]. If you will play more, you will have higher ranks and this is the point where you will see t-bags or facecamping in every 2-3 games. If you're unlucky, then be prepared for insults in post-game chat. At first, you might consider this offensive or annoying, but you have to remember that these people are angry. If you can deal with all this stuff, then i will talk about things that will (finally) make you exhausted.

[i]Servers[/i]. As much as i know, your hits(or escapes) will go through validation from the server that decides whether you get hit or not. And most of the time, if the survivor uses dead hard(David King's perk), then your hit is not going to be considered as a down state for the survivor. In other words, survivors that are using dead hard can just escape your hit and continue to run, even when you saw blood and heard their screams. You can think that this is not going to be a big problem, but at least 1 survivor in every match uses it(mostly, it's minimum 2). 

How i see this game over the time? For me, it's getting boring. People use the same meta perks(both survivors and killers) and even if you will use some fun perks - you will lose because the other side don't think the same way you do. For some reason, Behaviour is starting to realize only [b]now[/b] that there are perks that are waaaay stronger than others. And it's the perks that you will see in every single game. 
Right now I have fun only playing in custom games because custom game with friends(who aren't tryhards) look like what this game was supposed to be - entertaining, scary and unpredictable. Sadly, it's not. It's own community(with a little help of work team) that is destroying any fun both sides can have in this game.

UPD AT 15 FEB. 2024:

Honestly, i don't know what got into me, but i started playing again after a long period of brake. And quite frankly, this game had many changes happen to it(which i didn't like - i miss old Dead hard, for example). BUT. Somehow those changes...made game better? I guess i just had to trust the process. I don't play much with friends, like i did before, but even playing alone - it's still fun and exciting. I don't know what they sprinkled in this boiling soup of pain and joy, but it worked - i enjoy the game the same way i enjoyed it when i just started(which was 2 years ago). New killers honestly make me scream, especially Chucky. I think this game is going to keep changing for the better and i'm here for it.

This game is interesting, and the aesthetics are neat, especially at the level of the killers... But it is not balanced at all, and the whole game is clearly designed for the survivors to get by, and ultimately, at least one of the four. Survivors can do anything, including gain superhuman powers, while killers are reduced to running around like old men, jumping through windows like pensioners, getting stunned by sticks or lamps, not to mention time consuming. recharge between two attacks, the too many hiding places, and the numerical differences (the groups communicate by microphone). It's a game where only surviving players can really have fun because they're sure to win, and where killer players are constantly being bullied, exactly the opposite of what happens in a horror movie...

This game use to be fun when it first came out until before covid hit. Nonetheless with the constant changes to the game, it has become increasing frustrating and unplayable. The cons of this game outweigh the pros. Here are some issues with the game:

1. F'ing pu_c developers won't put voice chat. 
2. The rank system is horrible. A experienced solo player will often than not get matched up with inexperienced players.
3. Toxic players.
4. The wiggle mechanic is useless and utter garbage. It needs a rework. Hooks are placed too close to each other. THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO POINT IN WIGGLING. The wiggling meter moves to slow. Here is a solution: increase the movement rate or decrease the successful skill check as the meter gets closer to full. Also,  someone has to take a hit and the timing has to be perfect for a captured survivor to escape. Majority of the time, killers have no problem with the survivor wiggling in their grasp.
5. Toolboxes and health kits charges have exponentially decreased in usage/repairing a generator. 
6. The hit radius from the killer is ridiculous - you can still get hit when fully vaulted over a window or pallet. 
7. There are too many constant changes to the maps and game-play that are not necessary nor needed. This is done in favor of the killer because the placement of some windows or pallets in certain maps are op. (They - the developers even acknowledged this in a recent update and took out some pallets. Also, the success rate of escaping was probably too high and the developers probably wanted to decrease this amount. Which lead to camping hooked survivors, disconnects, complaints, and less players willing to play as the killer.
8. A stacked killer will win the majority of their games unless they ride the small bus to school.
9. Some killers are overpowering including the perks they use and offerings.
10. This game support the alphabet community. Players can equip a rainbow badge.
11. When you are cleansing a totem, the character ( while uninjured) will make a sound like they are having a hard time taking a dump. Like why add this to the game? This gives away your position, especially if a killer is near by or a survivor is getting chased. 
12. The camping meter that the developers implemented is stupid. The timer will still be shown after a survivor's second hook. Why? There is no reason to show it because at this point, the survivor has no chance to escape from being hooked. Also, if all generators are completed, the camping hook timer becomes unavailable. Another dumb decision because this gives the killer the opportunity to camp one hooked survivor because he or she gets dominated in game or is just a loser.

Update: 

The game was fun years ago when it first came out. It was my absolute favorite game for years! Now it's just an unbalanced mess. Sometimes it's heavily killer-sided, others survivor-sided. The devs are too busy pushing out skins and new killers/survivors instead of working on balance, and sadly at this point there's too many killers and survivors available that balancing the game seems almost impossible. 

The gameplay is waaay too repetitive. I wish they had added different ways to escape similar to Friday the 13th or even Texas Chainsaw Massacre, like the devs originally promised during the early years. Instead, they change things that most people aren't asking for, like UI updates and perk overhauls that somehow made the balance problem more obvious! 

There's a ton of OP perks on both sides that EVERYONE picks, regardless of character. Clearly this indicates a balance issue, especially when there are over 200 perks available to choose from.

The amount of paid DLC for this game is absolutely terrible, and a very obvious cash grab at this point.

This is not the DbD it was when I first reviewed it, and I can't recommend this to other players in its current state.

Dead by Daylight masterfully captures the essence of a horror movie in a competitive multiplayer game format, offering a uniquely thrilling experience that‚Äôs both simple in concept and rich in execution. At its core, the game is surprisingly straightforward: four survivors must escape from a killer in a closed environment. Yet, within this simplicity lies a deep, competitive edge that keeps both newcomers and veterans on their toes.

The game‚Äôs mechanics are easy to grasp but hard to master, making it accessible to players of all skill levels. Whether you‚Äôre strategizing with teammates to evade the killer or using the environment to your advantage, every match offers a new, fun challenge that‚Äôs as unpredictable as it is exciting. The variety of killers and survivors, each with their unique abilities, adds layers of strategy and replayability that keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging.

What sets Dead by Daylight apart is its ability to surprise. Just when you think you have the game figured out, it throws a curveball that changes the dynamics of the match. This could be a sudden appearance of the killer, a new obstacle, or an unexpected ally move, keeping the adrenaline pumping and ensuring that no two games feel the same.

Moreover, Dead by Daylight fosters a competitive atmosphere that‚Äôs hard to find elsewhere. The thrill of narrowly escaping the killer‚Äôs grasp or successfully hunting down every survivor is unmatched, driving players to constantly improve their skills and strategies. This competitive spirit, combined with the game‚Äôs fun and engaging gameplay, makes Dead by Daylight a standout title in the multiplayer genre.

In conclusion, Dead by Daylight is a must-play for anyone looking for a game that‚Äôs simple to understand, competitive at heart, full of surprises, and, above all, incredibly fun. It‚Äôs a testament to how a straightforward concept can be transformed into a deep, engaging experience that keeps players coming back for more.
