Dead by Daylight is a pulse-pounding asymmetrical horror game that pits a team of survivors against a relentless killer in a deadly game of cat and mouse. Developed by Behaviour Interactive, this multiplayer gem offers an adrenaline-fueled experience like no other.

Gameplay:
The core gameplay loop of Dead by Daylight is both simple and addictive. As a survivor, you must work together with your teammates to repair generators scattered across the map, all while evading the killer's pursuit. Each survivor has unique abilities and perks, adding depth to the cooperative experience.

On the flip side, playing as the killer offers a completely different perspective. With a variety of terrifying killers to choose from, each with their own distinct playstyle and abilities, hunting down the survivors is an intense and satisfying experience. Whether you prefer the stealthy approach of the Trapper or the brutal force of the Hillbilly, there's a killer to suit every playstyle.

Atmosphere:
Dead by Daylight excels in creating a tense and atmospheric environment that keeps players on the edge of their seats. From the eerie sound design to the chilling visuals, every aspect of the game contributes to its spine-tingling atmosphere. The asymmetrical nature of the gameplay further enhances the tension, as both survivors and killers must rely on their wits to outsmart their opponents.

Progression:
The game offers a robust progression system that rewards players with new perks, items, and customization options as they level up their characters. Whether you're unlocking powerful survivor perks or gruesome new cosmetics for your favorite killer, there's always something to strive for in Dead by Daylight.

Community:
One of the game's greatest strengths is its passionate and dedicated community. With a thriving player base and active developer support, Dead by Daylight offers endless opportunities for collaboration and competition. Whether you're teaming up with friends for a late-night gaming session or facing off against strangers in a heart-pounding showdown, the community aspect of Dead by Daylight adds an extra layer of excitement to the experience.

Overall, Dead by Daylight is a must-play title for fans of asymmetrical multiplayer games and horror enthusiasts alike. With its gripping gameplay, spine-tingling atmosphere, and thriving community, it's no wonder that Dead by Daylight continues to captivate players around the world. So grab your flashlight, sharpen your machete, and prepare to dive into the heart-pounding world of Dead by Daylight.

I've played many hours now, and while I have fun with friends, I have had increasingly less fun the longer I've played. Currently, the community is filled with mostly those who have been playing the game for awhile. They know how to abuse the in-game mechanics and stride the delicate line between reportable and non-reportable behavior. The developers behind this game have made it continuously clear that in-game behaviour - targeting players in a single match, moves/movements that do not require skill and make the game less playable for the other side, and/or actions that down right stop the other side from being able to play - are not bannable as they would be in other games. Behaviour that would be considered inappropriate and mechanics that would be overpowered are allowed to persist. The game is most fun in customs, and with friends; is less fun in solo q, and people who main killers consider the game a way to have a personal power trip, which is very concerning. When purchasing be prudent and be aware this game is very hard on mental health.

So, I got into this game about two years ago, thanks to my friends who insisted it was THE GAME. I got hooked, but let me tell you, playing solo is extremely depressing.

For a whole year, I was a killer main as if it were a job, but then it hit me: Why am I playing this? So, I took a break, rediscovered my love during Halloween, and rejoined the creepy fun.

Back then, I collected every killer during those sales, and here's the big revelation: don't overdo it on the killer side. The real charm is being the survivor, especially with friends. It's like you're in a horror movie, but you get to laugh at your friends' screams.

I switched to Steam because Epic Games felt like endless gaming, and now I'm back in the game with my buddies. Playing with friends turns this game from depressing to fun.

My advice: Dead by Daylight ‚Äì is not perfect, but it's still pretty awesome. Play with friends for the best time, go solo for a challenge, and maybe be the killer once in a while. Despite the killer burnout, I'm giving this game a solid 7/10 ‚Äì sanity is overrated anyway. Happy surviving, folks!

I don't feel much scared when I watch this game on YouTube until I buy it and immerse in it with a full sense of the environment and sounds. The match is just around 10 minutes, does not take very much time, and I don't have to be eager to win like many other games. This game is about scaring people or being scared, not about winning.

As a newbie, I see quite many information about the game, and it a little gives me a headache. But after experiencing a few matches, it is not as complicated as I think. The game also has a tutorial mode, quite helpful. But I think the 'Game Manual' should be posted on the official website where I can 'Alt+Tab' to read while reading Power, Perk, Add-on, Offerings, etc. I also try reaching devs for feedback, and they reply to me quicker, more clearly, and more politely than expected (they do not ignore me as many comments I have read online about BHVR devs).

Truly, l don't have many times to play, but I enjoy this game, and I do not regret buying it. If you're considering, just buy it, it is really fun!

**300 Hours Well Spent**

Review:
Dead by Daylight is a game that's hard to define. My first encounter was tough, but something kept pulling me back. After about 10 hours of gameplay, I fell in love with it. The game thrives on tension and unpredictability, especially at lower ranks. But as you climb the ranks, the gameplay evolves into a test of skill and strategy. The higher the rank, the better the experience.

Now, after 300 hours, I'm hooked. Dead by Daylight is a journey of perseverance and triumph. If you're up for a challenge, I highly recommend it. It only gets better the more you play.

This game isn't for everyone.
It has a high price of admission if you want to experience all the content it has to offer, and also there are lots and lots of mechanics that have been implemented over time that aren't explained all that well to new players.
I'd seriously recommend learning a fair amount about how the game works before trying to play it, as it'll make your new player experience much smoother.
My main draw to this game for the 3ish years I vaguely knew about it before buying, was that it seemed like it was an adrenaline-pumping game, and that the primary source of enjoyment came from making exciting and daring plays, not necessarily winning.
I don't expect to win every game, but I do my best to use all that I've learned to do well, and that's what I think a lot of people should try to do if they want to get the most enjoyment possible.
Play to play well. Winning is just a side objective that can come from doing things well.
Everyone enters a trial ready to see if they're better, but even if they're not, everyone leaves with the points they can use for spending on characters which they can use again.

are 9k shards in ingame shop, which is around 80 hours of playtime to afford 1, there are 34 killers whom 13 are licenced, so you need 144k shards just to get all original killers (5 of them are granted for free), 40 survivors whom 15 are licenced, so u need 171k shards to unlock all survivors, (6 of them are granted for free), so if we imply that getting one killer/survivor takes around 80 small, because, 34 killers, mean 102 killer perks, and 40 survivors mean 120 survivor perks, not considering universal perks because they can't appear in the shrine, shrine has 4 slots, two of them for killer perks and 2 of them for survivor perks, shrine cycles every week on wednesday, so the specific perk you want has less than 1% chance of appearing in shrine, and it cycles once every week, lets say that after a cycle appear new perks in the shrine, lets say the perks that appeared can't appear again untill all perks were shown, then cycle restarts, you still need 51 weeks just to see chace, you won't see a specific perk ever, shrine needs a rework, prices of free ingame characters have to be lowered, and either original characters need better perks or licenced ones have to be nerfed, sou you are not forced to buy licenced characters just to be able to compete and win matches, don't waste time or money, this game is not worth it

This game is fun. I've played it often. I almost always leave off on a bad note though. As an asymmetrical 1v4 horror game balancing it is obviously going to be a challenge, however, it is possible if you listen to your player-base. Too often I see people asking in earnest for changes to be implemented. I've seen many phases of this game. Old dead hard, Old Boon: CoH, old ranking system, old prestige. My main issue with these things isn't that they were "fixed" its that the company behind this game took YEARS to do so. For example Billy finally got his stupid overheat "fixed" after 4 YEARS of him getting shunned and nerfed. 

I dont agree with the way this game does DLC related Microtransactions. Too reminiscent of EA and their Locking Characters behind paywalls. 

The game is repetitive. There are plenty of glitches and bugs that still are and may never be fixed.

It's new matchmaking is horrible for new players and players who just play for fun. Pubs and comp/ranked play should always be separated.

Its not innovative. Recent DLC has just been shoving licenses in your mouth. Licenses you CANT GET unless you pay real money for auric cells or buy it outright through steam, epic, ps store, xbox store, nintendo store. 

I think this game is a great example for a game premise that was excellent but a terrible execution of said premise.

This isn't worth your time- trust me. There's so many other fun games to play with friends instead of this.

BEFORE YOU GET THE GAME!!!
The game seems like a good horror game, and it is for the first few hours, but that wears off eventually and it quickly becomes a competitive 4v1 asymmetrical game. I recommend checking out some of Otzdarva's videos to see what the game truly is. There is a huge learning curve (At least for some characters) and might require thousands of hours on this game to be "Good". For game play, you may or may not like it. 
There is the survivor side: repairing generators, distracting the killer, healing teammates, and trying to escape.
The killer side: Knocking down survivors, sacrificing the survivors to the entity, and slowing down the survivors as much as possible. 
The game will feel very unfair at time; there will be perks and addons from either side that seem to turn any situation to their favor and make you feel like you should have won. 
The community is also very toxic at times, and it can feel very discouraging to keep playing. But just remember, its a game, and I'm supposed to have fun. Ignore the endgame chat, don't go to the exit gates if the survivors opened it to watch them teabag you, and if you come across a group of survivors abusing game mechanics to give you a hard time (Bully Squads), there's no shame in disconnecting. If the game is irritating you, then just get off of it and get some fresh air, play a different game, or do something productive. 
So if your looking for a competitive 4v1, this is the game for you.

One of, if not my most favorite game / pass time. I really think this game is something unique and special, not only to me, but to many others as well. Ive been playing (on and off) since around 2019, so I've thankfully have been able to witness the games progress with its ups and downs. 

The game itself is different in a good way. I really don't get bored playing dbd, as there is alot of ways you can mix your perks as the survivor or the killer, to keep the matches enjoyable and not so repetitive. Its good that the play style from survivor to killer is so different. My heart is either racing trying to live and rescue fellow survivors, or when I'm trying to kill everyone. Either way it gets my anxiety up and my heart pumping - and I love every second of it. 

One of the good things about this game is that I don't really see that many cheaters in the game. I'm not sure if this is because of easy-anticheat, or because people don't feel the need to cheat. I have seen footage of cheaters and such, but I personally never went up against one. There are problems with the game though. The biggest problem I have (not sure how fixable this is) is the random server disconnection. Not just one person leaving, or the killer leaving, but a trigger that makes all survivors and the killer dc. The reason this sucks more then the killer dcing intentionally, is because you get no BP, and no progression on your player level. You spend upwards of 30 minutes on a match and all for nothing. It is really infuriating. The balancing of the survivors and killers and their perks are always a problem. It seems that when a new survivor or killer comes out, its somewhat either too powerful, or way too underpowerd. They are quick to change these problems, but its nice to have them already finished (or atleast usable) when they come out. Obviously like most games there are meta loadouts for survivors and killers. I really don't count this as a problem. I don't typically use the meta perks, and I usually get 3-4 kills every match as the killer (with Trapper and Doctor), and escape as survivor. So don't feel obligated or forced to use the meta perks, they ARE helpful, but do what you feel is most comfortable. 

Anyways, I love this game and its community. Its not perfect, but it is damn fun. 9/10.

Edit: New Lights Out (2024 for people in the future who might read this) mode is pretty neat. From my short experience so far, I have mixed feelings about it. It's pretty fun and a breath of fresh air from the base game. The new mode feels more 'casual' then the base game, as that feels much more competitive. A few problems I do have with the mode are as follows. 

1) I play killer and survivor 50/50 when it comes to the base-game. I have a lot of fun with both sides. That is not the case with lights out I'm afraid. I find myself playing killer much much much more then survivor for numerous reasons. I tried to play some survivor in LO but after the first few matches, once the thrill of being jump-scared wore off, it was really bare-bones and not very fun. With some killers (Ill get to that in my second point), its borderline impossible to win or at the very least have fun. There isn't much the developers can do to rework this mode, because at that point you would have an entirely new game mode. Some things I do suggest are making the generators louder for survivors and killers, not necessarily having any progression on them though, and making them have no auras for the killers, that way both have to use their ears in order to find the generators to either repair or damage. Maybe as the killer is hauling a downed survivor, they could brefiley see the auras of the nearest generators. 

2) As to what I said about borderline impossible matches, Myers, Ghostface, and Dredge. I LOVE Myers basegame and in LO, but these two modes are vastly different. In one of them, Myers at level 2 and 3 has a terror radius, visible red stain, and is visible (not pitch dark like in LO). In the other, Myers at level 2 and 3 has no terror radius (all killers have no terror radius in LO), a barely visible red stain, and isn't visible at all (its pitch black in LO.) The biggest problem with this in LO is obviously the level 3 Myers insta down. Atleast in base-game, you could see Myers approaching you to stalk you in level 2, AND hear his terror radius in level 3 for a chance of avoiding a insta-down. In LO, once Myers has almost leveld up to level 3 with his stalk, and finds you (when he stalks you, you can see the survivors auras much easier, and the survivors might not even know you're there), he can go to level 3 and then insta-down you without any warning. It feels the same way with Ghostface. And this isn't me being biased at all, like I said before, I am a huge Myers and Ghostface fan, but I can tell when something is overlooked like this. As for Dredge, what is his power really useful for? Making the game even darker? I say either rework these 3 just for LO, or remove them for LO in this game mode. 

3) This isn't really a criticism, but, man, if they added proximity chat to this mode, that would be HILARIOUS! Just imagine you have a voicechat range of 8-12 meters and can talk to your fellow survivors or to the killer. If the killer could also talk to the survivors, that would just be fantastic.

Anyways, Lights Out is pretty fun and entertaining for the time being. I hope they fix the the issues and balance out the killers for this game-mode before perm. releasing it. I give this game-mode a 6.5/10.

[h1]GAME PLAY[/h1]
The basic concept is not new, a couple of humans try to survive against a beefed up super killer.
There is a large selection of maps, survivors, killers, perks, tools and add-on's to aid both the killers and survivors in their respective roles. If starting new it can be confusing or daunting, but if you intend on playing for fun you don't need to worry, just work out what you like. While the more competitive side of the game has a rather strict requirement for success in terms of strategies and builds.


[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The game has been around a while now, it looks old but it looks good. The developers have got it how they want you to play it and there is very limited options to change how the game looks. Its designed to be dark and spooky with a couple of tweaks available to aid sharper lines or better performance.

[h1]BALANCE[/h1]
The games balance is lacking. Depending how good your MMR is you will be in 1 of 2 positions.
1. Low MMR requires friends and team work to win, the killer is coming at you hard and fast and you don't know what to do about it.
2. High MMR has survivors who know what they're doing and if the killer isn't prepared with a set strategy and build they're going to have to work really hard to even stand a chance at winning.

[h1]COMMUNITY[/h1]
Its an online game. Expect toxicity, expect it thick and fast from all directions on both teams. But its not the worst community I've seen. We all complain a lot about the other team and how unfair it is that they've got it so easy.

The game is falling apart due to this meta and the developers do nothing because the majority of players fall into the camp that benefits from this. If you watched a cool video and think that you can replicate that, you are painfully ignorant. The genrush meta can only be countered with thousands of hours of experience. DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME unless you are willing to commit your entire life to it.

I feel obligated to change my review; I'd played this back in 2017 when the game had very serious issues with how the game was handled overall. Getting into a match was slow, the game was very clunky and hard to deal with.
However; now, years later; they've not only released plenty of quality DLC, they've also fixed the issues with matchmaking and progression. I still see people having issues with unjustified bans now and again; and the game sometimes boots from lobbies for no apparent reason. [strike]Dead by Daylight? How about Dead by the time my group of friends gets into a game that isn't a private match. The gameplay is pretty solid, it's actually really fun; the concept is great too. love-hate relationship is the perfect way to describe this game.

music, good. graphics, good. concept? super fun! controls arent bad. but the gameplay. the community. oh my god. its so easy to burn out with dead by daylight. from teammates in soloq not being helpful, teaming with killers, killers tunneling noobs, teammates literally just giving up when something goes slightly wrong. seriously if youre a new player prepare to get tilted if you arent playing with three other friends on voice call. sometimes people are nice and fun, and those moments make me feel really good about the game, its what keeps me coming back. but thats only maybe 2-3/10 rounds. survivor is always either way too easy or way too hard due to killer cheesing, same with killer gameplay- either way too easy or absolutely stupid due to surv cheesing. at some point things start to feel kinda mundane. the recent lights out mode is fun and interesting, but its *so* unfortunate they made this community voted game mode last for just a few days.
being competitive and stuff in dbd is fun but its easy to become discouraged by factors listed above.

anyways, get it to play with friends, maybe dont get too invested if you want to stay sane. be prepared to go through an emotional roller coaster of decisive wins and completely unfair losses. DONT BUY THIS GAME TO PLAY ON YOUR OWN!!! playing as a solo survivor is painful, there is *SOMEHOW* no voice chat! pain!

(my credentials- i play both killer and survivor, almost 500 hours at the time of writing. maybe that isnt enough but its more than i have in many other games. ive played just about as much solo q as survive with friends. also have a good variety of characters in both categories... pls see my opinion as valid :,)

So. You're here. The algorithm figured you like horror games, or maybe your friends play this game and you want to play with them, or you're looking just out of morbid curiosity. I don't know you, but let me welcome you to this magical realm of fog and crows and axe-murderers chasing horny teens - and lots of diesel generators lying around for some reason. God that's a lot of diesel generators.

Y'know the last 20 minutes of a horror movie, where everyone's running and screaming and bleeding? This is it. Why are you here? Doesn't matter. No really: The game is 7 years old and had no lore until 5 minutes ago. What is your motivation? Shallow: Survivors try to survive and Killers try to kill. How does it work? Repairing generators powers the exit gates so Survivors can escape. Putting an axe in the Survivors heads prevents them from escaping. Simple as. Imagine the edgiest game of hide-and-seek ever devised. That's it. That's the game, and it's terribly great fun. I know dudes with thousands of hours. Low complexity, high depth, like chess, in a game of 1 queen vs 4 pawns, and the pieces scream when you stab them.

Sure it's got some baggage that modern games lug around: Cosmetics, progression, unlocks, DLC, premium currency, challenges, season ratings. Some of that's alright, some of it's exploitative, and some of it I think would be great if I was allowed to overhaul it, but it is what it is. You either accept it or you don't. At least it doesn't have those apparently mandatory fishing and farming mini-games. Not yet anyway.

To prevent sticker shock, I recommend you grab the base game when it's on sale; I grabbed mine in August for $8, which gave me a couple months to see if I liked it before the annual Halloween Sale where basically everything is like +90% off. The base game starts you off with 7 Survivors and 5 Killers; that's enough to get you started and see if you want to stick with it. For all this crass monetization it is not pay to win. No amount of DLC will make up for skill. You git gud or you get hung on a meathook. 

Will you like this game? If you can stomach the gore, you probably will; it's got great staying power as multiplayer games go, with devs constantly working on balance issues, new characters and thus new skills, and new in-game events every month or so. However you gotta go in knowing this is a real skill-based PvP game and as such there's a steep learning curve. There is an invisible rating system called MMR so absolute noobs don't get roflstomped by grizzled veterans, but it can only do so much for you. Its best if you start playing with a veteran to show you the ropes!

Fair warning: Some players are toxic. It is a competitive multiplayer esport. Just rise above it; at least their harassment is limited to crude body-language in-game and mean-spirited post-game text chat (which you do not have to sit through). Survivors do not like being murdered (I know right?) and some get salty about it, making up for their inability to be aggressive in-game with aggression afterward. There's an elaborate system of do's-and-don'ts some players made up, using terminology like "tunnelling" and "three-gen" and "Tombstone Meyers," that boils down to "if I lose it's because you're a horrible person so I'm allowed to be nasty." Pay it no mind. Keep calm and murder them. Again. And again.

11/10
Edit: Well 4k hours later and I still play this game.

I still think its really fun but not as fun as it once was and I wish more people would find common ground between having fun and sweating to win, its not very fun to have survivors bully the killer constantly and its not very fun to have the killer tunnel out survivors to secure a win. 

I think the newest events and the new game mode are a huge step in the right direction in making this game a really fun experience.

i worry for the new players though because with the massive amount of money they would need to spend to get every killer and survivor plus the sheer amount of game knowledge they would need to learn is insane. 

The best advice I can give new players is:

-Watch content creators like Otzdarva or hens333 who have a big catalogs of videos that teach basic and advanced steps to learn the game.

-Play the game for a long time to really learn the layouts of maps, killer powers, perks, items, and techs. 

-Don't give up if you have a bad game just use that game as a learning experience to apply to the next game.

-Play both side evenly because you learn to play the other side better by mimicking what they do to you.

-If you find you are getting tilted playing the game take a break. DBD isn't going anywhere.

In conclusion this game is ever changing and will hopefully continue to change for the better.

Once upon a moonlit night, in the shadowy depths of the forest, there existed a sinister realm known as "Dead by Daylight." Within this cursed domain, mortals dared to tread, unaware of the horrors that lurked beneath the veil of darkness.

In this twisted fairy tale, players are thrust into a macabre game of cat and mouse, where the roles of hunter and prey blur into a nightmarish dance of survival. The hunters, embodiments of terror and despair, stalk the dimly lit landscapes with an insatiable hunger for blood. Each hunter possesses unique abilities, derived from the darkest recesses of folklore and myth, to ensnare and ensnarl their hapless victims.

Meanwhile, the survivors, lost souls trapped in this ghastly purgatory, must evade the clutches of their relentless pursuers. With trembling hearts and frayed nerves, they scurry through decrepit ruins and desolate cornfields, desperately seeking sanctuary amidst the encroaching shadows.

Yet, even in the face of overwhelming odds, hope flickers like a solitary candle in the night. Working together, survivors can outwit their oppressors, mending shattered generators to unlock their path to freedom. But beware, for every heartbeat echoes like a drumbeat of doom, drawing the attention of the lurking horrors that haunt this accursed realm.

In Dead by Daylight, the line between dream and nightmare blurs, and the boundaries of reality dissolve into the abyss. With its haunting atmosphere, chilling gameplay, and spine-tingling suspense, this dark fairy tale of survival and sacrifice will leave players breathless and trembling, long after the final chapter has been written. So tread carefully, dear traveler, for in the realm of Dead by Daylight, death is but the beginning of a new nightmare.

Honestly I really really enjoyed my first couple weeks playing this game and considered making it my main game, however there's a huge issue for me that's caused me to probably stop playing.

The skill based matchmaking in this game is taking all the fun out of the game for me, and I don't feel like its a game for me anymore. I have 200 hours in game and I'm *OK* at the game, but every single lobby I play in now is full of people with 3-4 thousand hours. This huge discrepancy in experience has made it so every game is a massive sweatfest, I run meta perks to try to keep up with the massive skill difference and it just isn't fun. I think it really sucks to say that I'm done with the game because I was having a ton of fun with it, but I think the way the devs have implemented MMR has ruined it for me. Don't play this game unless you're willing to spend thousands of hours just to keep up in public lobbies.

Started to play since release, mainly as a survivor but did some good number of killers games. Back then the game was a mess of course and you could wait for an hour to get to a lobby, though it was far more scary than now.

To this day, there has been numerous improvements to accesibility and gameplay, though it leaves the game to be a bit bland imo. 
I'm also sad to see that the mobile version of DBD is getting more love than the base game despite the community asking for new modes, and so on.

I still DBD, but I can't make long sessions because killers still have the ability to trap you inside a game or leave you defenseless.

In my opinion Behaviour is more dedicated to making money out of DLCs and cosmetics (only for some characters) or starting new DBD related projects like new games or even movies, than making DBD better and more appealing.

Still, DBD is realisticaly the best asymetrical game out there, and it can still be worth playing with friends or for short sessions. Beware the learning curve though, your first games will not be fun.

I hope Behaviour will wake and start making more content and less cosmetics.

A precariously enjoyable but overwhelmingly unrefined experience for those playing as the survivor role in particular. Depending on what happens this game can either be completely miserable and pointless or relatively engaging and entertaining in each given round. 

With few lasting competitors this game has a happenstantial monopoly on its genre, which is ultimately its main redeeming feature.



From the perspective of the survivor this game is fundamentally balanced around the player always being individually disadvantaged versus to the murderer, due to the survivors having an overarching numbers advantage. When facing the murderer in one versus one scenarios, which occur most of the time, a survivor is inherently doomed to eventually get caught unless the murderer is completely ineffectual. Many special abilities that murderers have can expedite the process of catching survivors even further. This is presumably meant to be balanced out by the fact that survivors can coordinate their actions to become stronger as a group, except the game doesn't give survivors a proper means of doing such beyond a superficial heads up display that leaves most important information unknown. Rendering the survivor role inherently ramshackle by how it demands yet inhibits thorough coordination in competitive play.

The threat avoidance system in this game is overall sloppy and awkward. Survivors may avoid being chased by keeping out of sight yet the murderer can randomly find survivors by accident while searching or travelling around. Players can use certain environmental fixtures to prolong a chase but many are finite, can only be found in specific places, require knowledge to use effectively and only a limited amount of them are even effective at all. Many potential chase techniques that a survivor has are dependent on the murderer's reaction to that technique, rendering the outcome even more out of the survivor's control. In the end avoiding the murderer in this game is often a matter of luck due to the numerous random factors at play which either advantage or disadvantage the survivor in each moment; all weighed against the type of murderer they are up against and how effective the opposing player is at using them.

Survivors have to memorize the exact mechanics of several dozen unique murderer gimmicks just to have any hope of functioning against them in a chase. Yet almost every murderer's gimmick is fundamentally unfair as they either have no meaningful counterplay, counterplay that entirely hinges on situational luck or the counterplay is only effective against inexperienced players. Numerous murderer gimmicks also require minimal effort to even use, the murderer getting full value out of their special ability by simply pressing one or two buttons to either debilitate or outright catch survivors. In all but the most advantageous environments the murderer's input overwhelmingly takes priority over the survivor's, rendering much of a survivor's knowledge and dexterity largely pointless in more competitive levels of play where murderer's seldom make mistakes. Even the server connection itself rules in favour of the murderer's input which seldom results in lag disadvantaging them when compared to the survivor's connection.

There are a multitude of ways that the murderer can make the game completely miserable for survivors if they want to, and many of these methods require no real effort or tact to perform despite how distinctly advantageous they are. The murderer can camp a hooked survivor to stop others from saving them without making a huge sacrifice, the murderer can purposely choose to protect a clustered group of generators that are disproportionately easy to patrol, the murderer can leave survivors to bleed out on the ground for minutes, the murderer can focus down a specific survivor to quickly eject them from the match. The developers have slowly added in various mechanics to combat this kind of behaviour yet many of these solutions are ineffectual and may even be circumvented. The only other safeguard that survivors have is to equip perks which exclusively exist to aid them against unfair scenarios. Perks which may never have a chance to activate over a dozen rounds of play, consume valuable space in the player's build that entire time and must be bought first before the player can even get access to them.

This game is loaded with numerous items and perks that are either nearly useless or extremely situational to the point of being nearly useless. Most survivor perks are completely ineffectual outside of very random and uncommon situations, discouraging the player from choosing most perks in the entire game due to the low likelihood of them yielding results. Over the past several years the survivor role has only gotten two competitively strong new perks and both of them were eventually nerfed, yet the murderer role often receives decent perks with each new content release. There are only a handful of remotely strong survivor perks out of more than a hundred options by this point and all the while murderers enjoy a variety of oppressive and unpredictable build combinations.

In that same vein over the past several years the survivor role has only received a limited number of buffs, many of which exclusively served to discourage unfair elements of the game that the murderer could purposely benefit from; and as mentioned these changes do not actually even fix the problem they simply reduce it at best. Meanwhile when the murderer role is given buffs they are often fundamental improvements that just outright make the role more threatening; such as increasing the speed on all their generic actions, increasing their field of view or reducing the effectiveness of a common survivor item.

By comparison the murderer role enjoys a much more consistent and interactive gameplay experience only perturbed by more exceptional situations; although even it is mired by scattered balancing issues such as overly disadvantageous pieces of terrain, survivor teams coordinating with third-party software and maps which are disadvantageous to certain murderer gimmicks. Furthermore beyond that there are various overarching problems that impact both roles as well.

Outside of minimalistic holiday events, sparse balance changes and belated glitch patches virtually all of the content this game receives now is heavily monetized and seldom innovative. The game almost never receiving any significant new features. Presumably because the code is so antiquated that adding new features would take inordinate amounts of effort. Or the developers are too lazy to even bother. Each update introduces a new array of ridiculous glitches which further allude to either the instability of its code or the developer's incompetence, resulting in a perpetual cycle of broken gameplay elements which randomly softlock players and force entire pieces of content to be temporarily disabled. One character was disabled for an entire month recently.


From the perspective of a survivor this game can be enjoyable, enough so that it often serves as a reasonable diversion, however this massively depends on a wide variety of factors which after nearly a decade should really be resolved by now. Between the endless glitches, awful perk balancing, clearly slanted role balancing, uncoordinated yet team-centric gameplay and the abundance of ways in which the murderer can make survivors miserable this game is atrocious from a critical standpoint; its random glorification of murder and schadenfreude being particularly repugnant. 

Yet if players want a chase-driven gameplay experience that actually has a decent amount of players and support there are few other options beyond this game; which is ultimately its main redeeming facet.

Edit: 2/5/24 - TL;DR - Just don't start playing this game. If there's anymore hours than when this is posted, it's due to me coming back for my friends. Don't ever get into it. Just don't. For the love of God, don't. lol

As much as I love to play this game, I had to uninstall. I'm not coming back.

For the record, I was a Survivor Main.
We all know this is a 1v4 game. The issue? Too many toxic killers that I've come across that don't play fair for me to enjoy it. That's my main issue. I get it though, survivors are and can be just as bad.

The second bone to pick I've got is the double standard.
Prime Example: Survivors have a perk called "Made For This" that allowed you to run 3% faster while injured. They changed that to 3% in a Deep Wound state. In one of my matches, I came across a Trapper that had nothing but 5% haste perks. I could NOT run the killer no matter how hard I tried.

The third issue that I've had with this game is literally getting stuck on NOTHING. A part of a hill and getting stuck on it. Getting stuck on a wall. Stuck on a corner of something.. Etc.

4. The block button should be considered to take people that don't play fair (i.e. Slugging, Camping, Tunneling (and it's been nothing but the entire match)) out of YOUR matchmaking. Much like for example you can't see someone you blocked in a game due to harassment. That's not the case in this game. It just blocks communication. So no matter what, you could be stuck with the same killer 3 times in a row if you're that unlucky. 

5. This game is constantly.. and I mean CONSTANTLY precariously balanced imho. BHVR devs don't even play their own game to know what they're doing. This game makes people angry. It makes ME angry. They allow atrocious behavior to persist despite all the complaints. They FINALLY implemented a camp meter (can't remember when) so you can get off of the hook but that doesn't do jack considering they can STILL camp out of range and come back to the hook to tunnel you out.

Lastly, as much as this can be fun and everyone's being fair (and you're playing with friends).. I have encountered those who'd rather ruin your day moreso in the last 3 years than when I first played this in 2018. I still miss the match I had with a Wraith that knew what he was doing. He scared the daylights out of me lol. He played with all of us like we were his food.

I don't want to be angry anymore when it comes to this game. It's tiresome trying to find a good match that's fun on a game that ruins itself every time they release a Killer. I don't blame it, I blame the people operating it.

It's really hard to love this game.

The more you try to leave it be, the harder it is. It's an amazing museum of horror classics but the execution is just awful. I've been a passionate player for over 3 years now and the more I play, the more it feels like I'm an addict looking for his midnight fix.

Don't get me wrong: the game is gorgeous but the community is just a clusterfu—Åk. There's no way you can get enjoyment or fun at high ranks since even most of the high ranking players promote the boring ways of playing such as tunneling or BuckleUp+ForThePeople.

Bullying. The game feels like a safe haven for bullies and bullied people: the only other game I know where a similar keyboard courage can be observed is Dota 2 and you know the Dota community. It's just baffling how people on the other end of the screen make their top priority to ruin someone else's day. The worst of all is that this kind of behavior is being installed to new players which means that hate grows from the very start.

Overall, I'm really heartbroken that this great idea of a game is floating purely because of the company's licensing abilities that brings new players in just to smack them with a load of crap as soon as they start getting into it.

[h2]Core issue[/h2]
The main problem with this game is the fact that developers refuse to change the core mechanics. They merely attempt to patch problems (they've done this for years) and release new cosmetics/killers/survivors/bugs/crashes. 

[h2]Gameplay Issues...[/h2]
Although they do target problems with the core gameplay such as 3gening, camping and tunneling, all of these are still [b]very[/b] present in the game. If anything they've made it even better to tunnel by adding and buffing slowdown perks that make it easy to win a 3v1 (especially on stronger killers). Fundamentally, the only way a killer can win is by either snowballing (downing survivors fast enough), playing dirty (camping/tunneling/etc) or by bringing plenty of slowdown perks. A combination of the last two are by far the most common; especially at higher MMR, and/or weaker killers. 

[h2]RNG[/h2]
While this game isn't riddled with RNG, some are really frustrating; sometimes survivors end up with most generators in really save areas, or in complete dead zones. There's also stupid RNG, such as gens blowing up (and losing progress) when a survivor leaves it (7% chance or w/e).

[h2]Survivor Solo Queue...[/h2]
Most of the games in solo queue are terrible, with survivors suiciding early, making stupid mistakes (letting the killer snowball), etc. The difference between solo queue and a SWF (survive with friends) is huge. I'd suggest playing with others, otherwise this will likely drive you nuts (at least if you want to win, and not just goof around like some content creators such as JRM). 

[h2]Bugs...[/h2]
With each patch we see game servers crashing, clients crashing, and other interesting bugs (killers getting stuck, killers power bugging out, perks not working, survivors/killers able to enter unreachable locations, etc). Some of these bugs have been in the game for long, and end up being dubbed "techs", such as window techs, slide techs, etc. Often a patch arrives, and on the same day, or the day after some content is blocked cause of a bug. 

[h2]Developers...[/h2]
The developers don't really listen to advice, and mostly follow their own studies (which is frustrating; see rants from content creators for this game, e.g. Otzdarva). E.g. they still haven't done anything about nurse (who ignores every chase mechanic in the game), even though there are players with thousands of wins in a row on that killer. 

[h2]High MMR...[/h2]
First of all, there isn't really a "high MMR" in this game, since you reach the MMR cap fairly quickly. 
Gameplay on higher MMR is mostly just an armsrace of perks/items/addons. A game can be over in 2-3 minutes if survivors bring the strongest stuff, and similarly if the killers bring the strongest stuff. Which is why these are banned in tournaments (see DBDLeague).

[h2]Balance...[/h2]
The balance in this game is quite horrible, some killers are completely busted, such as nurse, spirit and blight. When you end up against a really good killer playing one of these, you'll know. Unless you're in a SWF that's prepared for it, you'll almost always lose. Then there's killers like Freddy and Trapper who can lose even if they outplay the survivors. There's also a world of difference between the strongest and weakest addons/perks. There's perks that basically don't do anything useful, and those that are busted. As a killer you'll likely end up hating second chance perks, such as adrenaline, unbreakable, for the people, buckle up, dead hard, decisive strike etc. As a survivor you'll end up hating certain playstyles, such as 3gening, camping & tunneling, along with slowdown perks. Especially those that completely block you from progressing.

[h2]Slow Progression...[/h2]
Unless you plan on spending thousands of hours on this game (like me) expect to spend 100+ EUR on DLCs for the game, and even then you still need hundreds of hours to unlock the content you bought (which is kinda mindblowing). There's plenty of content creators talking about this issue, just search on youtube. 

[h2]Learning Curve...[/h2]
Further, expect to spend hundreds, if not thousands of hours in the game before you learn killers mechanics, maps, perks, addons, etc. There's hundreds of perks, 35 killers, each with 15-20 addons, 22 maps each with multiple different layouts, etc. Expect to be a beginner until you have upwards of 1k hours in the game.

[h2]TLDR;[/h2]
Play at your own risk; it's really an addictive, expensive (money & time) and abusive relationship that you're entering.

Dead by Daylight is the epitome of chaos and survival, just like dealing with the IT department terror on a monday morning : you'll never know if you'll make it out alive. 

In this game, stealth is key ! The heart-pounding stealth required from survivors mirrors the art of slipping through the cracks, a skill Roy and I hone when avoiding office gatherings. Well, actually we don't really need to avoid those as we are usually not invited to said gatherings. 

Playing a killer can also be fun and relatable as you feel like turning into one every time Daniel from the 7th floor makes fun of your glasses... PLOPPER !

Anyway. What is actually more relatable is playing a survivor because, let's be honest, we all feel like survivors in the office sometimes...

In conclusion Dead by Daylight is a great game. It might not be flawless, but then again, neither is troubleshooting a legacy system. I'd give it a solid 4 out of 5 IT tickets.

Sincerely yours,

Maurice Moss (The Gardner)

Im gonna be honest. This game is good until you figure out you need to have dlc to want to play this game and have "fun". No game should do this but it's addicting. Yet BHVR doesn't want to fix basic things in the game that the community has problems with until they start getting hate. They cant even make their updates better. Take the "Anti Camp Update" for example. It doesn't work as well as you think they just go a little farther and boom, no anti camp progression. A billion dollar corporation doesn't have people play test their own game.
Thus leads to horrible imbalance between both sides. Now lets go back to the dlc part, paying to win is a thing but it's usually looked down upon. Not in this game because you HAVE TO BUY THE DLC TO HAVE FUN IN THE GAME. Fun should be accessible at all times not locked behind a digital pay wall. Yet i still bought all dlc for this game. Spending $200 on them for digital fun. For that money I could take my friend (imaginary) on a concert, or go ahead and have dinner with them or something. What im trying to say is the developers don't know what they're doing and or don't play test their own game, and the horrible imbalance due to you having to buy dlc to get the perks that come along with the dlc, but certain perks are out right meta locked behind digital pay walls forcing you to buy them to be in check with the killer. Not only does it rake in money for the devs but they wont fix it for the last reason I just said.
Yet I still play the game regularly because I did buy all dlc and was happy with it until I came to the conclusion that im making this review. This game was a lot more entertaining in the first 15 or so game you played.

Summary:

Game is like hide and go seek and/or blind man's bluff, but it gets repetitive as there's only one gameplay mode: 

- fix the total amount of generators before the killer kills everyone or escape by hatch or exit 
  gate as the lone survivor.

Pros:

- Constant and different challenges/quests to complete 
- Multiple Characters to choose from
- There's Lore/Stories about the characters you play
- Free Cosmetics and 10$ Premium Rifts
- Quality of Life Updates: Bloodweb instant selection and Increase Blood Point Bonuses

Cons: 

- Online Multiplayer Only (Internet required)

- Unexpected Gameplay.  Pallet Saves are broken and instead of saving the survivor on the 
  shoulder of the killer, the killer is unaffected.  The pallet save turns into a free off the 
  shoulder for the survivor who tried to do the pallet save?  Take this as a grain of salt, but 
  apparently "The Entity" may have played a part in this.  But, this sounds more like an excuse 
  for bad gameplay design.

- Crossplay games, most survivor/killer players disconnect and are penalized for 
  disconnecting. Instead of penalizing players they should be innovating ways 
  to keep players in the game

- No Ultra Widescreen support

- Inventory/Perks Menu needs better filters.  They're only ordered alphabetically, recognition 
  by pictures and can be only searched by inputting texts for a search filter (if you know what you're looking 
  for)

- Sync issues with Killer/Survivor (ie, Pallet Stuns but the Survivor still gets hit or Vaulting and 
  still getting hit)

- Unstable Servers caused by Owner/Admin leads to disconnects and extended wait time no matter the 
  reason.  The only resolution is to restart the game and inability to rejoin and continue the session

I really loved this game, but I grew tired of the limiting killer trend. Remove this, can't do that or you'll get punished, you can only do this 8 times. What's next, Trapper and Pig get a overheat mechanic? In what world is it fun where one role gets these unnecessary restrictions and limitation while the other is free as a bird? Imagine a mechanic for survivors that if they gen rush, the entity blocks the hooked survivor for a limited time for prioritizing gens over their team. That'll be a stupid mechanic and unfun for the survivors and their anger would be in the right. So why do it to killers? Their reasonings always prove the opposite of what they try to do. Until they remove the 3 gen "solution" and start focusing on the real issue, (map design) I'm not sure if I want to reinstall the game.

This is a strategy game, not a horror game. Though the devs only partially realize that. If you go watch DbD youtube videos or twitch streams you won't see people with face cams screaming, instead they're using counterstrike style call outs and doing cost-benefit analysis on every action they do in the game.

DbD is full of grinding, and that kills horror games. When you've done something a hundred times and memorized all the stats it stops being scary. DbD has so much grinding and so many microtransactions that it's basically a free mobile game except it costs $20. With all of the licensed dlc in the game it's basically fortnite and the devs have given more attention to cosmetics than actual gameplay.

I have no idea how looping has stayed in the game this long but it seems the devs don't actually play the game anymore and just look at stats to make balance changes. Honestly I can't blame them for it. The community is toxic af and super competitive. There's no way to play the game casually besides invite-only private lobbies. Ranked mode is the only way to play and god help you if you play survivor alone. Surprisingly there's no voice chat in game for survs, not even text chat, just 2 emotes, that's it. Despite this playing with friends still gives you a massive advantage bc Discord calls exist letting survs coordinate extremely well.

Despite all this DbD is very addicting bc it drips feeds you just enough rewards and the gameplay has enough variety and depth to keep you coming back.

I have about 200 hours in this game, it's are really addicting and fun game (literally my hyperfixation), as of right now I'm a Dwight main as a survivor, and a Huntress main as a killer. The one thing that I'd really change about this game is adding more of a system to punish killers for tunneling/camping. The system now is great, but toxic killers are still able to find ways to get around the camping system to where fellow survivors aren't able to unhook a player without them getting killed as well. I would also love a little more customization for some of the characters that doesn't involve spending more shards (the free currency you can spend on characters). When you spend shards on characters they don't come with any other hairstyles or clothing options besides the one outfit, this was the case at least when I bought Yui, Jane, and Felix.
    The community is mostly very wholesome and silly, and I would say there are less toxic people than most games, but of course there's always going to be a portion of the community who are. There is also a large part of the community that are part of the lgbtqia+ community (we love the gays <3) and I haven't ran into any problems with homophobia so far in the game. 
TLDR: If you're looking into buying Dead by Daylight, I highly recommend it! Lots of laughs, a wholesome, fun, and accepting community, a little bit toxic but not as toxic as other games I've played.

at 1,200 hours the game becomes more toxic and the flaws become more and more hard to ignore. I only play because some friends have fun gaming together, but this game has no real fun left.   The game has no mechanic to penalize all the toxic behavior and it becomes tiresome to deal with non stop toxic B.S.    I don't say this ligtly, but the worst online community.  On top of that, a buggy game, a horrific grind system.  Fun can be found, but you have to enjoy being shit on most of the time to hope for that 1 or 2 fun games inbweeen tons of very unfun games. 


Now at almost 1,000 hours I would still say the game is still mostly fun, but still very much flawed.  It is fun to play with friends, but it is poorly balanced, has a surprising amount of bugs, toxic community and the to unlock all the perks, get ready to grind, grind grind.   I still keep this as a positive review, but honestly, its one more poor update from going to a negative review.

They buffed killers and nerfed survivors when the escape rate for survivors is already extremely low. Most survivor mechanics do not work properly and flashlight can be disabled with a perk, wiggling is still useless. 
People were asking to buff wiggling yet everything about killers were buffed. They don't nerf lightborn, a perk that cancels out a survivor item when survivors barely have items, but nerf survivor perks only because they are popular to use. What is the point as well when killers have OP aura perks, there is no point in hiding. Aura perks should not be in the game for either side, defeats the entire purpose of the game.

They aren't even fixing the survivor hit box which should be their number one priority, the hit box make most mechanics useless such as vaulting. I've been grabbed and hit whilst being on the other side of the vault. I average 30 ping as well so it is not my latency. In fact when I play killer, I can see these hits are just not fair. I keep getting hit so unfairly that I avoid most of the mechanics in this game because they simply don't work as intended. Also I've been grabbed from generators despite cancelling the action quick enough where I can walk, yet the game thinks I am  on the generator. This game is god awful.

After 5-6 long years of playing DBD on/off,  I really do love this game. From custom games with friends to playing online as killer/survivor, I've had my fair share of good times. The gameplay loop is shockingly addictive and the roster of characters is well fleshed out, from cool original creations like the embodiment of darkness itself The Dredge, to licenses like Chucky and Pyramid Head, each fleshed out well enough so that every killer feels fun to play with their own playstyle. With all these positives, I would love to recommend this game, but I can't inherently do that in the game's current state.

Dead by Daylight has one of the worst new player experiences I've ever experienced. It's irritating that if you want to start lasting more than 2 minutes online as you climb the ranks, you need to brush up on Killer and Survivor Perks, Addons, Items, Maps, Looping Strategies, etc. On top of that, a lot of the perks you can earn for free are arbitrary or passable at best. The issue there is that most of the perks that would WILDLY assist newer users are locked behind paid DLC, that could cost between $5-$20. Even then, it takes at least a little "grinding" after that, because perks start at level 1 and need to be leveled up to level 3 through the Bloodweb progression system, which could take a couple of games or days of on and off playing. All this culminates in a skill floor that is disastrously high, and if we're being honest, a lot of people don't have the free time to invest anywhere from 60-200 hours to learn the ins and outs of a video game. Trying to teach friends this game has been frustrating at best, because I see them die early and quickly and it sucks knowing that the only advice I could give is to cough up more money or watch Otz videos and commit to playing DBD often.

Along with all those issues, the player base can't be ignored. While I don't agree with the notion that it's one of the worst communities (In fact, plenty of small-big content creators are an incredibly positive force for good and have welcomed hundreds of kind people into the fanbase) it certainly isn't welcoming. For one, both sides have a set of made-up honor rules, molded around the idea of allowing people to have enough fun but not throwing away "winning" in the process. The issues arises in the fact that they are **made up** so there is never a surefire way to avoid being yelled at, because a survivor will complain that you targeted them too much one game while a killer will complain that you rushed the objective too fast the next, leading to a frustrating dynamic where someone is always mad. Additionally, it's very common to have players disconnect or intentionally die, as there are very surefire methods to do so due to certain game mechanics. The devs have added AI to replace players who disconnect, and while a nice band-aid, still doesn't address the issue at large, with a high amount of intentionally dying on hook, removing the option of getting a bot in place of the player. Not to mention all these make the already bad Solo queue experience worse, since there is no ping or comms system in DBD aside from 2 emotes, preventing solo survivors from communicating with their teammates in times of need.

Lastly (speaking of the developers) I can't ignore the stumbles from BHVR. To be optimistic, the balance/QoL changes have been increasing in quality lately, with accessibility changes and gameplay adjustments, but that comes with the a LARGE asterisk. Updates take a while, usually 3 months, and historically the devs are slower to pressing balance changes, leading perks or characters to potentially be downright busted for 3 months. Characters like The Blight or The Nurse have been S+ tier pretty much since they came out, with seemingly little to no acknowledgement from BHVR. Additionally, map design recently has been dodgy. Maps can be huge, with lots of physical clutter sneezed across the level, or long with countless hallways and doorways and small pallets, guaranteeing going down in certain areas in you're unlucky. As pessimistic as it is, BHVR seem to address these issues by slapping duct tape over the hole, while releasing yet another skin pack despite having the tools to permanently improve overall game quality for everyone. 

All of that said, I still do enjoy the game. If I could put a "mixed" instead of recommend/don't recommend I would, because DBD can be and still is fun, and I do think the game is worth giving a shot. If you don't mind investing in the learning curve I say go for it, as some of the stated issues become secondary to personal experience past the barrier to entry. Aside from that though, with pressing issues still needing solutions and a poor new player experience, DBD is a flawed game with a very fun game floating around somewhere inside it.

(560 hrs) Coming back to this review because I initially wrote it while I was ignorant to just how deep this game goes. Learning that has also allowed me to gleam what I think is the primary source of people's rage in dbd: failure to adapt. This is a game with an incredibly high skill ceiling, and many people simply hit a wall at some point and blame it on either toxic players or bad game design. The truth is that as long as you stay flexible and passionate about playing your respective role: you will prosper. For that reason I can't say I would recommend this game for a casual playing experience (unless you don't mind losing most of your matches). However I would 100% recommend it to anyone willing and wanting to devote themselves to a truly great asymmetrical-horror multiplayer experience.

It's a fun game, but the developers' philosophy easily ruins it, both in terms of how they view the game as casual and their lack of agency when it comes to fixes, bugs, and revamping parts of their outdated system.

They created a paradoxical game in which it is heavily bloated with skills, perks, and killer's convoluted kits make the game into a competitive nature. The developers update their game about as much and as often as minecraft does (with as much depth added, might I add), and since when this game came out it was kind of simple, now you need to know of about 70-100 perks for killers OR survivors (OR you need to know BOTH if you want to play with an advantage when it comes to outplaying and taking advantage of certain situations). and know 30ish killers' kits, which 1/3 to 1/2 are trapper level: Simple and can be explained, seen or played several times and you know everything there is to know of it (minus the best strategy). Some kits just outright write a novella that detail nothing well-defined like pinhead/cenobite.

Knight right now has been recently released from a 1.5 month killswitch in which there was a plethora of bugs, one of which  caused you to be able to spam his ability off CoolDown when vaulting windows. They fixed it and there still remains 6-8 other bugs for him that were there prior to the killswitch.

If you've been thinking about trying this game, please don't. I don't care if you saw they had Ash from Evil Dead, Leon and Jill from Resident Evil, Bill from Left 4 Dead, Freddy from Nightmare on Elm Street, none of that. That's how they draw you into a game that is incredibly toxic, painful, and downright abusive.

You will be beaten down both in-game and in the after-game chat no matter what you do. The game is unbalanced, perks range from literal dirt to meta/god-like, and without fail, at some point, you are going to be paired up against some sad, pathetic jerk who's only goal in life is to make your time in this game miserable no matter which side you play. You will constantly be called slurs, cursed at, told to off yourself, and worse. If you already don't have good mental health, STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME.

I'm too deep into it to stop, but trust me, you will be so much happier.

DBD has the worst game designers. The game is very unbalanced, either you get an easy-to-win game or an impossible-to-win game. And also the artwork is beyond a$$. DBD has the worst skins of games i've ever played. The AoT skins were really really bad

Unfortunately I can't find much fun in DBD nowadays I love all the new chapters and all the new maps and perks, but when I play survivor its just kinda dull and boring and killer is boring because if you don't run meta you've practically already lost. Not to mention I'm a high mmr player so I go against comp teams mostly. I really miss the casual side of DBD and it sucks I won't be able to re-live those days. I really don't suggest picking up this game. I would have maybe 3-4 years ago but nowadays the grind is to long the learning curves are insane and then once you even get halfway decent you will be getting meta cheesing lobby's  where there hard and annoying to win or a boring stupid disaster. If you truly enjoy the game still that's great you should be able to enjoy the game, but for me and mostly how a good chunk of players feel is boredom, and even if we get a new Asym it won't matter because players will find a way to break/meta cheese there way to victory instead of playing for fun. Which will in turn make said game lose players. VHS, Last Year, TCM, all have had these problems. Some die because they just don't get updates I'm aware of that but for the most part if players gave said games a chance we would still maybe just maybe have them still today. Not sure how long TCM still has, but hopefully we'll get a new asym that revolves around fun, intresting, and exciting gameplay instead of balance and perks and meta's.

"Asymmetrical games are an untapped source of online potential. Dead by Daylight is by a longshot the best of the genre to date, beating all past and current competition, namely in bang for your buck fun, core gameplay mechanics and continued support from the devs. The main complaints I and my friends who I play with are all about balancing, which is something that has been (in my opinion) tuned well enough to award players for skill without too many curtches (but I have to admit, the survivor team does have a fair share of crutches compared the the killers few). A great Horror Game experience for one team, and a great Killer experience for the other. Dead By Daylight has become my most played game and one that I continue to want to come back to after every session. Highly recommend, don't be deterred by reviews focused on balance issues. Core Game is solid and with seemingly dedicated developers, it will continue to be."

ive played this game for many years, started on my playstation but finally started getting locked in on pc. I cannot reccomend this game anymore, the state of the game is so tedious, the devs dont listen, they overbalance every "meta" perk that emerges to try and force a meta into this game, it doesnt work. ever. all perks are stale, overused, or nerfed into the ground until theyre quite literally a useless hindrance to whoever uses them. strange balancing to all items and even making gen time longer is insane, especially to expect a new player to understand. the learning curve is terrible now. theyre killing their own game by making it so stale, its just the same old junk every single game. the same handful of killers and perks, same old stale survivor perks, none of them matter anymore because all of them have been nerfed into the ground or had so much balancing they now have a paragraph to read on their description to even remotely understand how they work. killers can get away with everything, slugging and tunneling is the new meta. and bhvr rewards them for being unskilled. i couldnt tell you how many times ive been slugged and bled out while being "h*mped" because i looped the killer for a couple gens. there is nothing to combat this. i have experienced this more times than i can count on modern dbd. swfs ruin the killer experience and yet solo queue is literally unplayable without seasoned players in your lobby. if you are a new player reading this, please stop while you are ahead. i regret every penny i spent on this game.

This is more a neutral review more - neither great, neither bad kinda thing.

I had a lot of fun playing the game(both as the killer and the survivor).
I could go into details but I had two major issues with the game:
1. I got the infamous two killer bug/3 survivors (they should iron this out asap on the PC version);
2. If you get disconnected from the game you lose all blood-points from the match (almost every online game has a tracking system that allows you to keep the rewards of your progress even though you got disconnected - see WoT for example);
3. Waiting time for matches (the wait can go up to 20 mins).

While fun at times, there are serious issues with the game that will impact your experience. The execution is sloppy from here and there(collision detection/hitboxes). I get that it's going for the look and not for the functionality. And from an online game that is 6 years old by now, it's unacceptable. Fix your game, give your customers a good experience, and start ironing-out your bugs. I've been playing this game since 2019 (started on PS4) and sadly have to say, many things changed. Some for the good but mostly for the bad. It hurts me to write this, because i've loved this game with all my heart but i'd still like to give my honest opinion too.

Devs don't care - why? Things nobody was asking for get changed while the real problems like bugs being in the game for YEARS literally have no priority. I could go even further into this but it would be a veeeery long review (even longer than it is right now).
Besides all that, the community is very toxic after all. I lost count of how many times i got told to k*ll myself or being insulted for my nationality just because someone didn't liked the way i played, doesn't matter on which side i played on. It also took them 6 YEARS to actively do something against cheaters (and there are still many many out there).

They are trying to change the game to make it more appealing to either role, but sadly don't think that through. Buffing/nerfing certain Killers unnecessarily while others don't get touched at all. Just like Perks (on either side) being totally fine over years but have to be changed now because they want to "change the meta" only creating a new, even more annoying meta (movement speed meta, endurance meta, gen rushing/kicking/slowdown/regression meta).

Right now the perks, mostly survivor perks, lack creativity. The game got Perks which literally do the exact same but slightly changed being better or worse. Also you've got little to no killer variety, if you like to play as and against the same 3 Killers out of 34 different ones, good for you, but you won't see any other killers beside Wesker, Chucky or Blight at this point of the game. 

Coming back to the Players: The playerbase right now is having a competitive mindset, meaning they'll do ANYTHING it takes to win the game, leaving casual players who don't play the game 8-12 hours a day, not being able to have an actual chill and fun game without getting ripped apart every round over and over again.

Someday i may come back and write a different review, but for now that's how i feel about a game which brought me joy (and sometimes tears) over many many years, breaking my heart watching the game slowly dying because of the incompetence of the devs and toxicity of the community.

Go ahead DBD community and do your thing with only being able to say "skill issue" whenever someone actually points out the problems of the game right now, i know y'all can't take criticsm <3

I think I'm finally quitting DBD for good. I had fun, but it's gotten a lot less fun recently. I have some good memories. I also have a love-hate relationship with this game. The current main problem is that Killers feel like they have to camp or tunnel to win the game. If they're going against a SWF (survivor with friends), they are not wrong.

DBD is trying to balance around two completely different situations. One is survivors playing grouped up with comms and another is a group of 4 strangers. What DBD has done to try to alleviate this is to add  more HUD information so survivors can see some of the things other survivors are doing. For example, you can see which survivors are on gens and if another survivor is being chased by the killer. 

These HUD changes have fundamentally broken the game. I'm a survivor main and I dislike these changes. I used to love the horror element of this game. The Killer could be coming towards at any moment. You just didn't know. It was constant fear to look around as much as you can, but also staying on the gen. Or having to rescue a survivor on the hook, without knowing what the other survivors were doing.

What has happened on the game with these HUD info changes, is that Killers now camp or tunnel more than ever. I would say it's at last 67% of the games are a Killer who camps or tunnels. I can't even get mad at them because I know if they go against a good group of survivors, this is the only way to win. I used to play Killer on the regular, but I stopped because it's not fun playing Killer when you feel you have to camp or tunnel. 

I like the chase. I like the horror element. I feel like those parts of the game are now illusory. If you put on a good chase, the Killer will stop chasing you or disconnect. If a survivor goes down fast, the survivor is likely to disconnect. 

The fundamental problem of DBD are grouped up survivors with comms. They will communicate where the Killer is. They will work together in unison, speed-rushing the gens. They will work together to bully the Killer with flashlight saves. The Killer must camp or tunnel to have a chance at winning. The game is semi-balanced around this concept. A good Killer who camps or tunnels will go against a good SWF who will gen-rush. 

It makes playing a solo survivor almost unbearable. Many matches with disconnects. Match will be an easy 3k/4k for the Killer or an easy escape, with only a few balanced matches. But yet, there is no horror. There are no epic chases. The solution is obvious, but it will never be implemented. Put SWFs in a different game mode. The main mode of DBD should be 4 strangers with no external comms (in-game voice proximity chat would be cool though) against a Killer. That's the horror. That's the game with one chase that can win a game. Devs can then make changes that disincentivize camping / tunneling. Get rid of all the HUD info too, except maybe add Kindred base-kit to stop camping / tunneling.

Stuffed Green Peppers

Ingredients
6 green bell peppers

salt to taste

1 pound ground beef

‚Öì cup chopped onion

salt and pepper to taste

1 (14.5 ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes, chopped

¬Ω cup water

¬Ω cup uncooked rice

1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce

1 cup shredded Cheddar cheese

2 (10.75 ounce) cans condensed tomato soup

water as needed

Directions
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Cut the tops off bell peppers and remove the seeds. Cook bell peppers in boiling water for 5 minutes; drain. Sprinkle salt inside each bell pepper and set aside.

Place ground beef and onion in a large skillet over medium heat; cook and stir until beef is browned, about 5 minutes. Drain off excess fat and season with salt and pepper. Stir in tomatoes, 1/2 cup water, rice, and Worcestershire sauce; reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer until rice is tender, about 15 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in cheese.

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).

Stuff each bell pepper with beef and rice mixture; arrange open-side up in a baking dish.

Combine tomato soup with just enough water in a medium bowl to make the soup a gravy consistency; pour over the bell peppers and cover with aluminum foil.

Bake in the preheated oven until heated through and cheese is melted and bubbly, about 25 to 30 minutes. (this game sucks)

The game has evolved a bit over time, and will continue to do so. However, after over 1000 hours, my general opinion is: Behavior will continue to buff and nerf everything into oblivion to the point where you have to keep up with how your various abilities change. There is a pretty large learning curve, because each killer is different. It helps to play as killer and survivor, to know the killers weaknesses. The amount of continued development is something the player has to keep up with. There are so many killers and ability changes now, that if you take a break, you have to catch up on how everything has changed. Keeping up with the killers, the changes, the metas, and everything like that is sort of key to being S tier at this game. It is a very good game. However after many hours I have reached some burnout on it. I recommend it to almost anyone. However, I will warn you, the game is very toxic and sweaty.

Not fun for casual gamers, the game suffers from really bad balancing issues in that if you don't play with a team of 4 your chances of winning are virtually 0, "murder simulator" would more accurately describe the game. The killer has far too much control/ power over how enjoyable a round is and they tend to play toxic by camping/ tunnelling making it really boring and predictable.

Another reason I don't recommend the game is because there are many aspects of the game that devs refuse to fix and havent fixed for years now including dodgy hit boxes and the fact killers can hit you through the other side of a pallet which is one of the only counter plays survivors have. Nurse is also very broken and hasn't been addressed yet.

Finally the community is awful and gets way too heated and toxic over a game.

 the community can be a real opinionated pain in the ass, and the game is constantly adding new perks and characters that can change the dynamic of the game drastically, creating an odd friction between killers and survivors and normally one side or the other will pretty much just say the game is unbalanced and its because of (insert new killer/perk/items/ETC.) 

now is the game FUN!?! yes (IMO) it has tons of content and is clearly one of the biggest horror games of all time (or at least horror themed) its got a pretty good progression system that feels rather rewarding in general, the blood web can be a little tedious but not bad by any means

the black eye of this game is definitely the community though...i cant imagine actually trying to pick up this game for the first time with where its at, if you play killer and dont know what youre doing survivors will call you a "baby killer", and if you play survivor youre eventually gonna run into killers that are just sweaty as hell...and the end game chat is just terrible honestly, i mean normally i just drop a "gg" but some people just explode with frustration and either leave comments on your profile (which is actually pretty funny) or just start shit talking until you leave the match...
