I bought this game hoping for a thrilling and fun experience, but I was sorely disappointed. The game is full of bugs, glitches, and imbalance. The killers are either too overpowered or too weak, and the survivors are either too smart or too dumb. The matchmaking system is broken, and the servers are laggy and unstable. The graphics are outdated, and the sound effects are annoying. The game also lacks variety and content, and the developers are slow to fix the issues or add new features. The game is not worth the money or the time, and I regret buying it. I do not recommend this game to anyone, unless you enjoy frustration and boredom.

For example, one of the most common bugs is the ‚Äúhatchet glitch‚Äù, where the killer‚Äôs throwing weapon goes through walls and hits survivors. This makes the game unfair and frustrating for the survivors, who have no way to avoid it. Another bug is the ‚Äúinfinite loading screen‚Äù, where the game gets stuck on the loading screen and never starts. This wastes the players‚Äô time and forces them to restart the game. These bugs have been reported for months, but the developers have not fixed them yet.

The game also suffers from imbalance, as some killers and survivors are much stronger or weaker than others. For instance, the Nurse is widely considered to be the most powerful killer, as she can teleport through walls and obstacles and catch survivors easily. On the other hand, the Clown is regarded as the weakest killer, as he has no mobility or map pressure and his gas bottles are easy to dodge. Similarly, some survivors have perks that give them an unfair advantage, such as Decisive Strike, which allows them to escape the killer‚Äôs grasp once per match. Other survivors have perks that are useless or detrimental, such as No Mither, which makes them start the match injured and unable to heal. These imbalances make the game boring and repetitive, as players tend to use the same characters and strategies over and over.

The game also has a poor matchmaking system, which often pairs players with different skill levels or regions. This results in matches that are either too easy or too hard, or that have high ping and lag. The game also has a toxic community, where players often insult, harass, or cheat each other. The game does not have a proper reporting system, and the developers rarely ban or punish the offenders.

The game‚Äôs graphics and sound are also outdated and annoying. The game looks like it was made in 2016, which is when it was released. The game has low-resolution textures, bland colors, and poor lighting. The game also has a lot of clipping and collision issues, where characters and objects go through each other or get stuck. The game‚Äôs sound effects are also irritating, as they are loud, distorted, and repetitive. The game‚Äôs music is also bland and generic, and does not fit the horror theme of the game.

The game also lacks variety and content, as it has only a few maps, modes, and cosmetics. The game has 22 killers and 24 survivors, but most of them are similar or reskins of each other. The game has only 14 maps, which are randomly generated from a pool of tiles. The game has only two modes, which are the standard 4v1 mode and a custom mode where players can set their own rules. The game also has a limited selection of cosmetics, which are mostly recolors or slight variations of the default outfits. The game also charges a lot of money for its DLCs, which often add new characters or cosmetics that are not worth the price.

The game‚Äôs developers are also slow to fix the issues or add new features to the game. The game often has long periods of time between patches or updates, and when they do come, they often introduce more bugs or problems than they solve. The game also has a lot of unfulfilled promises, such as cross-play, cross-progression, dedicated servers, and a new ranking system, which have been delayed or canceled. The game also has a lot of wasted potential, as it could have been a great horror game with more creativity, polish, and balance.

In conclusion, Dead by Daylight is a game that I do not enjoy or recommend. It is a game that is full of flaws, frustrations, and boredom. It is a game that does not live up to its premise or potential. I've met many good people on this game such as my gf and friends I thank this game for that and not much else.

Dead by Daylight (DbD) is a thrilling asymmetrical multiplayer horror game that pits four survivors against one relentless killer. Developed by Behaviour Interactive, it has gained a dedicated player base since its release.

Here‚Äôs my review of Dead by Daylight:

Title: Heart-Pounding Horror and Intense Showdowns
Gameplay (4/5):
The core gameplay loop in DbD is both simple and addictive. As a survivor, you‚Äôll work with your team to repair generators while avoiding the killer. The tension rises as the heartbeat sound grows louder, signaling the killer‚Äôs proximity. The asymmetrical nature keeps matches fresh, and the variety of killers and survivors adds depth.

Graphics and Atmosphere (4.5/5):
DbD excels in creating a spine-chilling atmosphere. The eerie maps, dim lighting, and haunting sound design immerse players in the horror genre. The graphics are solid, although some animations could be smoother.

Killer Variety (4/5):
The roster of killers is diverse, each with unique abilities and playstyles. From the stealthy Wraith to the brutal Leatherface, there‚Äôs a killer for every preference. However, balancing issues occasionally arise, affecting the overall experience.

Survivor Experience (3.5/5):
Playing as a survivor can be intense, but it can also feel frustrating. Escaping the killer requires teamwork, but solo queueing can lead to uneven matches. The grind for Bloodpoints (in-game currency) can be time-consuming.

Community and Toxicity (3/5):
DbD‚Äôs community can be passionate, but toxicity exists. Some players take the game too seriously, leading to unpleasant interactions. However, finding a friendly group can enhance the experience.

Overall (4/5):
Dead by Daylight delivers heart-pounding moments, whether you‚Äôre narrowly escaping a killer‚Äôs grasp or landing a clutch save. While it has its flaws, the game‚Äôs unique concept and constant updates keep players coming back for more.

Remember, the true horror lies not only in the game but also in the friendships you forge and the adrenaline-fueled matches that leave you breathless. Happy hunting! üåüüî™üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüíÄ


Title: Shadows and Betrayal in the Fog

Gameplay (3/5):
Dead by Daylight is a gripping dance of survival and deception, but it‚Äôs not without its dark corners. Let‚Äôs delve into the shadowy realm of cheating.

The Cheaters Among Us:
While most players embrace the game‚Äôs challenge, a sinister subset lurks‚Äîthe cheaters. These elusive individuals exploit glitches, use unauthorized software, or collude with the enemy. Their actions disrupt the delicate balance between survivors and killers, tarnishing the experience for all.

Wallhacks and Aimbots:
Wallhacks grant cheaters X-ray vision, revealing survivor locations through obstacles. Aimbots ensure every shot hits its mark, leaving survivors defenseless. These digital specters haunt the Fog, undermining the game‚Äôs integrity.

Community Fallout (2.5/5):
Cheating fractures the community. Trust erodes, and accusations fly like crows disturbed from their roosts. Legitimate players suffer, questioning their allies‚Äô motives. The Fog thickens with suspicion.

Developer Vigilance (4/5):
Behaviour Interactive battles these shadows. Regular updates and anti-cheat measures attempt to cleanse the realm. But like survivors in a desperate chase, they‚Äôre always one step behind.

Survivor Resilience (4.5/5):
True survivors adapt. They learn to spot the telltale signs‚Äîthe killer who always knows their location, the impossible shots. They report, they persevere, and they fight back.

Final Verdict (3.5/5):
Dead by Daylight remains a thrilling experience, but the specter of cheating looms. As we navigate the Fog, let‚Äôs remember: honor among survivors, vigilance against the shadows, and a determination to keep the game true.

In the Fog, trust is fragile, and betrayal wears many faces. Will you survive, or will you succumb to the darkness? üå´Ô∏èüîçüî™üíî


Title: Shadows of Deception: Dead by Daylight‚Äôs Anti-Cheat Struggle

Introduction: The Fog Thickens
Dead by Daylight, a game where survival hangs by a thread, is plagued by an insidious force‚Äîthe lack of a robust anti-cheat system. As players traverse the fog-shrouded realms, they encounter not only killers and fellow survivors but also those who exploit vulnerabilities for their gain.

The Current State: A Fractured Reality
Easy Anti-Cheat (EAC):

Dead by Daylight relies on Easy Anti-Cheat to detect and ban cheaters. While EAC is a step in the right direction, it‚Äôs not foolproof.
Some players slip through its grasp, leaving the community vulnerable to their malevolent actions.
Automated Bans:

EAC tracks known hacks and cheats, but it‚Äôs a reactive measure. Players suffer before the banhammer falls.
The Fog echoes with frustration as legitimate survivors face unfair odds.
Community Fallout:

Trust erodes like ancient tombstones. Accusations fly, poisoning the once-cohesive community.
Survivors question their allies, wondering if they‚Äôre facing a true adversary or a digital phantom.
The Four-Point Plan: A Beacon of Hope
Dead by Daylight acknowledges the darkness and vows to fight back. Their roadmap for anti-cheat measures includes:

Vulnerability Identification:

Intensifying efforts to identify and fix vulnerabilities. The Fog must be free of hidden traps.
Cheater Mitigation:

Curtailing player sniping‚Äîthose who forcefully join specific lobbies to disrupt matches.
The Fog should be a battleground, not a theater for sabotage.
Community Vigilance:

Encouraging players to report suspicious behavior promptly.
Together, we can cleanse the realm.
Developer Persistence:

Behaviour Interactive, like a determined survivor, won‚Äôt rest. Updates and vigilance continue.
The Fog may shift, but so does our resolve.
Conclusion: A Battle Unfinished
In the eternal struggle between light and shadow, Dead by Daylight fights on. As survivors, we adapt, report, and endure. But until the Fog lifts from the cheater-infested corners, our trust remains fragile.

Remember, fellow survivors: honor, resilience, and a watchful eye can pierce even the darkest veil. üå´Ô∏èüîçüî™üíî

i say this wholeheartedly, do not play this game if you're someone with an addictive personality or someone who in general struggles with mental health. if you cannot maintain your cool, this game is going to be agonizing for you - at least if you plan on playing Killer primarily.

similar to league of legends this is a game designed to ensnare you, drag you into a toxic feedback loop of endorphins and depression, and keep you hooked so you spend more and more money on skins and killers.

this game is objectively pay to win. you either grind for ~35 hours for one character, then grind another 6-12 hours for their perks, all to use them on another character so you can tailor the experience to your liking, or you fork over 5 dollars for a character just to grind 6-12 hours on their perks.

pair this with an uber toxic community, and a gameplay structure designed so that the role of the killer - the role with theoretically more power - is stressful and anxiety inducing, this is a game best avoided. Or if you like league of legends and cock and ball torture it's a 10/10.

I stopped playing 2.5 years ago because I noticed a disconnect between the devs and the community playing the game. 

I bought tons of money worth of skins and DLCs and at some point I decided it was all a waste of money. They continue to push really shite DLCs ([u] let's be honest, "Nick Cage" is kind of a stupid effing DLC [/u]) and seem to just be in it for the money they're making from these. You don't  have to buy them, but you also don't feel like you're playing the full game without them. Every DLC that came out broke the game and I'm sure this still reigns true based on more recent reviews. 

It's a shame a game I used to have so much fun playing has become so [b] bland and boring [/b]. Perception could've changed had Behavior just stopped thinking about the next DLC and really thought about how to balance, fix, and go back to the root of what this game was intended to feel like.

One of those games you keep playing against your better judgment, hoping it'll get better eventually. It doesn't really...but you stick around anyway because it's a unique genre without much competition (Identity V being the closest competitor, albeit a mobile game).

BHVR's DBD could learn a lot from its current mobile port, run by the same developers of Identity V. Separate Ranked & Casual match queues, multiple game modes, better cosmetics...It's only very recently that the PC version has started to incorporate some of the features from mobile DBD/IDV and often in a lazy & half-baked manner than what's available on the mobile counterparts. BHVR really needs to step their game up because 8 years of the bare minimum live service is honestly beyond embarrassing at this point.

This was once a fun, creative, wonder of a game. The concept was amazing and the gameplay was addicting, but over the years it never got consistently better. This idea of "balance" on a purely casual game is one of the reasons why, I believe there should be no such thing as a meta and the game should 100% be played how the player wants to play. A meta implies there's a right/strong way to play, which should have NEVER existed in a game like this. The large variety of perks and abilities each side has encourages creativity and experimentation which can never be put into practice because of the simple fact that one thing is significantly better then the other, so you have no reason to ever use your other options because you risk having a game that could be ended very abruptly along with an unfun experience. The developer team behind this game is laughably incompetent and their idea of "balance" isn't even at least good. The game is objectively one sided if both sides were pushed to their absolute limits, anyone with over 100 hours will tell you that; survivor queue times take around 10 minutes for a match that could end as quickly as it started. The developer team rarely listens to the community and when they do they choose to listen to the more toxic side of the community. Which, by the way, were created by the team themselves because in any "competitive" game, people want to naturally win, some more then others per say, which breeds the toxicity. The team themselves are greedy and care more about the short term health of the game over the long term health. For example the "Darkness Among Us" chapter was poorly designed, lazy, had absolutely no inspiration, and suspiciously seemed more like they wanted a killer whom they could make a bunch of simple cosmetics for, that people would want to buy. Even after that catastrophe they seemed to not have learned their lesson.

I myself admit I was once in love with this game, and part of the toxicity it breeds. But over the years as I got older I realized these truths about the game and never want to touch it again. As an older, on and off player of this game I would not recommend this game, or at the very least if you buy it don't give this team any more of your money unless they truly deserve it, which they do not. Go buy left 4 dead 2 or something, it may be old but its sure as hell not a bad game.

If you have taken the time to read this review and are willing to have a reasonable discussion in the comments on why you disagree, you're more then welcome to. But the information I have stated is all true, until changes are made it will remain 100% true.

UPDATE: this review deserves an update and there have been edits in here in there in each paragraph. I'm happy to say the developers HAVE made some wonderful changes since the creation of this review. The grind on the bloodweb has been significantly lessened and the earning of bloodpoints has been multiplied so that the earnings scale to a larger amount over time. Some very problematic perks/offerings have been tuned down or changed entirely so that they cannot be as easily abused as before. During my years playing the game it felt like the developers did not care about the player base or the health of the game, but how much money they could milk before this cash cow was dry. That opinion has changed as it feels like new life has been breathed into it because the community itself responded positively to these changes, therefore everyone naturally has a better experience. 

However the statement that the game is ultimately one sided still remains true but that doesn't matter as much as it once did. One rarely sees super sweat squads that go out of their way to make the killer player have a bad time, and even if you did find a group like that its still manageable because the killer role feels more powerful than before. 2-3 kills or 6-8 hooks is better then nothing and one should be theoretically satisfied with that as they put up a good fight. Although I will say "competitive" dbd is an absolute joke to me and if anyone who genuinely plays this game as if it was an e-sport is going out of their way to earn a trophy that doesn't exist. Therefore, competitive dbd teams are a joke, but at least this isn't the only game they play.

One glaring issue that is present 7 years later the map Lampkin Lane, which is unironically the most poorly designed map the game has ever seen and still is even to this day. Unlike literally every other map in the game which follows SOME sort of theme (with the exception of the RPD map), Lampkin throws all of that away and structures its strongest tiles to be literally unplayable for killers unless you're a nurse, or in some cases a hag who can trap it. In this game survivors have pallets and windows to evade the killer and waste their time, windows usually are LESS effective due to them always being available while pallets are stronger but a one time use each. However this map throws all of that away and makes all windows 100% safe with little counter play. Not to mention these windows are littered in EVERY accessible house, each equipped with enough space from each vault to track the killers location to determine which direction they went, and little space in between each window/pallet so that running to a new loop is never a problem. There was a rework for this map that solved players from abusing it through (old) balanced landing about the maps core problems and arguably made it BETTER for survivors because of the numerous fore mentioned windows. A map with a ton of pallets/windows is fair game, its something that all killers will have to deal with eventually (except nurse), but unless the whole killer player population drops what they're doing and plays nurse forever then this map will continue to be an automatic lose for killers. Its wide and open with long sightlines until you enter the house with tight corners and things killers could randomly get stuck on, so not even huntress/deathslinger players will have a good time. Its just to simple for anyone to abuse these overpowered windows and outrun any killer, even casual players can abuse this without a shred of effort or planning. Killers have to go out of their way to do everything they possibly can to do well and generally wont. 
In conclusion, either remove the map entirely or do an extreme overhaul/rework of it. I cannot stress enough how much of a problem this is, even RPD can work against killers and its been done before. Anyone asking "how do I play Haddonfield as killer?" would be greeted with "you don't", thats the definition of problematic.

This game is not for new players anymore for the same reason games like R6 or League of Legends aren't for new players anymore and that's the player comparison of MMR and Time Played. Someone with 100 hours but is absolute dogshit at the game has an inherent advantage over all new players. Despite being at the same MMR. All because of familiarity. they know the maps, mechanics and general strategy compared to a fresh player still learning. 

Past that this game did revolutionise it genre on it release. but has fallen into cash grab tactics to keep its relevancy which has resulted in over $200 to have a full game experience and a relatively stable starting place compared to the current player base. That's called pay to win structuring for those familiar with its debut in TF2 and COD

which means the game overall is ass unless your willing to drop 200 dollars or hours to get to the proper matchmaking criteria and out of the grind hellscape of losses, smurfs, way to little blood points, and randomised perk buying, and much more rouge like elements in a paid multiplayer game.

The endgame chat is just a way to get other people to call you horrible, horrible things more creatively, and does not provide a fair and even balance between killers, maps, survivors, or perks in general. I highly, highly recommend getting this game if you want to kill yourself and just need that little extra push, because the developers and the community of this game will provide it to you almost immediately. Whether you are playing this game as a newby running a pretty bad build due to limited perk options, running the Mr. Nice Guy Build, playing slugging nurse, or even intentionally letting the survivors escape out of the exit gates, you will always face backlash with what you are doing by the most vile, degenerate people on the face of the planet. And do not bother going to other places to complain or vent even remotely dbd related. Even Quora pages will leave you with clinical depression from the sheer backlash of daring to play this game to win. Dead by Daylight needs serious help, and has left me needing it as well.

If you are still intending to buy this product, or have already bought it, I wish you the best of luck managing to fend off the rancid mouthed, keyboard warrior gross people that nobody likes.

I started playing this game about 6 years ago, mostly on Xbox and some on steam. The current state of the game is the worst it has ever been. "Camping" and "Tunneling" are two terms that everyone in the community should be very familiar with and it is also overwhelmingly present in matches lately. I read a comment once about this game and it still rings true to this day. "The game is designed in a way that if one side is having fun, then the other side is not." The developers at Behavior are some of the worst devs I have ever seen for a video game. Almost 8 years and their game only gets worse over time. Instead of fixing broken mechanics, they would rather release new skins and new characters. The devs are completely out of touch with the player base and rarely listen to complaints that need to be looked into. This game is no longer worth my time or your time until the current state gets some needed attention. Do not waste your money or your time. There are better games with better communities and better devs. THIS GAME SUCKS! Plain and simple.

This game is goofy fun for beginners. 
Interesting for intermediates. 
And a slog for pros.

Overall an 8/10

While I rly like the game and the characters, this game is suppost to respesent a survival horror game, Dead by Daylight is FAR FROM a survival horror game, Instead off trying to survive a terrifying killer, Here you loop the killer around some pallets and come some boxes And then Teabag him or her because you showed how easy it is to survive you ''Terrifying Killer'' Assides from that, killers have to put someone on meathooks, but before that they have to hit the person twice and then Pick em up, And then hope the Survivor does not have a overpowerd skill called Desisive Strike or if another survivor doesn't have a Flashlight you just have to tap into the killers direction and they are forced to drop the survivor, And if that doesn't work, just bodyblock the killer and make them do they job all over again and then teabag some more. All with all Survivor in this game is not that spectacular, just repair 5 generator pretty damn fast open the exit gate and leave. As a killer if you dare to take the job, Just try not to get agitated by how stressfull your job is, Unless you play Hillbilly, He is broken as all crap. Along that in this game people will rage at your profile just because you killed them or because you did your job as a killer, And if you let other survivors die because it is to dangerous for your own life, Expect also a massive rage comment, I find the game decant but the community in this game is pure cancer. It is actually worse then League Or Dota in my opinion. I suppose if anything you are forced to make your profile privvate or friends only to not come acress the salt and rage in this game. With that said, This game takes grinding to get certain Perks what is even more crappy in my personal opinion.

As a last thing said, If you wana play this game for fun with some friends, Expect to get yelled at because apperandly it is toxic, You heared me, it is Toxic to play a multiplayer game with your friends. Do you still get it ? Because I certainly don't. The fact you get yelled at no mather what side you play and no mather what you do is pathetic and it surely makes it that I wound NOT recommend this game purely because off 2 main reasons. 

1. Killer in this game is a joke all you need to do is run around the same pallet or loop for 5 minutes and the game is done be either all generators done or the killers ragequitting.
2. Survivors in this game are mostly cancer. Is just teamagging and bullying the killer along with that just overal toxic behavior and making you think you are playing with little kids.

Maybe if the community gets better this game gets a me a possivity line but for now, If you rahter have a fun play, Stay the hell avay from the toxic waste land.

[h1]Asymmetrical game full of DLC and lost potential, with the most toxic community out there.[/h1]
Very positive rating on Steam is a meme, reviews are given as positive without actual review part + majority of players come from Epic. Literally, you turn off cross-play, suddenly you can't get a single match in 10 mins of waiting ! 
[b]As killer, you go against:[/b] TLDR: trolls
- 4 jerks who make you chase them in forever circles
- people who just give up for some reason in the middle of a match
- trolls who on purpose provoke you, they're trying to ruin your mood
- extra trolls, who even when they open the escape door, stand there until you reach them, just so that they can pathetically t-bag in front of you and then walk away - if you refuse to entertain them, they'll literally wait minutes until the very end, prolonging the lost match, just to get their pitiful satisfaction
- stupidly high level players, like Level 100 ! - my second match was against 2 of them
[b]As survivor, you go against: [/b] TLDR: surprise, also trolls
- killer who picks you as their target and then just focuses on killing you and only you
- killer who puts you up on a hook and then stands next to you until you're dead
- killer that gives up in middle of match on playing at all
- killer that downs you as you're the last person alive and sits next to you until the match ends minutes later

Either way, you'll play against and with pathetic remnants of human beings, trolls and provokers, people that aren't playing a game, they're trying to piss you off. Saddest part is, that the game could be fun without these individuals. But since majority of the "community" is toxic, you very very rarely get a fair and fun match. 

There are also stupid perks that break the game on both sides, nonsense of infinite jumping out of windows and generally no reason to report anyone, even cheaters, because nobody gets ever banned. Balance in this game ? Non existent, you'll play against people with thousands of hours in the game, right from the start. Considering that they literally have perks you can't even get at that point and know all the maps perfectly, good luck. They also don't play for fun, majority of them play just to annoy everyone online that they run into, and ofc at the end of the match, they'll try to provoke you in chat.

Occasionally the game can be fun, but it won't be against the troll teams. And that's majority of them, especially from Epic, where the game is free and where majority of the playerbase for this game comes from. Sadly, it's the only assymetrical game that's still alive, even in at the start of 2024, mainly thanks to licensing everyone's beloved horror stars.

Core gameplay is literally very basic and can devolve into the most boring game: survivor, find generator, hold a button to "repair it", press space bar when QTE shows up, fixed, that's it, move to the next one. Killer meanwhile: goes around all generators, listening if one's running or not. With perks he can also randomly hear explosion sound coming from people running near birds, killer goes there, hits a survivor, survivor runs, killer runs after them like in a cartoon. Once survivor messes up, killer finally catches up with him, downs the survivor, puts them on a hook and then politely goes away from that area and hunts for another one, fully knowing that this survivor's gonna get rescued soon, making his effort pointless.

Lost potential: game would be much more fun without all the nonsense perks, for both killers and survivors. With more variety to survivor objectives, rather than just getting to generator and pressing a space bar on a QTE. Actual incentives for people to not be so horrible to each other and punishments for the toxic players. Better level design, that doesn't allow for infinite running in circles and jumping through windows and infinite pallet drop runs. It looks fun on videos, but when you play yourself, it's frustrating, especially against high level players with very strong perks, it becomes tedious.

Last mention is the DLC, unlocking new survivors / killers is extremely slow and tedious, it's designed to push everyone to buy the characters with real cash. $300 worth of DLC says it all. 

P.S.: If you'll really decide to buy the game, get it on sale. Look up which characters are fun to play before mass buying DLCs and in Options, there's Anonymous mode that you can turn on, it hides your name from other players. Find guides for your favorite characters, try out different perks and best of luck with having some fun.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2020 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Dead by Daylight is an intense and thrilling survival horror game that pits four survivors against one powerful killer. Players must work together to escape the killer's clutches before they're eliminated, while the killer must use their unique abilities to track down and kill the survivors.


The game has good sound design and graphics, creating an immersive and intense atmosphere that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The variety of different killers and survivors, each with their own unique abilities and cosmetics, keeps the game fresh and engaging, and the high-stakes gameplay is guaranteed to get your heart racing.


Overall, Dead by Daylight is a thrilling experience that is sure to keep you coming back for more. If you're a fan of survival horror or just enjoy a good scare, Dead by Daylight is a must-play.

Editing the review after an extra 500+ hours.  A game with [strike]ok[/strike] terrible mechanics [strike]at best[/strike].  Easily the most toxic community of players of any game I have ever played.  Extraordinarily non-receptive development team to player feedback.  BHVR is petty towards any negative feedback [strike]by streamers.[/strike] at all. Knowing what I do now I would have never bought this game, or spent the time I did playing.  Save your money and buy literally anything else.  The novelty will wear off.  Avoid in favor of a game you will actually like down the road. 
Easily the worse game I have ever played.  For context I have 400+ games on my steam account alone.  Plus other PC platforms, plus consoles.  I am generally one of the easiest possible players to sell to and love almost every game I play and try to see the best in even subpar games.  
Its a horror game that isn't in any way frightening.  Just frustrating.  It has bad game play, awful mechanics, the worse community, no dev vision, no character cohesion, feedback system is worthless, isn't fun, bad graphics, terrible cheat detection, learning curve requires 1000+ hours to even potentially be decent, MMR basically imaginary.  I have struggled over the extra 500 hours to find even one positive feature about this game and there just isn't one.

.1/5

"Dead by Daylight" is a thrilling and addictive asymmetrical horror game that has captivated players for years. With over 2,000 hours invested and exclusive streaming, it's clear that the game offers a unique and enduring experience.

The asymmetrical gameplay, where one killer hunts down four survivors, provides endless variety and tension. The ever-expanding roster of killers and survivors, each with their own abilities and perks, keeps the gameplay fresh and dynamic.

However, the game's community dynamics can be a double-edged sword. While the variety of player interactions adds to the unpredictability, the presence of toxic players can be frustrating. The balance between intense competition and a positive gaming environment is a challenge, especially for someone who streams the game regularly.

Despite occasional frustrations, the constant updates, new content, and the developers' commitment to evolving the game contribute to its longevity. The fact that you've invested so much time and exclusively stream "Dead by Daylight" speaks volumes about its appeal.

In essence, "Dead by Daylight" offers an exhilarating experience, but the presence of toxicity and occasional frustrations is a testament to the passionate and competitive community. It's a game that keeps you coming back for more, even with its challenges.

It's 4v1 .  4 survivors 1 killer .  Survivors repair generators to open a gate to escape. Meanwhile Killer goes around hunting you. Teamwork makes the dreamwork.  Everyone has a job to do.  If you're getting chased by killer,  the rest of your team better be repairing those generators!  As killer, you'll have to strategize how to go about your hunt and keeping an eye on those gens popping off.  If a survivor is running you for a while,  you have to decide to let go of your ego and chase someone else off gens or take a big fat L.   On top of this, killer and survivors bring these things perks that give you special abilities to help you achieve your objective.   Testing different combination of these perks is fun.  Most of the game's community are alright and wholesome, but of course there are always the bad apples.  Just manage your expectations.  All in all, a fun way to pass the time if you're into these type of games.

Been having a ton of fun playing this game!
It taps into your inner emotions and I often end up shouting 'I hate this game', but really it's a love-hate thing.

As a survivor, it has thought me that I actually am more of a coward than I would like to believe... I will do whatever I have to do to escape alive. Even it means selling out my fellow survivors, beg for mercy or act silly (noseboops teehee) or just run away without looking back. After 400 hours of playing, I still get scared, which is really impressive!

As a killer - I am mostly completely ruthless, but I have to admit that I'm starting to grow a soft heart. Even with all the 'limitations', players have found very creative ways to communicate - from noseboops, offering their items, or slowly shaking yes/no with their heads... it makes for hilarious moments in between all the tension! And really - in the end, it's about the good times!

Loving it and looking forward to what's next!

[h2] The good side: [/h2]
DBD can be a funny and entertaining 1vs4 online game where you can play as a killer or a survivor like in your favourite horror movies. The thrill is easy to feel in both roles, killers must get the survivors and these need to escape through two different doors restoring the power fixing 5 generators. In some situations you can escape through a hatch.
The concepts are easy to get, there are a lot of content to combine: perks, hexes, items, addons. Some killers are harder to play than others.

[h2] The bad side: [/h2]
There are a lot of DLCs, normally high priced and they release more and more to keep the hype and players attention. The base game comes with ten killers and survivors. I suggest to get them on sales or use "shards" ("game money" you win when you level up) instead of money if you can (not all characters can be bought by shards though).

The company could do things much better. They don't even know their own game, because they don't play it. 
So they are completely oblivious to what's going on. Looks like they give priority to opinions coming from people having a tantrum instead of listening opinions from people providing them a useful feedback. Is for this that the game has a lot of hasty wacky stupid changes in short periods of time. What you find entertaining can disappear in any moment, or a simple game mechanic can be removed and spoil the whole game for a (normally long) period of time.

All online games have rotten apples. Some people will write insults on your profile, teammates will disconnect of the game, some like to insult in chat...etc.
But no worries because not everybody are like these ones. There are cool and nice people that makes a funny and positive experience of the game =)

[h2] Conclusion: [/h2]
I used to enjoy and have a lot of fun with this game but now it's just not the same, at this point is getting very chaotic and I wouldn't recommend it to new players or older DBD gamers.
The game can be very amusing and challenging and yet very unfair if you're playing in the wrong update date.

I see DBD and other "Behaviour" games and it seems they're good having original and good ideas but they fail when it's time to make them work.  I've been a witness of how this company along with their lack of communication, rudeness towards their players/clients, arrogance and incompetence have destroyed their own game and reputation. It's a pity because the idea was good and it's sad to see how a team destroys their own creation.

Edit 2: Don't remember when they added some audio accessibility features, but they still took too long to get here. Being able to see certain sound triggers is better, but still doesn't fix some of the audio problems for those with disabilities. Some sounds, especially music and "ambiance" are STILL too loud.

Edit: If you are willing to "grind the game out," wait for long killer queues, or play with friends, you will have fun. If you are NOT willing to do those things, find something else. (Also a lot of "meta" perks and stuff are locked behind pay walls, and only 1 perk per DLC is typically relevant.) The game starts to get good at around hour 20. So we got some MMO syndrome over here where the only "good content" is late game, making the experience for new players really bad.

Original Review

Queue times for killer are too long. Survivor gameplay is a mixed bag of feelings. Character "power level" and "usefulness" out of the box is all over the place. The game's recent colorblind mode made the game finally playable in a lot of ways, where in the past I couldn't even SEE on most maps due to black on black color scheme that couldn't be changed, but the lack of sound options or video options, as a whole, still make things way too difficult to see or hear. I understand that not letting me raise the gamma makes it more "fair" but I also can't actually see due to my own color issues.

Sometimes I play with friends and have a bit of fun, but the core gameplay loop doesn't engage me enough to recommend it to others. I could probably enjoy the killer gameplay a bit more but the wait times for a game are way too long for so little pay off.
Always entertaining with friends and to play on your own.

Fun game
It only took me a bit less than 1000 hours to understand that the community is the reason why this is a horror game.

In my opinion, this game has 3 main negative attributes:

1: Toxicity, the playerbase has a loud minority of people who will insult you if you lose, and accuse you of cheats/exploits/degenerate strategies if you win. These people can be largely ignored by not reading chat, but every now and again you will face an opponent playing in bad faith looking to ruin the game for everyone for the sake of it.

2: Problems intrinsic to a 4v1: on survivor sometimes the killer is going to go for you and ignore everyone else (referred to as "tunneling"). There are ways to counter it with clever teamworks and perk usage, but you will have to accept that it is going to happen to you once in a while.

3: DLC microtransactions: you will probably want to spend some extra money down the line if you get invested. You can play the game perfectly fine without though. This problem is more prominent playing killer, as the killer characters are unique vs. survivors who all have the same functionality.

If you can accept these conditions, Dead by Daylight is one of the most fun and engaging pvp party games on the market. The skill ceiling is high with lots to learn (and a community that creates a load of recources to do so). Very fun to play with friends, but even solo qeue is not nearly as bad as people would have you believe.

I recomend you buy the standard version or resident evil version if you're starting out.

I used to play VHS, but sadly that game did not survive.  DBD is an OK substitute in a laughable party game sort of way.  Maps are very unbalanced, and the game suffers from "perkapalooza."  Many perks are useless on both the killer and survivor sides, and a few perks are so powerful that they are very frequently used over and over again in every match.

The one thing DBD has going for it over VHS is that DBD doesn't try to over-balance MMR-based matchmaking.  In my opinion, over-balancing the MMR-based matchmaking with a small player pool was ultimately the downfall of VHS.  Every VHS match was very sweaty.  By contrast, DBD has a reasonable mix of sweaty matches, easy matches, and matches where you get destroyed. It is true that maps, characters, and perks should be balanced at high-level play in a game, but as former Halo developer Max Hoberman points out the matchmaking system should actually incorporate some imbalance to prevent matches from always being sweaty.  Despite failing quite spectacularly at balancing the game at high-level play, DBD does well at incorporating MMR-based imbalances into the matchmaking process itself so that you aren't constantly in matches where the opponent(s) are always at your skill level.

Other than that I think VHS was superior to DBD in virtually every way.  The directional sound cues in DBD are garbage when compared to VHS.  DBD's sound cues are not very directionally accurate.  I do wish Behaviour would consider improving this because high-quality, trackable sound cues made for *much* deeper skill development for killer mains in VHS.  It would add a badly needed dimension to DBD gameplay if they improved it.

Beyond sound cues, VHS had extremely well thought-out killers/survivors and maps that worked well in almost any combination.  This is not the case at all for DBD.  While DBD's matchmaking incorporates a good distribution of MMR imbalances so that matches aren't always sweaty in a pure skill sense, DBD itself is a very poorly balanced game.  This frequently leads to matches where skill is not always the factor that determines a win, and instead luck is an uncomfortably large component.  E.g. was the map killer or survivor biased, was a weak/overpowered killer chosen, were weak/overpowered perks/add-ons chosen, etc.  In VHS skill alone almost always determined which side won, not these other factors.  If DBD balanced the game at high-level play across all characters, maps, perks, and add-ons while keeping imbalanced MMR matchmaking, it would be an amazing 4v1 game, but I don't think that's very likely to ever happen.

Overall though I have to give a thumbs up to DBD for standing the test of time, but it's very clear that it's seat as the king of 4v1 games is far from a foregone conclusion.  If a game like VHS were to come around again with a better advertising campaign, a more lax MMR-based matchmaking system, and good map/character/perk balance, I think it could very easily capture significant market share from DBD.

Until that day, DBD scratches the itch if you enjoy 4v1 games.  Just don't take it too seriously.  DBD is a light-hearted party game that provides good entertainment value when you take it for what it is.  The comp aspect of it is completely laughable compared to VHS, but as long as you know that going in, you can still have a lot of fun playing it.

This game is a decent amount of fun, but the monetization is like what you'd expect from a mobile game despite already having a $20 entry fee. If you want access to all of the characters you'll have to be coughing up at least $100 for one side alone. You might think "oh, I don't NEED every character", but
- Almost every character drops with at least one game-changing Perk, which will be extremely difficult to get without buying them (not impossible, but)
- The meta changes wildly with every major update, and Perks that might seem useless at first also have the potential to be buffed into top tier
- The challenges that come with every battle pass drop encourages you to play with paid characters and their Perks
And so you'll inevitably spend the money or miss out on a very large part of the game. Despite how expensive it is to get into the game and get the full experience, they have the gall to also charge $5 for a single cosmetic item, which can range from a new weapon for your Killer to a change in haircut.

Despite some balancing issues on either side, the gameplay is surprisingly fun and unique (mostly because every other asymmetrical multiplayer game ends up dying out) and I'd love to recommend it, but I ultimately can't purely because of how much it costs to actually get into it.


UPDATE: The devs more or less said in a recent Q/A that they do not plan to add new general perks for free, and they seem to have no plans for making the game accessible to new players at all aside from lowering the price of certain DLC - except it's all bundled together as well, meaning you have to spend some hefty cash anyway. It still costs $200 to get access to 75% of the perks for both sides total, and that's not even going into how different killers play or how the audio and cosmetics of survivors might make you more likely to play them as well. Even if you want to just play one side, you're still spending upwards of $100 in the in-game store.
Factor in that the battlepass is now deliberately designed to focus on new characters, and you're SOL if you want to spend a minimal amount of money on the game. Don't buy this game if you value your wallet.

I have never had a game - or ANYTHING in my life - that makes me this absurdly depressed and angry. This game will make ANYONE feel terrible and want to act toxic. It is actively harmful to yourself to play this. This sounds dramatic, but this game will genuinely turn you into a terrible person. If you by chance get addicted to the (few) good parts of this game, it will slowly develop you into a toxic piece of shit. I have intense anxiety issues which this game has actively made much, much, much, much worse over the years of playing it. Sitting in the lobby in queue legitimately makes my heart drop and I start sweating. It has been legitimately detrimental to my health to play this. I am actually, genuinely BEGGING you not to get into it.

Since the highs are so high in the game, whenever I'm thinking of something to play I'll sometimes gravitate towards this. Every time, I tell myself "surely it can't be that bad - I was just dramatic before." The negative effects of this game sounds childish, dramatic, and stupid, so surely it can't be that bad. It is. This game is a constant toxic loop of making someone feel terrible or feeling terrible yourself. You're either ruining someone's game or yours is being ruined. I can't put this into words without it sounding stupid. Just please, do not play this.

Just ignore this game and play something else. You won't have to worry about all of this.

[h1]Don't Play[/h1]

[b]Immense Frustration[/b]

The gameplay loop revolves entirely around robbing your enemy of fun. This makes the experience miserable and the community is notoriously horrible as a result. Both sides are heavily encouraged to keep the other from playing the game.

Survivors' job is the extend chase for as long as possible while their teammates repair generators. This is accomplished by running around, dropping pallets and creating distance between them and the killer. Survivors can stun the Killer, blind them, run away, etc.

Killers' job is to put as many survivors onto meat hooks as possible and sacrifice them. They can also leave survivors on the floor to very slowly bleed out.

Both sides, when played efficiently, will cause the other side to no longer interact with the game. Survivors will often be [i]just[/i] outside of reach. Killers can literally put Survivors in time-out on hooks or on the floor.

The better one side is at this, the more painful the experience is for the other. Most games work like this as it's obviously not fun to lose. But because Dead by Daylight revolves around non-interactivity, losing feels indescribably miserable. If Survivors are decently better than the Killer, the Killer will spend a majority of the game running around and accomplishing nothing, rarely/never able to get hits as they are taunted and made fun of. If the Killer is decently better than the Survivors, the Survivors will accomplish nothing and be repeatedly forced to sit on the floor or a meathook doing absolutely nothing, sometimes facecamped, etc. There is almost never a balanced match, so one of these two options will inevitably take place. You are either the side having fun, or you're not. Most likely, you're not. Losing feels overwhelmingly hopeless.

The icing on the cake is that sometimes each side can lose despite doing nothing wrong. Survivors can lose because the Killer brought overpowered addons (upgrades), Killer is playing a high-tier Killer, their teammates are bad, etc. Killers can lose because the Survivors brought overpowered items/addons, the Survivors are coordinated and can safely camp every pallet, the Killer they're playing is low-tier, etc. Both can lose due to bad map generation or just plain ol' bad luck.

The developers are also infamously out of touch with the community. Simple changes can take literal YEARS to release, and decisions will consistently be made that are direct opposites of community consensus. It's almost impressive how horrible their decisions can be sometimes. Content releases are also quantity over quality, often leaving players disappointed and every release a total buggy mess.

The game is also balanced around good behavior. Killers are expected to not do certain things such as "tunnel" (kill one Survivor as fast as possible, ignoring others). There are also other, personal unspoken rules that each Survivor expects Killers to follow and may vary. For some reason, Survivors do not have a similar expectation. The "rulebook" means that most games, many of the Survivors have unrealistic expectations for matches, as the average Killer may not be aware of the rules or choose not to follow them. This frustrates a lot of players, adding to the endless cycle of being pissed off and taking it on other people (the only reason to follow [i]any[/i] of the 'rules' is to be nice - most of them are self-imposed handicaps, so obviously most players ignore them).

Everything about the game is just completely and utterly miserable. But...

[b]Sometimes It's Fun[/b]

When the game is fun, it's [b]really[/b] fun. The lows in the game may be really low, but the highs are equally as high.

It's very addicting. Frankly, the fun matches are nowhere near as common as the miserable ones. But the fun games were so fun that it doesn't matter. You will want to keep playing anyways to chase that high.

Please just don't bother. If you get into it I promise you will regret it.

It is excruciatingly frustrating and every player is chasing a high. Everyone is an asshole that is taking out their frustrations on others. Nearly every match is misery.

I beg you not to play. Playing this game frequently is suicide to your mental health. Everyone is always feeling terrible and frustrated and trying to drag down others. Terrible feeling to surround yourself with. Avoid it.

The love hate relationship I have with this game is immense. 

At the time of this review I have over 2500 hours playing as solo survivor. Around 1000 hours playing as killer.

This game could be fun, but there are too many people who get into this game that have no respect for the spirit of asymmetric games or party games. I would love to be able to just blame players, but this is the sole fault of the developers. 

They have the data, they have the stats but they refuse to get it. This game will never be balanced, its too late. In an effort to get more franchises they have destroyed the main game play mechanics. 2017-2019 was the golden age of the this game.  Why? Because at that point in time what made the game fun for the majority of players existed, not in a vacuum but on display as its main component. Now its gone. They've run out of ideas and instead of making new game modes to incorporate the new franchises they want to add they've just made it a lopsided unfun boring press W or hold m1 for almost every match now. This goes for both sides.

There are several things that became the downfall of this game. 2 I will mention. I think the most important one was adding survive with friends. Survive with friends made an already mildly toxic game experience exponentially worse. 4 man survivor is beyond easy, its actually pathetic its allowed. This game experience is shared by every killer, you get into a match and you get stomped and you get an assortment of bad mannered players harassing you at the end. The next match you go in and decimate all the survivors who don't say a word, but you pop off. Now you've become the toxic one. 

The next one, was after its lead developer lost a match being live streamed he lost the plot. He fell into a black abyss and kept ramping up killer powers. Which was fine, but in the process a lot of the game development was obviously based on a retributive streak instead of a balanced perspective. (If you ever wonder why nurse hasn't changed and is still as over powered this is it)

This can't be a competitive experience, but alas 7 years in the developers still can't make it clear. 

Playing survivor used to be fun, because it was teetering on the edge of being too difficult.
Killer used to be fun, because it was teetering on the edge of being too difficult.

Now, survivor is unfun, boring, repetitive and lackluster experience where the match you play is impossible or beyond easy.

Now, Killer is unfun, boring, repetitive and lackluster experience where the match you play is impossible or beyond easy.

I can't for my life fathom a new player installing this game and not just uninstalling it after a few hours. The amount of dedication it takes to understand the ins and out at this point is a toll. With hundreds of perks (mostly useless) and dozens of killers and survivors its a daunting task just to learn what the hell is going on. 

I will continue to play because I hope for its future, but I can't recommend anyone else at this point.

Edit 2024.01.16:
Ok seriously. If anyone see my review, here's why this game STILL has problems. Today I will be sharing the incredibly unethical and fun that I used to play the game as a survivor.
Here's the thing. Matchmaking now seem to work depending on how much you survive. (Used to be the pip.) So what if you just intentionally die (previously de-pip)? All you need to do is to keep a mindset of your happiness from a match as a survivor is not depending on survival or not.
Here's how I played. I used "Plunderer's Instinct", "Balanced Landing" and "Quick and Quiet". I never use "Sprint Burst". I chose off-meta (and probably still off-meta) perks only. I racked up hundreds of items from the chests, and able to survive chase from killers from unexpected sprint after falling, or hiding in a locker.
The most important part of this strat is to control your MMR or pip. For instance, previously, since I do not want to pip, I will intentionally give up on some score earning categories. This may include objective and altruism. Yes, you read it right. I can intentionally let every other survivor die so I can use the hatch. Since now the MMR is based on survival, you can simply max out all objectives and die at the end, there's only 5000 BP difference. You can get matched with less skilled killer over and over, repeat.

Edit 2018.01.09:
Almost 1.5 years since I wrote the review, and 70% of my original content was still relevant:

Original Review: 
No team score system, which discourages pub survivors from cooperation.
People can disconnect to prevent rank loss. (Force quit the game)
People can disconnect to prevent others gaining points. (Killer get ~2000 for each DC, far less than killing them in the normal way). DC'd killer will let survivor gain no points.
Saves can be modified and will not be detected as cheat.

Honestly, you either play with beginners or people who have thousands of hours and treat this like a life or death tournament. The game can be fun if you stick with it and get decent but then you have the devs who nerf or buff things at random just because they enjoy tinkering, is this better than the beginning of the game's inception where it took years to change gamebreaking mechanics? Not sure, but if you stick with this game you will definitely be developing some kind of stockholm syndrome and refuse to leave your abuser. The temporary ban system is really weird. There are ways to get permabanned (cheating, griefing constantly, probably some other shit) but, the way to get a short ban is to disconnect from the game. You can usually do this by pressing the menu button and choosing to "leave the match" which will create a short ban. It starts with 1 min, the next  is 5 min, then jumps up to 15 min. I had never reached this point til recently as I have been having blackouts from the recent freezing ass weather that is currently happening where I live. Just got the 30 min ban time within 3 days and I'm not even sure I'm going to try to log back in today. 
I'm not going to stop playing this game because I am very addicted to it, but when something out of your control happens and they basically go: Fuck you, you can wait now. Make it a 5 min ban tops or at least reset the disconnect ban every 24 hours, because this shit is ridiculous.
Don't get me wrong, I can still enjoy the game too but the level of toxicity this community has and can also bring out in you is CRAZY

if you've seen gameplay online and thought it looked boring well you're right! watching gameplay is boring unless you like *insert popular person here*

the real enjoyment comes from actually playing this game, the unexpected, the sense of being alone and all of a sudden you hear your heartbeat raise and know that you're being hunted, that's the game at its core for anyone new jumping in.

the killer might be something you enjoy, knowing inside that you're making people freak out and panic if you enjoy that sort of thing.

on the complete other side of the spectrum you have the OP guys that have been playing for years, they circle objects like a game of cat and mouse and hope that their team is doing a generator in that time, which honestly we probably aren't since we are still trying to find the generator, you might meet one of these people every few games and will probably get carried in these games. (if you are one of these OP people thank you for carrying my ass more than once since I know I suck)

overall this is a pretty fun game but burnout can happen fast, like really fast, but I only play as the survivor since I like the thrill of the unknown.

the DLCs are pretty fun, I haven't personally brought them but I've gifted the entire thing to people over the years since they get pretty hardcore addicted to this game, the range of killers you see and their abilities are wild, if you haven't watched gameplay and just dive into it without knowing you'll have a really good experience playing against them, I enjoyed the ring woman (can't remember her name right now).

while I'm more of a single-player Factorio/Zachtronics sort of person this is one of the few games I enjoy to change things up, you do have a chatbox in the lobby but I'm not sure if there is VoIP since if there was I probably automatically disabled it out of habit. cheating in this game isn't common, I haven't played long enough to see a speedhacker or something but I'm sure they probably do exist but compared to stuff like Tarkov it is non-existent. 

if what I described is something you might enjoy then I'd say give it a go, otherwise, save your money, maybe it's a game you'll enjoy in the future when you're craving something different.

I just don't get it...
Like, the game is pretty fun, But I would NOT say this game is "putting a full-time job's worth of hours in a week into a video game" type of fun.
I see some of the playtime hours that some people have for this game and it baffles me that people could spend that much time playing the same type of game over and over again.
I guess to each their own but, I mean I guess it's no different than any other multiplayer experience to some degree. But all you're doing is either going around and fixing generators to leave or killing the survivors, and that's the game...
Whereas other multiplayer games that I tend to enjoy have a lot more variety. Like capture the flag, kill enough of the enemy forces, King of the Hill, deliver the payload, etc etc.
Nope, for Dead by Daylight, at least from what I've played through so far, it's just the same thing every time. And yet people rack up over thousands of hours playing it, like HOW.
I guess some of the licensed characters of different horror icons being playable is also a defining factor on why it's so popular, but by the end of the day their licensed characters. It would surprise me that there's a time limit on all of them being available and as soon as their time on the game expires it'll leave DBD as a empty husk now that it has introduced all these different characters, not to mention the microchansactions for every character. My god.
Without getting too much into detail, I have seen second-handed that this game can mess with people's schedules to the point where it feels like they're playing it as an addiction.
Maybe I'm missing something, I don't know. Like I said, the game is fun in its own right, but probably more so in short bursts. 
I do not see this as a game that is worth spending more than one or two hours a day playing, Let alone spending over 40 to 50 hours a week giving some people's play time spanning into the quadruple digits so quickly from what I have observed.
Play responsibly my friends, especially if you have responsibilities to take care of.

This is honestly one of my favorite multiplayer games ever, as I am big horror junkie. It's so cool seeing so many familiar faces and of course new ones, together in a game. The game itself is a huge loveletter to the horror community, wether you like a specific monster or a survivor from a franchise the game will probably have you covert. I like playing as a survivor and most of my playing hours are spent playing as such, but sometimes a few rounds as killer are refreshing as well. The game can be hard to master because of all the differnt killers and perks, but if you have patience this won't be a problem for you. Also the game can feel like playing a "lottery" at times, sometimes you will have the time of your life and at other times you will be feeling very frustrated. But you won't have to worry about the frustration if you remember that this is just a game and try to have a positive attitude. Wich brings me to the community of this game, probably one of the worst parts of this game. There will be times people will go willingly out of their way to make you feel bad and even write some completly horrendous stuff in end game chat. Luckilly there is a option to "turn off" the end game chat if you press the chat symbol. Alltogether a solid game if you're up for it's high learning curve and manage to respect other players that are just trying to play the same fun game as you. Patience and a positive mindset are the key. Keep in mind that buying the base game can be boring, due to many fun perks being locked behind DLC paywalls, the original characters can be unlocked by playing the game and gathering a in game currency called iridescent shards, however this curreny will take a lot of playing hours gathering enough to buy a single charcter. The other licensed killers and survivor will only be available by spending real money on the DLC pack or spending auric cells (wich have to bought via real money as well).
Personally I would recommend you to wait until there is a discount on steam, so you can pick up some DLC packs for just a couple of euros/whatever currency you use. Hope to see you in the fog soon!

I have seen this game develop through 6 years. I regularly play it with my friends irl and have met some great friends through this game. 3500 hrs (Including some on console) on this game and still playing there's not much more to say than that. It has so much replay-ability to me. Each game feels different because it can go so many ways, so it never gets repetitive to me like some other people say it does. 

My wishes for this game: 
*I would appreciated a few other game mode options where the ratios of asymmetry or the goal is different. 
*As of today (1/15/23)- I would like to see killers ability to hard tunnel from hook or proxy camp completely removed from the game, even if that means you are unable to wear the same cosmetic combo as another survivor - that would increase my enjoyment of this game 10 fold. 
*I would also like to add that I would appreciate alternative objectives (maybe specialized to each unique map). 
*Only licensed killers from here on out would be my preference, I feel that we have plenty of killers and survivors at this point and plenty of perks, the only thing that would add excitement to this game for me in this regard is to get some licenses that I value (IT, Jeepers Creepers, Predator) 
*I also feel that at this many hours in the game there's not much horror aspect to it for me anymore except when I get the jump scares from a scratch-mirror-Myers, Ghost-face, or Hag TP. I feel that a good portion of it being horrifying is how immersed in anticipation of getting hunted down or snuck up on I can feel. Any effort to make this game spookier would be delightful to me.
*Lastly, I would additional Stranger Things DLC -this time with Billy and Eleven or Robin as survivors (or at least skins) and Vecna as the new killer. I would love Vecna's house with an alternate upside down reality you can get to via portal like the Halloween event as a map.

A game that is CAPABLE of being absolutely amazing! But with that, it brings glaring issues which can also understandably ruin the experience for most people. Below this, I shall list a few things that may determine if you will / will not enjoy the game!


HORROR FRANCHISE FAN: If you yourself are someone that is or has been a fan of horror franchises, either in gaming or in film, there is a good chance you will very much enjoy this game. Being able to immerse yourself as your favorite antagonist when playing killer is such an incredible experience, and the same goes for playing your favorite protagonists. Actively playing a game where you're able to pick and play your favorite character from a media that either never existed as a game, or never existed in a multiplayer format such as this, is and will always be an amazing experience. 

COMPETITIVE: This game is inherently incredibly competitive. Having to work together as a group of four players to combat a single player that is capable of killing you with complete ease, means that this whole game revolves around competition. The same goes for killer too, of course. Playing as a single person that has to deal with four people actively working to cause your downfall, and having to manage so many different objectives at once to prevent them from winning, is stressful as shit. If you are able to put up with stress and competition without getting overwhelmed, then you'll be able to enjoy this game!

TOXICITY BANDWIDTH / SENSITIVITY: The community for this game is lopsidedly toxic. 40% of the time you will either encounter players seeking to have fun with everyone involved, or are simply quiet and focusing on playing the game without any worries. That other 60% however is filled with a bundle of players that either take everything personally despite this simply being a game, or seek to go out of their way to harass, belittle, and be horrible to whoever is opposing them. Killers and Survivors both have a tendency of taking this game far too personally, or forgetting that there are real people behind the characters they're facing. Survivors taking glee in creating as miserable of an experience as possible for the killers by forming groups of harassing players that seek to only make the killer feel like shit instead of playing the game as intended, or feeling as if the killer trying to play the game and win, is a horrible person for doing so, and deserves to be ridiculed for such things. On the opposite side of it, Killers have a tendency of viewing survivors attempting to survive, avoid and play their part of the game, as personally provoking or annoying, causing them to stop playing the game as intended, and instead playing as if they have to prove a point of dealing with someone that has wronged them. This creates a community wide toxic mindset of 'us vs them' when it comes to Killers vs Survivors. If you are capable of not taking this game personally or overly seriously, and playing as it was intended to be played, remembering that the goals on both sides are either to Kill everyone or to Escape unharmed, then you will enjoy the game! Kill them with kindness in return, maybe make people act better!

UNBALANCED GAME-PLAY: This game is incredibly unbalanced. Killers are able to bring one sided loadouts that are nie-impossible to beat and can slaughter everyone within a few short minutes, and players are able to stack up as a full organized team to simply, as previously mentioned, harass and torment the killer, with loadouts dedicated not to playing the game as intended, but to make the Killers life a living hell for as long as the survivors want to fuck with them. It is up to the players to create fun load-outs to use, and its up to them to not be menaces. If you are able to remember that this game will forever be unbalanced and that it never will be fair, and still can have fun with that, you will have fun!

COMMITMENT TO GRIND: This games leveling, prestige, bloodweb and perk system, is immense and tedious in nature. To fully experience the game you must prestige multiple characters, survivors and killers alike, to unlock their abilities and share among eachother. This will take a lot of time and dedication, which some people simply do not have. If you are able to be fine with spending a lot of time playing to finally begin snowballing progression, then you will have fun! This is not a game that you can play for a little bit and get the full experience out of. It requires a lot of dedication!




TLDR: Unbalanced game with a horribly toxic community that is grind heavy and incredibly competitive, but is perfect for people that do not take things personally, can ignore people that take games too seriously, and just want to play to have fun. Heavy bonus points if you are a fan of horror franchises! This game is a 7/10.

To add for reference, I also have 1600 hours on XBOX:

I first began playing around the time when Freddy was the newest addition to DBD. The game is simple enough, as survivor you work together to complete generators and escape the match while as killer you kill the survivors. After that, the game becomes complex with the massive list of perks and killer powers and counters. Honestly it is overwhelming how much information is involved in this game. Highly recommend looking up youtube videos and sticking with the Free content until you develop a more solid understanding. Avoid the drama, ignore the salt, and when you start getting to mad at the game, take a break. Good luck in the fog!

I dunno why I took this long to write a review for this game. I love it, I think I might always love it even when the games are frustrating. For me, there's just nothing else that scratches the itch that Dead by Daylight does. I've made tons of friends, my stream has grown in the most positive way, and I can't wait to see what Behaviour does in the future. I know DBD gets a lot of hate from its own community, and the players can even get under my skin at times, but I think that's just all online games tbh.  I'm here for the long haul, the hold this game has on me is so strong.

Sadly I can't recommend this game, fun for the first few hours but then the terrible grind kicks in. I'm nearly 24 hours in and still haven't unlocked a single new character.
If you can handle a toxic player base and being forced to fork over your cash to get anything good, then maybe give it a shot. But for me I'll just stick to games that actually value my time.

Regardless of anything else, I'm going to rate based on the #1 criteria for me when it comes to a game, and that is "Do I feel in control." And in Dead by Daylight, yes. There has never been a situation where I have felt, whether playing either side of this asymmetrical game, that I was not in control of the result of the game. If I won, it felt like there was something I could have done differently. Same if I lost. This game is heartily recommended to me. 

That said, I do have to warn you about the community, which is the saltiest group of people ever seen outside of an 18th century sailing vessel. Now, when you have an asymmetrical game and there are regular complaints about devs favoring both sides of the game, that does probably mean that it's actually pretty well balanced. But man can these folks be annoying. If you want to play, use all the anonymizing things available. I may just be a salty 30-something playing a game for zoomers, but that doesn't mean they're not whiny. It just means that they have a perfectly good excuse, which is that they're a lot younger than me and less mature. 

Enjoy the game. Just not the community. But brilliantly made game.

DBD's fun, but I just feel like the devs fumble balancing it. Any "balances" they do implement to curb toxic behaviour etc. just promotes new issues (i.e. endgame camping with the disabled hook meters/edging the border), tweak maps in a negative way (i.e. Ormond rework/smaller maps in general), or nerf perks into the ground for often bs reasons (MFT explicitly). 

I'm not saying the devs aren't trying, it just FEELS like they don't listen to the community, and make changes that drastically hinder/support one side in particular during any major balance update.

On a separate note, some way to communicate in solo queue would be deeply appreciated. Maybe lessen the gap between solo players and SWF a bit? All these other team games have pings/ping wheels, so why can't we? The amount of times I've wished to be able to say/ping: "I'm going for the save/Leave without me/Open the gate(s)/Don't heal me (plot twist/resilience reasons etc.)/trapped or rigged gen/Stealth killer nearby" etc etc etc, is actually insane.

And to complain just a tad more (I am very skilled in it :3): the amount of insta-down powers/perks/addons for killers seems like a bit too much. This may just be my dumb*ss opinion, but I honestly feel like insta-downs should be earned and not just handed out like candy, and actually be worked for/require skill and timing. Especially concerning Bubba and Billy. They basically can keep up with running survivors and suffer little to no downtime between chainsaw swings. it just feels... wrong... 

Regardless, with what a headache the current meta has become, I just can't recommend this game in good conscience. Call me what you will, but the game needs a bit of tweaking, imo.
