I want to say that I enjoy playing this game, but even then that's a bit of a stretch sometimes. Yes the game can be fun when you're able to have fun with it, whether it be playing killer or survivor, BUT there are a lot of issues I've had getting back into it two months ago after not playing it for two years that were not present the first time I was playing.
For one, every match that I finish the 'Grade Progress' tab never shows the actual progress, always saying an error along the lines of 'Grade Progress Error, restarting the game should show your current grade' even though once I get back into the lobby my grade is updated anyways, and that's just something that's annoying. The OTHER major problem I have is that I am Physically Unable to play with other people after the first game upon startup, regardless of what I try to do to fix it, with it saying 'Connection to the party has been lost' with me being unable to invite anybody or join anybody. Everything I've tried does not work; Uninstalling and Reinstalling, Repairing the EAC, Verifying Integrity of Files, Verifying Integrity of Files and then manually installing EAC before opening the game. Nothing Works, and I cannot be asked to go thru the motions of the support tickets because as far as I know, this kind of issue is PERSON TO PERSON and DOES NOT HAPPEN FOR EVERYONE, and it should supposedly fix itself in due time, but in the past two months with there being at least 4 separate updates, there's been no change, in fact there's only been more bugs rather than less, but with as many interactions with however many killers, survivors, perks and add-ons I'm not surprised more bugs pop up after every update with how spaghetti the code of this game is, and I wouldn't be surprised if there are other people who have a similar issue with being unable to play with other people in this game.

Regardless of all the crap with the party issues and the game bugs, even after all that the game can get somewhat repetitive if you have no clear intent or goal put upon yourself, and the archive tomb challenges really help with that, but my only problem is that you can only choose one at a time, and if you have a really easy challenge that just takes a while to accumulate, you take however many games that is doing that one challenge instead of being able to have multiple on at once. But I digress, its not that game changing if you can select multiple at a time.
Not to mention that the amount of effort it takes to get every, single, character, whether its a survivor or a killer, it just takes so dang long to get one of them to prestige THREE, and this is after they changed how much bloodweb items cost.
Monthly grade rewards are helpful towards that, but its at best 2 million a month, which is enough for like, at best 2 prestiges on a single character. Maybe I'm just complaining too much, but I haven't even gotten started on the gameplay.

At least with the killer each power they have makes the games diverse enough to feel like they're unique, but almost all of them still revolve around the 'patrol generators, find survivors, if you don't get one of them within a minute, give up and go back to patrolling, find survivors, down someone, hook them, either patrol around the hook or go back to patrolling generators, etc. etc. and this isn't the same with all killers.
With survivors on the other hand...It's a lot more boring, since they all play the same after you unlock all the perks. Yes you can take chases and loop and all that jazz, but for the most part you still just sit on generators, either hide or run if the killer is nearby, if someone gets hooked you either go for them or assume someone else is going to *reminder I'm only able to play Solo Q so my opinions might be different than others, but i can't have other opinions because I'm physically unable to even play with others in a SWF* and then go back to doing generators and then once they're done open the gate and escape.
I'd be able to enjoy this game more if the game wasn't so repetitive on the survivor side and so stressful on the killer side, alongside the crap with the party issues and not being able to play with others. It won't stop me from trying to get all the achievements but I would be able to have more fun and enjoy it more if the issues were not there at all.

Great game! 10/10 would recommend to everyone. 

The killer side is fun, great hunting vibes and can be challenging when running against a coordinated team with effective communication. A great way to vent pent up frustration from a rough day.

The survivor side is also fun. I quite enjoy the stealth aspect of it where being sneaky and stealthy often is the determining factor for whether or not you survive a match.

There is quite a learning curve for survivor side, and killer side too, but the steeper learning curve is definitely survivor side. But once you actually have an idea for what you're doing, it makes for some pretty intense and enjoyable game play on both sides.

This game is rife with cheaters and hacks and BHVR just tries to hide shit instead of fix it.  They're also incredibly shit at balance, and the game is heavily tilted in favor of one side over the other.  The community is extremely toxic, generally.  It's entirely designed in UE4 Blueprints (think RPGMaker for FPS) making it one of worst optimized games I've ever played.

If not for these things, the game would be much better than it is.

EDIT: I also forgot, some of the worst matchmaking imaginable - brand new players against hardened vets is the norm.

There are also absolutely no assistive technologies such as for color blindness or hearing issues.  There isn't even a Brightness or Gamma slider in a HORROR GAME.

EDIT2:  The progression system is unmitigated endless grind, you cannot use perks you paid for in DLC without grinding a million hours worth of blood points first.  To actually max an account takes 1.5 BILLION bloodpoints, a perfect game, as a killer which gets the most, is 32k.  People with 8,000 hours don't have everything.

This is actually a bad Korean F2P game in quality, grind, and monetization.  Their devs and forum moderators are some of the thinnest skinned woke PC garbage to ever walk the Earth.

They also have the most anti-consumer "battle pass" style system I've ever seen - even if you play at the highest level and play this game as a full time job it's designed for you to spend extra cash on getting tier unlocks because grinding them is impossible.  There are many posts you an find about the math.

This is going to be very long. I bought the game on PC when cross-progression got leaked just for it to be debunked a month later so thats why I have like 1 hour on this game. So there is no point on playing PC for me since everything I own is on console. So this is my current thoughts on the game. I have around 700 hours on Xbox and since the Knight chapter, Behaviour could not give a dam about anything besides sales. I originally got the game when the Resident evil chapter came out because I thought it was awesome that Nemesis and Jill were playable in a different video game. I had so much fun on the game during 2021 and half of 2022 then it all went downward. Behaviour is way too slow at balancing the game for a "live service" one and let killers/perks be broken for months, or forever like nurse and blight. The devs just want your money now and it's really sad because they capitalize on these big licenses to basically be a Fortnite of horror. Otzdarva's video on the devs not listening shows how much they only care about the competitive community. The devs cannot find a balance for the casuals and sweats which can be tough for almost any game, but 80% of the feedback is ignored anyways. The devs have really slowed down on the balance and health of this game for all these big chapters and let the game stay buggy and have all of the server issues. It's really sad as these guys used to be loved and praised by the community but now their goal is just to maximize revenue. My biggest issue and the reason why I would never recommend this game to anyone anymore is the toxicity. This game doesn't even have voice chat and is still more toxic than even competitive FPS games like Valorant or CSGO. Tunneling has been in the game since year one and they just accepted it now (for new people reading tunneling is where the killer targets one person out of the game first by ignoring other players). Most DBD players will tell you to just not play if you don't like it then don't play survivor or the game in general which is what I have been doing. Or it isn't the killers job to make the game fun for you. These are both valid but if you really ponder, aren't games SUPPOSED to be fun? Why does DBD allow this exception for a player to instantly just get removed from the game. They can queue for a new one but most people play survivor with friends because of solo queue which I will get into later. Now for the killer side: sweaty survivors just make the game unplayable. There will be times where you get into a game with a 4 stack and this becomes very common if you are good at killer. That 4 stack will just play rude, tea-bag you, gen rush you, and then send you messages after the game saying how bad you were. Now the argument for this is that every game has toxicity. Very true but what people fail to realize is that the MMR system is extremely flawed and the devs have done a horrible job on it. Too commonly you will be unmatched into an unfair game. This issue results in the bad balancing by nerfing survivor constantly and just buffing killers over and over again. But when you buff them over and over then the casuals now have to deal with overdrive billy and no recoil trickster. Especially stealth killers which make it extremely hard for new players. The last thing I want to address is solo queue because if you don't have a 4 stack on survivor, then your random teammates will have no coordination with you. This also results to survivors commonly giving up first hook or sabotaging the team. The game basically requires you to 4 stack if you want a even chance which leads to another issue; the sweat stacks for killers. You starting to see how all these issues connect? Now I want to wrap this off with my final point being this game is NOT new player friendly. To any new players who are still reading this, if you are getting the game get ready for a ton of toxicity, a large unnecessary skill gap that the devs forced to help the competitive community, and to not have fun a lot of times you are playing. This game is built on the foundation of you being ready to endure the toxicity and be willing to learn all of these complicated techs, perks, killers, and maps or you buying it for a licensed horror character you like to play for about a week and just forget the game even exists. You have the choice to play any way you want but the results that will come depending on how you play is my warning. If you get easily angered, are in it to win it, and want to loop the killer forever/destroy the survivors you probably shouldn't play this game unless you want to dedicate yourself to being apart of the community. If you are more passive, want to get scared, play this game for fun, can handle toxicity, and don't mind loosing ALOT then this game is probably better for you but the truth is, not a lot of people are like that and they want to enjoy an even balance between winning and loosing. So primarily I would not recommend getting into this community and being an active player. But the choice is totally yours in the end. I hope this review helped you at least a little but currently the game has a lot of flaws not being fixed and that's why I'm not going to recommend it.

The TLDR version is: BHVR bluntly dont give a rats behind about this game. There are bugs & glitches galore with this game, this game is more unpolished than my kitchen floor yet instead of fixing the bugs and the issues, the core fundamental issues with the game, they want to add MORE stuff to the game which ultimately means even more bugs & glitches + their customer service is non-existent.

After 8000 hours in this game (whether mostly survivor or not is irrelevant) I can safely say without a doubt this game is NOT worth full price. They care more for making money than making a good game which is deeply saddening. The game is HORRIFICALLY unbalanced. Was back in 2016, and still is now. While I admit i started playing in 2018 even I felt like the game was quite heavily survivor sided and even more so to this present day. Back then there was some semblance of decency to this game & you could enjoy it. But the player base is by FAR the most toxic I've ever experienced, even more so than Rust! There are even people who will go as far as to call you a..... child liker, to use an expression. A malicious attempt to destroy peoples credibility and lives potentially. I have one person who harasses me with these false accusations myself.

As said the game is HEAVILY unbalanced & in favour of the survivors, but high MMR is nothing but meta on BOTH sides. Skill Based Match Making was the biggest mistake, followed closely by cross play. BHVR keep pushing this as a COMPETITIVE game, when the game is almost WHOLLY a party game. The games are filled with people that just want to be really unpleasant, whether its constant toxicity from survivors to killers, or killers willing to grief you, 4 minute slug you or constantly hit you on hook. I've been maliciously targeted by MANY of these "Griefers" as survivor and unpleasant people and its made my gaming experience from September 2021 to Jan 2024 (time I've quit the game out of respect for myself) an ABSOLUTE NIGHTMARE AND MISERY. Their customer service is also downright disgraceful, when I report griefers, or hackers, nothing gets done. One griefer who I wont name has targeted me across 17 out of 18 games across the span of a couple of months, I have provided MULTIPLE videos of evidence of them griefing me and BHVR has done NOTHING.

Occasionally there can be some nice fun games in this, and when you have wholesome moments in DBD and meme times in this game they are usually some of the best you'll ever have, but are too few and far between for me to justify giving a recommendation here, and the fact there are SO MANY bugs and glitches, and quite a few hackers too which BHVR either wilfully ignores or just plainly cant be bothered to fix it further validates the latter point.

All and all this game has the potential to be 10/10 quality, but the developers legit just throw it all away with their corporate greed before game polish approach, and the lack of caring for the DBD community is inconceivable. Sadly I can only give it a 2/10. I CANNOT forgive the companies poor ethics, lack of care for the game, the disgraceful customer service I've had, and the incompetence in a lot of other areas as well.

-I have played for about 1K+ hours on PS4, and some time on PC, so I'm at least familiar with the game.
-It is a grindy game if you plan on trying to become more successful in-game; with a steep learning curve. I recommend researching what perks to unlock first; from what killers, so you don't waste as many bloodpoints when you begin. 
-DLC characters aren't a MUST; but it will help immensely, even just 1-2 DLC ( w/ characters/killers) is beneficial and enough to get you semi-started.
-Killer is the way to go for bloodpoints; but it can be frustrating as the matchmaking system isn't perfect and you're often paired against survivors that are MUCH more experienced in the game (but this isn't EVERY game) (And a lobby while playing as Killer CAN take a bit to find)
-Survivors matchmaking isn't much better and in the beginning your teammates will probably be potatoes. Playing with friends will make it easier, especially when it comes to communication. 
-Can be a fun, yet frustrating game.

Ignore the talk about the toxic community (Yes a lot of people complain about how the killer/survivor plays) the game is genuinely extremely fun. If you're a horror fan this is essentially the super smash bros of horror. 

The main negatives for new players would be the fact this game can be pay to win as various top level perks are only obtained with killers/survivors that you need to purchase with real money. They have measures to help with this slightly with a method of purchasing perks with in game currency you earn but it still takes a long time to get these perks plus they're randomised each week. 

You also have issues with how long it takes to level up and prestige survivors and killers. In order to unlock perks you have to level up your characters with a thing called bloodpoints. You earn these after each game sadly it takes a lot of Bloodpoints to prestige a character and the only way you can use perks from one killer/survivor to another is by maxing that character. Considering how many characters there are in this game means this game is very grindy. 

Even with those two big negatives not to mention plenty of other flaws with the game, the game is massively engaging and super addictive. Give it a chance, I hated it at first due to not understanding it and thinking it was just a boring gen simulator but it's much more than that.

[strike] It's odd, when I started playing this game in 2019, I wasn't having that much fun. Of course it was nice with friends, but I found playing killer to be frustrating (esp as a pig main, what a year), and solo queuing survivor wasn't much better either.

So I stopped playing DbD completely a few months later, until this November, 2023. I have been loving it? I don't know what they did at BHVR while I was gone but they actually made the game fun. All the collabs are crazy too, Resident Evil? I get to play as Wesker? Jill? Sheva even? Silent Hill? Chucky? (Alien is actually what got me back into the game, it's one of my favorite movies.)
I actually got called OP playing as pig today too, was a new experience.
So yeah, give it a try. It's on sale for Christmas right now. Get the Ultimate edition for all the old non collab DLC; the Resident Evil bundle if you like Ada/Rebecca/Jill/Leon/Chris/Wesker/Nemesis/Carlos (also blight has a Birkin skin); get the Silent Hill edition not only for the Silent Hill DLC but some other old DLC too.
The monetization on cosmetics can be a bit much sometimes, but you can earn everything (slowly) with in game currency you get from leveling up. They're also handing out a good chunk of it for the holidays as well, so be on the look out for codes and stuff [/strike]

Revising this review because admittedly Behaviour has done an amazing job at balancing and fixing a lot of the games prior issues. On my previous review, I mentioned how maps were done poorly. They revised a lot of the maps to be a lot better balance wise, as well as fixing some of the bugs and pallet placements to make a more fluid experience for both sides. Perks still have metas and some balancing issues, however, I have seen much better reform and consistent nerfs/buffs for things that needed it. All in all, I would say the game feels fresh and after coming back 2 years later, I definitely don't see myself putting it down anytime soon.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Imagine: You and an associate are walking down the the street, looking for someone to mug. A frail, lonely passer-bye appears and you gut them for a tin of aspirin, $50 and some body pins. Turns out, a 15 year-old jackass saw the whole thing. Your pal wants to disembowel her, but you are against murdering children; however, the problem still presents itself. So what do you do? After some blunt force trauma to the head, and a quick stuffing into your car the way you put something in the fridge that won't fit and then quickly slam the door, you begin to take your newest victim to a place you feel more comfortable thinking. After some time, you and your bud compose an idea. More accurately, your psychopath of a friend does. "If she goes nuts, nobody will believe her when she says some guy got blown away right in the open!" Your response? :"yeah, and some totally normal girl will just drop their sanity at our beck-and-call. I think we're fucked unless we... u know-" "no" he responds calmly, cutting you off. "I know what will make anyone go nuts, trust me." After some real convincing from your pall, you make a questionable purchase on steam. The girl is locked in a room. food is fit in through a small mail slot. The windowless room gives no comfort to Christi, who plays the horror game Dead By Daylight by BHVR for 949.3 hours. Soon after, you make her write a steam review in order to gauge her sanity. She types.

She is imminently executed by your hand. It was a reaction to the words said. Like protecting a loved one from harm, you shoot.  You sigh, blood and lead mix with squashed brain and you step out of the cell. The new coffin-room in your friend's home lies soulless, but not empty. Though you conscience is non the heavier, you tremble at what the scraps of a lost mind had last spelled:

Very fun once you get into it. It has it's problems, but the devs have filled this game with love and care. Definitely give it a chance!

I can say this game is worth what you pay. However, my only advice to you is don't get involved with this game if you don't like challenges. This game will challenge your patience and problem solving skills. It will challenge your ability to think creatively when there isn't many options to choose from. If you have a positive mindset, you will love this game.

Don't be surprised by how tough the learning process is in the beginning. It will get easier if you treat this game as a learning opportunity and simply have fun with it.
I guess it's ok. Just don't expect your teammates to do anything productive

I wanted to say something about the game from a different side:

Many people may think that it is more enjoyable when played with friends. They may be right, but I was always alone and played with pleasure for hundreds of hours. 
Of course, playing as a single survivor has its difficulties. Sometimes, no matter how successfully you play, you can lose because of toxic players and being alone. And that really ruins your mood. But sometimes a complete stranger from somewhere in the world, thinks the same way you do and helps you survive. When this happens, the pleasure I get is priceless. 

This game has given me hundreds of hours of fun. It still continues to give. I met new people, had a lot of fun, sometimes laughed a lot, sometimes got angry, but it was definitely worth the money I paid. I strongly recommend it to everyone.

I have almost 30 hours on this game and I feel like I've given the game a fair enough chance, granted I mostly play survivor but regardless I can't say I had fun with the game. Honestly, I really did want to have a fun time with the game but I just can't. I won't say the game is bad because of the community being as toxic as it is but I certainly won't say it's not a problem. But it is a problem a lot other games have to deal with so I can't take away points for that.
Note that I did have this game gifted to me so technically it was free.

Now for my actual opinion! The game feels underwhelming and mostly boring at times. Yes, I did have some moments where I was invested but sadly those moments are rare and are short lived.
Now do keep in mind if you plan to get good at the game you have to understand how certain perks work, how killers work, layout of maps, etc. And of course all of that takes what? Time. Now the question is how can I invest my time into the game if I'm bored out of my mind? If I feel like that then how am I supposed to feel encouraged to devout my time into improving? 
Even still, I'll take the blame and say it's my fault because the game isn't for people like me but I can understand why people enjoy this game so do take this review with a grain of salt.

Really thought I could get back into this game but it gets really repetitive and boring REAL QUICK. 

If there is anything that bothers me, its the concept that Killers rely on hitting their prey with x weapon but if they MISS their target, their really isn't much of a delay to allow the victim to get away. Just finish animation and continue chase with a boost in speed. 

They get a speed boost for just about everything and if they got the set of META perks then good luck as survivor cus your chances of living are below 15%. 

Maybe its the map design or something else but in my last game, I managed to avoid a hit from the killer only to have him finish his animation and quickly catch up to me and hit me once and for all....Like that was my opening to escape but instead it just delayed the inevitable. Nice.

BUT the same could be said for the survivor in terms of having the META perks. 

Idk, I feel like this game requires players to cheese all the mechanics to some degree in order to escape and that honestly just sucks.

Something isn't right and I feel like their should be more ways to actually get away from a chase. The longer it goes on the faster the killers becomes and it's like the only way to get away is to literally zig-zag the killer into becoming an idiot and losing track which really isn't easy to do considering their barely any fog or "Darkness" or anything else besides a wooden plank to fall over in front of the killer. 

Shame, the concept looked good on paper but the execution was far from perfect. If the game made players rely on their keen senses rather than simply forcing players to get the META set of Perks then the game would have more 'Skill' involved with it. 

Either way, I am glad the game is dead and irrelevant. Too much META this and that with perks, it takes away from the overall experience.

Re-Writting Review: So I'm back now after not playing dbd for well over a month, and have a more focused view of why I can't give the game a good review and would like to make this review for less venting and more for people looking to buy this game.

So let's start with the good
- Alot of the mechanics are fun for some of the killers and survivor can be alot of fun as well
- Creative Cosmetics and *some* original characters
- A game that receives constant updates ( Which will also go to the bad )

Now to the bad, Whereas I do believe this game isn't a dead or grave game with no hope or reason to play, These reasons make it hard for me personally to enjoy it anymore.
- I normally wouldn't count this to the game itself but the community is toxic, beyond the point of many others and I put it on par with known toxic ones like COD. Why I am putting this here is because 1. It effects the social media end of this game which can get tiring 2. Because certain game mechanics since I started playing have always encouraged it
- Poorly Balanced. This goes to what I said about fresh updates, the devs are always quick to pump out a new DLC or Killer or Survivor or Cosmetic, rather they do this for money or genuinely think their brothel for poor balance of a game IS balanced, I don't know, But what I do know is 90% of the updates are nerfing things that don't need it, and buffing thing's that don't need it, and overall the constant adding of new perks has gotten ridiculous , you know how hard it is to learn as a new player what perks and killers are worth BUYING and spending time on when there's so many perks and half of them suck?
- Pay to Progress. Pretty much pay to win if you want a even somewhat fair chance, Prepare to spend roughly 300$ to get all the characters

So overall, if you can handle all these flaws, go gettem tiger, I suggest getting this game on sale and save the rest for your new characters.
If you wanting a competitive  game, I don't recommend, not because it lacks competition but it's so unbalanced and based off luck, it involves little skill and makes it dull.
If you want a silly game to goof off with friends and viewers? It can be pretty fun

So overall summary: It's unbalanced and a big money pit for mediocre game play that is only tolerable with friends and not to be viewed from a skill based competitive point of view. 4/9

I currently have almost 1.5K hours put into this game, hours full of enjoyment, resentment, lost of interest, pickyness and, especially: Frustration, I've never felt this way with a game to a point where I can't even describe how bad that frustration has gotten over the years, and It hasn't gotten better in any way ever since then, I'd dare to say that it has even gotten worse and worse, that I can safely say that the game has reached its lowest point yet.

When you see a community as bad as this one, whom insult who is basically their patriarch and voice of reason and wisdom (Otzdarva), and see the same Developers of the game ignoring him nonstop and his ideas to make the game a more enjoyable place, the SAME person who has basically given them most of their popularity, you can already imagine how bad it has gotten, new players leave immediately, and it is obvious why.

This game is no longer worth it, pick something better to interest yourself in, its future is looking as dry as ever, I started playing when this was somewhat of a small company itself, but right now it is comfortably sitting at 1.3K employees, doing absolutely nothing to help the game or its community, I can't even fathom how they can make nothing work, neither the directives at Behaviour, their Devs, or even their social workers when DBD Mobile has gotten so much stuff we've requested for years to no end, the last QnA made sure to show us where their real interests are in: And clearly developing the game in a healthy way Isn't in their plans, and won't be anytime soon.

I never had a bright hope for this game ever since the beginning, neither I thought the Devs were competent at any point or that it deserved all the popularity it got, but this is the point of no return, I'm sorry you had to go through all of that Otz, if you ever read this review, I'm truly sorry.

Er, mi scusi? The game that I paid for in more ways than one is telling me I cannot play the game with an offline status? Just great. Fine, I'll play along. So I do, then what?

This game might as well be a scam. It lures you in by showing you all these cool killers and survivors you can play as when in reality you only get a small percentage of those characters because guess fucking what ya gotta pay extra for all those other ones. Now, I don't get as worked up about microtransactions as other people as long as the price is reasonable and it doesn't give you a competitive advantage and if it does then there should be a way to earn it instead of spending money. While this isn't present with the licensed characters, which I completely understand, it is with the Dead by Daylight original characters. I would applaud them for this, until you take into consideration that the amount of grinding you would have to do to get every earnable killer, not even including survivors, is 620 hours! So let's say you actually have a life and responsibilities so you, reasonably, don't want to go through all that. Well fuck you because the cost to get every killer at the moment is $145 and $80 if you only account for the DBD originals. And sure, you could just not buy all of them but the game is designed for you to use perks belonging to the killers which you can only access after you buy them. These can be completely game-changing and it just throws any idea of the game not being pay to win out the window. So in short, duck you Behavior for somehow managing to be more of a greedy cesspool of desperation than fucking EA.

As a killer main with plenty of time sunk into survivor as well. Yes, this game has its flaws. Yes, the game has periods of TERRIBLE balance where survivors were disgustingly overpowered. Yes, the game has periods where the killers wield that same power. Yes, the game has a terribly rigid meta. And yes, this game is host to one of the most outright toxic communities in any game I've played. Hell, I'd go as far a necrotic.
Still, this game is a lot of fun. If you stop worrying about other people or winning the game and just... enjoy the storytelling told through the gameplay and eb and flow of each match, it's great fun! Run whatever goofy perks you want and stop giving a shit and you'll usually have a good time.

Game's probably in the best state it's been in since release, but devs fix shit at a snails pace and don't listen to the community. Many issues go ignored for way longer than is reasonable and at least in my opinion, it's reached an unacceptable level. On a more subjective note, killer designs have been pretty bad for at least a year, maybe more. Every killer past Blight (released September 2020) has ranged in design quality from "meh" to "downright horrible", with the notable exclusion of Albert Wesker in August of 2022, although Wesker has his own problems still. Overall I think the game could be fun for you and if you get it on sale and really want to try I won't say that's a bad idea, but I don't think it's worth putting time into a game where horrible balance issues go unaddressed for years, despite near 100% agreement by the community that a problem exists (*cough**cough* blight addons *cough**cough*).

I really do enjoy this game a ton. I love asymmetrical games and few come as close to how fun this game can be. There are complex mind games on both sides that take time to learn, but when you do it makes you feel proud of how good you can be. And while the community in the game can be very, VERY toxic, you'll meet a lot of people that will give you probably some of the coolest memories in gaming. I know I've met plenty of those type of people. But the game is just too toxic. It feels less like a game and more like a job sometimes. The matchmaking is terrible, bugs that make the game frustrating that are never fixed, a meta that requires you to spend money if you want to be at the top, and you will never go a day without seeing a cheater. The worst part to me is the developers. They just never seem to listen to player feedback. Ever. They seem like really nice people and I wish them the best, but if there is a toxic un-fun meta, give it at least 3 months before they even look into the issue. Listen, I've dealt with games they don't care about fun and developers that care more about money than gameplay (looking at you Blizzard) but I'd rather deal with jerk developers than someone that pretends to listen to me talk then pisses in my mouth mid sentence.

First of all, this game is fun. Its got a solid gameplay loop you can lose yourself in for hours at a time. It's by far still the best asymmetric multiplayer game out there. That being said, the game's updates is causing things to go downhill fast. Ever since the Knight was introduced the game has been steadily going downhill. Every new killer is more broken than the last and every new perk is more exploitable than the last. It feels like the survivors get nerfed every update and the killers get buffed every update. It is becoming essentially impossible to win as a survivor in public lobbies. Lately the generator placement has become abysmal with 4 (out of 7) generators able to spawn next to eachother. If you are thinking of playing this game alone as a survivor it's not worth buying, even if you become very skilled you will lose because the game is stacked against you. If the dev's finally get around to making the game playable again for survivors I'll change my review, but if you're seeing this, they haven't.

Pro's:
* One of the best asymmetrical multiplayer games on the market. (even though that might not be for too much longer)
* Great variety of killers, survivors and playstyles.
* Can be played in short bursts of 20-30 minutes.
* Extremely fun with friends. (Near impossible without)
* Fun events that happen frequently.

Cons:
* Survivors become worse every update.
* Killers become stronger every update.
* There's no way to counter many of the new killer's abilities. (Example: Skull merchant will punish the survivors for trying anything and can lock off large sections of the map causing you to essentially sacrifice yourself for precious seconds of generator time.)
* Because some killers are so broken nobody can play as them, because entire lobbies will quit as soon as they know they're playing against a broken killer.
* The devs only listen to influential content creators, which means that the casual player's voice is unheard. Which is why casual play is becoming more and more difficult.

[i]Disclaimer: I have 2.5K hours in this game - I previously played on Epic[/i]

[b]Asymmetry[/b]

Imagine that you are paired up with 3 other people in order to repair 5 generators so that you can open one of the two gates available to escape the area. While doing this there is a killer lurking in the shadows and patrolling the surrounding area looking for you. As they are getting closer there is music you hear - a musical theme that is getting ever louder as the killer is getting closer since you are in their so-called terror radius. The most exciting part is the final layer of this music which plays during the chase sequence.

You can stun the killer with pallets or flashlights but can never really defeat them. If a chase ensues you need to make sure it lasts the longest possible time so that your team mates have time to finish the reparation. When hit you gain adrenaline to run faster for a while but you leave pools of blood and also make a noise due to the wounds you have. You are an easier target now but you still need to press on. As the second hit comes crashing down you find yourself on the ground and the killer can pick you up and hook you. Your team mates now need to decide who will get to you and become a lifesaver risking to become the next victim. Every person must be hooked 3 times to perish. A creature with tentacles descends from the sky to take you elsewhere once and for all when this happens.

[b]A license haven[/b]

This is even more exciting if you love horror and are familiar with the many horror franchises out there with perhaps particular emphasis on the slasher genre. The killer can be Myers from Halloween or Ghostface from the Scream franchise. You can try to outrun the Xeno from the Alien or play hide-and-seek with Bubba from Texas Chainsaw Massacre. You can try to avoid Amanda from Saw to put beartraps on your head or reject the offer from Cenobite who has [i]such sights to show you[/i]. You can seek out alarm clocks to wake up from Freddy Krueger's nightmares or avoid Chucky because you don't want to be [i]friends 'til the end[/i].

But there's more! We have gaming licenses here, too. You can avoid the tentacles of Nemesis or Wesker's dashes - both of them set out to infect you during the match. Survivors can also be familiar to you from these licenses. It's fun hunting down Ripley with the Xeno or Cheryl with Pyramid Head. The game is not short of original licenses the creators came up with. There is a robot that can use pods to track you and teleport to start a chase and there is even a knight who sends out ghosts patrolling the area.

[b]More info on the gameplay[/b]

There are several maps out there and some are tied in with the licenses such as the Racoon City PD or the Nostromo Wreckage. Items can be taken to matches to help us with the speed of reparation or healing fellow survivors. Characters can be upgraded with the Blood Points we get (consider it the XP in this game) and each one can be prestiged after level 50. Both survivors and killers come with 3 unique abilities (perks) that can be unlocked for others if we do at least one prestiging. But you also have general perks available (not tied to characters) and it should be noted that everyone has 4 slots so you can create a lot of interesting builds since there are more than 70 characters (more than 30 on each side).

Now, the fun part is how you play from the 3rd person (as survivor) but the killer has a 1st person perspective. For killers the add-ons (2 slots) are not for items but modifiers that can enhance or change their powers. Each side can also take an offering to the match - this can be a request to play on a specific level or just something that gives a boost percentage to the BP earned.

Some killers are fast, others can teleport through walls, some can move stealthily and many require you to do other things during the match. You can disarm traps, use clocks to wake yourself up, cleanse yourself from infection or use either a vaccine or a spray to cure yourself from a virus. There is no built-in voice chat but you can only use a few gestures to give others orders. You have to pay attention to the left-hand side of the screen that shows what your fellow survivors are doing. You can see who is in a chase and you can always see the auras of those on a hook. 

[b]What if I'm a new player?[/b]

Prepare for a lot to learn. The game was released more than 7 years ago and a lot of content has been added. A small amount of characters are available but the rest must be purchased. For original characters a special currency (shards) can be earned so by playing a lot you can purchase a lot of characters and even many outfits. Now, this is a game that uses the [i]game as a service model[/i] approach. In every season we get new characters (there is a new chapter) and rifts open up for purchase which essentially means for a small fee we can receive a lot of cosmetics but only for specific characters. There is a lot of terminology for you to learn: you need to know what status effects there are and their meaning and many more. 

[b]Toxicity[/b]

This is why I'm downvoting this game. The playerbase is awful. After a match - regardless of the outcome - people say hurtful things to you. They consider you a cheater if you have won as a killer or your survivor friends look down on you if you did not play well and it was your gameplay that doomed the entire team. You can crouch repeatedly during a match to tea-bag the killer. The killers, in return, can camp / tunnel / slug that are all nasty (but efficient) tactics to win a match. Some offences you come across are simply not punishable. If you decide to report someone you need to 1) make a report in-game 2) submit a ticket on the developer's website and 3) upload video evidence as proof of the cheat, harassment or unsportsmanlike attitude you have come across.

The reporting system is very time consuming and - due to privacy reasons - you only get confirmation on when your ticket was actioned. Some players even upload a screenshot on their temporary bans as they consider it funny. Forums here on the Steam can be just as toxic - the official forum on the developer's website is much better but moderation is done regularly as it is a must.

The game's matchmaking system is broken - it is very easy to be paired with players that are thousands of hours ahead of you. With survivors climbing ranks it is especially difficult since you alone cannot win a match - you need the others but with lack of experience the so-called SoloQ experience can be painful. Killers can find matches difficult and sweaty just the same. Friends can team up and use voice communication (e.g. Discord) and have a coordinated match against the killer. Some of these SWF (Survive With Friends) groups tend to remain after the match and bully the 5th individual in the chat. The killer then will resort to slugging / camping etc. in the following match... it generates an unstoppable avalanche. Swearwords are common in the chat and "+rep" or "-rep" messages will quickly fill up your wall if your profile is public. 

[b]Summary[/b]

DbD is an amazing game. Running from killers as Nicolas Cage or Ash from Evil Dead can be pure fun. Opening the gate but heading back with 2 others to save the 4th individual who's struggling for their life on the hook can be one of the most memorable experiences in this game. There are some expert players out there (many also stream regularly) and the learning curve is there and it is very steep.

But the game has a lot of issues. New characters with their new perks always shake up the meta. The developers also make decisions that slightly alter the game mechanics. And there are killers such as Freddy in the roster that haven't been upgraded for years. I downvote DbD due to its community. This game requires a lot and I mean a LOT of patience to deal with toxicity. Who knows: you may get hooked (pun intended).

Edit 2: Another 500 hours into this game and somehow I am AMAZED by how quickly shit goes downhill with this game. The "power creep" of these newer killers gets worse and worse. They just mash multiple effects on top of one another and expect the game to be in a healthy state. On the survivor side of things though, the gen popping capability is so INSANE now that most killers will just play for a 3 gen from the start of the match. Multiple matches the server shut down because neither side was willing to give it up. The health of this game is bad at this point. Maps are getting too small, generator progress is too quick, even with the change to anti-camp it is has stopped nothing from getting tunneled out extremely quickly. But hey, they did a cross over with Ubisoft's R6 Siege....another broken dumpster fire of a game...so that says a lot

Edit: Now having played this game for years. I have to say that it is in an awful spot. Micro-transactions are the key focus of this game at this point. Cosmetics and Rift passes are more important than actual balancing. Every game as survivor is you facing the same 3 top tier killers every match and still getting facecamped or tunneled so you spend 5 minutes loading into a match to play for 2 minutes. The toxicity of this game is at an all time high. Survivors are just as bad as they go into to bully low tier killers and players. This game was fun at one point but has thus become a competitive breeding ground of small PP energy people competing to see who can ruin who's time better.

The game hasn't changed in like 8 years. Same gameplay loop since release, only new content is skins and characters. This is a cash grab. Developers don't listen to their fog whisperers (PR people/TTVs) when it comes to balancing and decision making. People keep returning anytime they shoot out a half-assed killer expansion, where all the money was put into marketing, so it's like feeding into the delusion that this game is "fun" and "replayable" when we've been repairing gens for 8 years. I think some technicians would probably be jealous of that experience. 

The engine they made physically can't add much more onto it (Like modes or complex game elements) without just remaking it entirely. It took them 8 years to even officially announce a new mode that they'd begin work on. 

They'll probably drop a 2.0 update or probably a 2nd game so they can trick the audience into buying the DLCs again. Completely speculatory on that, but we'll see.

well now to the rest. never have i played a game where the devs are so unambitious and lazy. it kind of disgusts me how there basically is a tier list with 2 killers having their own tiers. talking about 'changing up the meta' when these 2 also enjoy having good addons while other killers suffer from a horrendous choice of VIABLE addons. how is it even possible that the same shit dominates the game for years without any changes coming in the future? meanwhile theres a new feng min skin every week?

Used to be good. Game is full of hackers now at the mid to high ranks and Behaviour actively protects them by allowing them to hide their usernames so you can no longer submit proof of hacking. Some people think there aren't hackers, but that's because they don't get into high enough MMR to play against them.  Hackers usually win so they play at a higher tier of matchmaking. The hacks range from slight speed or aura reading hacks that are impossible to prove, to hackers that can fly and shoot oneshot hatchets or instantly pick themselves up or go underneath the map and take the game hostage. Your only way out is to DC but if you DC too many times you get banned from matchmaking and the ban gets longer and longer each time you DC.

If you don't believe me go watch Otzdarva's stream and you'll see hackers every day.  He encounters so many hackers that he is actually forced to play against them because his DC penalty is getting too high, and he only DCs against hackers. 

If you even bring up that hackers exist in the discord or forums or pretty much anywhere that Behaviour controls, they'll ban you for mentioning it.  They address the hacker problem by silencing everyone who acknowledges it and pretending it doesn't exist. We don't want new maps or new perks right now.  We want the anti-cheat fixed.

I'll say this is a great game. But the following is how I think the new players will react to the game. There's group A. These are the people who love this game soooo much even though the game has not been fair to them (hard to learn, difficult to master and getting used to the game) but still kept playing it regardless and got them spending hundreds of hours on it, and it ultimately made them become great and love the heck out of this game. And there's group B... These are the people that tried out the game, was too hard for them and gave up with only a couple of hours of gameplay. I think this game is divisive to players overall, but if this game sticks with you, it reaaally sticks with you. The game still feels unbalanced and unfair and frankly, I don't think it will ever be "fair". But regardless, I love this game. I recommend it, but I feel like you will either fall in group A or B.

I put 3,000 hours into this game. Not on steam, but a combination of Stadia, Xbox and Playstation. It's addictive and it's fun to play with friends once you have some hours under your belt and stop caring so much about hiding in corners to survive. Once you develop the knowhow to run bully squads against killers, it's a blast. With that said, there have been a number of changes. Namely, about 18 months ago(I'm guessing on the timeline) they suspended the penalty for disconnects(they wouldn't let you load into a game for a few minutes if you DC from one as a penalty). Ever since then, DC's have slowly grown. It has gotten so bad and so frequent that they had to create bots to take over for the players that DC, which is actually not a terrible idea. But something else we're seeing is teammates killing themselves to create a 3v1 scenario instead of a 4v1, which makes the game tremendously harder. Just to be clear: when I started playing 4 years ago this almost never happened. Once every few dozen matches you'd encounter this. Now, it's LITERALLY 30-50% of all matches played. On top of that, what they have gotten in the habit of doing, is releasing killers that are TOO STRONG. They do this to gain a large number of sales for the new killer, and then they nerf the killer making them more balanced. I'm all for a balanced killer, but it's awfully convenient that they run the PTB and rule the killer as perfectly balanced, but 2 weeks after the launch(once they've made a ton of money off of selling this too strong killer) now the killer is suddenly out of control and they nerf it. This is definitely a money grab. On top of that, they have a few maps that they haven't touched since release(years ago), yet they are updating onces that came out 1 year ago.

With all of that said, I clearly spent 3,000 hours on the game, and I think it's one of the best games I have ever played, but I will be taking a break from it. There is nothing new enough or fresh enough to keep me around, and I feel like the developers AND the community made some wrong turns that have encouraged play that is becoming increasingly detrimental to the experience of the game. I'll be back, but I'm gone for awhile.

[b] Dead by Daylight review + specs[/b]

This is a decent game and also not. It's fun when you're doing well, not so fun when you're not. It's fun when you're very new or have 6000h in the game. Not so much in the middle area though. There is only 1 game mode, where you can be either a killer or a survivor, basically every match consists of 4 survivors fixing 5 generators, then opening the exit gate to escape - with the killer trying to hang them on hooks and kill them. It can be fun at times, I've enjoyed it quite a bit - though it can feel VERY repetitive. Also, after reaching the highest rank on either Killer/Survivor (Or reached maximum prestige (level)), you don't really feel any point in playing in that position anymore - kinda annoying as I bought the ghostface DLC and barely ended up using it.

Additionally, a [b]huge[/b] problem with this game is matchmaking - matches are supposedly "MMR-reliant", but the devs' implementation of it is pretty terrible - someone with 15 mins in the game may be matched with a random number of people, with maybe 2000h as I've experienced many times. This, especially when playing killer, makes it annoying and not fun. As well as this, the community is a bit more toxic than average - they'll do anything to win: griefing camping killers and utility abusing torch survivors. This can be painful at the start but you get used to it and have to live with it, you can improve from it too. As well as this the player reporting system almost always requires you to go onto their website and report the same player AGAIN rather than just doing it in-game.

Yes, it's a fun game, but gets boring and repetitive, can become a money trap easily too.

The TLDR version is: BHVR bluntly dont give a rats behind about this game. There are bugs & glitches galore with this game, this game is more unpolished than my kitchen floor yet instead of fixing the bugs and the issues, the core fundamental issues with the game, they want to add MORE stuff to the game which ultimately means even more bugs & glitches.

After 7,000+ hours in this game (whether mostly survivor or not is irrelevant) I can safely say without a doubt this game is NOT worth full price. They care more for making money than making a good game which is deeply saddening. The game is HORRIFICALLY unbalanced. Was back in 2016, and still is now. While I admit i started playing in 2018 even I felt like the game was quite heavily survivor sided and even more so to this present day. Back then there was some semblance of decency to this game & you could enjoy it. But the player base is by FAR the most toxic I've ever experienced, even more so than Rust! There are even people who will go as far as to call you a..... child liker, to use an expression. A malicious attempt to destroy peoples credibility and lives potentially. I have one person who harasses me with these false accusations myself.

As said the game is HEAVILY unbalanced & in favour of the survivors, but high MMR is nothing but meta on BOTH sides. Or the games are filled with people that just want to be really unpleasant, whether its constant toxicity from survivors to killers, or killers willing to grief you, 4 minute slug you or constantly hit you on hook. I've been maliciously targeted by MANY of these "Griefers" as survivor and unpleasant people and its made my gaming experience from September 2021 to March 2023 an ABSOLUTE NIGHTMARE AND MISERY. Their customer service is also downright disgraceful, when I report griefers, or hackers, nothing gets done.

Occasionally there can be some nice fun games in this, and when you have wholesome moments in DBD and meme times in this game they are usually some of the best you'll ever have, but are too few and far between for me to justify giving a recommendation here, and the fact there are SO MANY bugs and glitches, and quite a few hackers too which BHVR either wilfully ignores or just plainly cant be bothered to fix it further validates the latter point.

All and all this game has the potential to be 10/10 quality, but the developers legit just throw it all away with their content before quality approach, their greed, and lack of caring for the DBD community. Sadly I can only give it a 2. I CANNOT forgive the companies poor ethics, lack of care for the game, and incompetence in a lot of other areas as well.

It's a great game for the first 300 hours but after that you'll start to see it's flaws and wonder why you didn't play a better game.

Just for context, I have played this game since the beginning in 2016. A majority of the my time has been as a killer main, where I've played all of the killers released so far to varying degrees. I have played a bit of survivor, but due to solo queue being a bit frustrating at times and not having many friends that play I avoid survivor for the most part.

Would I recommend Dead by Daylight as a great game? Yea I think the game is fun, even better with friends, but what really caught my attention was how different the game play is in comparison to basically any other game on the market. Essentially Dead by Daylight is, from an outsiders point of view, an asymmetrical horror game where one player is the "killer" and the other four are the survivors. The survivors objective is to repair generators to power the exit gates, opening them and escaping, while the killers entire goal is the prevent this from happening by downing survivors and placing them on the sacrificial hooks around the map. 

This is unfortunately only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the game, and one of the main reasons this game is so difficult for new players. When it comes down to it, this game is a in-depth time management game, where you must ensure you are being as efficient as possible with your actions and time to beat the other team. The Killer role feels this more so than survivor, but regardless you want to ensure your overall objective is progressing faster than the other sides whether that be hooking survivors or completing generators. 

The most entertaining and fun portion of the game is the chase. This happens when a killer locates a survivor and makes the decision to start chasing them. This ultimately dictates the flow of the game, as survivors who play things safe, utilize mind games, and waste the killers time to an appropriate degree put pressure on the killer as there will be 3 other survivors who "should" be applying time to the objectives. If a killer is great, understands the game, and knows when to drop chase to pressure other objectives instead of wasting their time chasing a survivor that understands how to waste your time, they can usually mitigate mistakes and quickly find the weak links on the other team.

Overall, if you are a new player, this game isn't easy. Honestly its very difficult and skill sets from other games don't really transfer over well so you will be starting from scratch. You will lose a lot, and probably get frustrated on what your doing wrong, but once you start understanding the game better and put more hours into it, its honestly come a long way and as of this review the game is probably more balanced than its ever been. Look to content creators like Otzdarva for guides and recommendations when your getting started and don't take the game too seriously. See you in the Fog!

I've been playing this game for a while now. Got it back in 2018 on my xbox and now play it on PC currently.
Overall the concept and design of the game is really good and it receives constant updates. 
I really enjoy this game as an asymmetrical horror because it is executed well. 
I think, especially as of recent, the developers could tweak a lot of things in this game to make it more balanced and fair, also I would like it if the devs were more transparent and listen to their community about this game as it would make the experience much better.
Overall I really enjoy this game and would very much suggest it to anyone who wants this game and/or think the game's concept is cool. 
If you like strategic thinking, scary/horror games, and/or fun/fast paced gameplay then this game is most likely for you.

Jan 1, 2024 Review:

My gripes from 2022 have largely been addressed by the devs. The game is the most balanced it has ever been (despite content creators insisting otherwise) and the last year of patches has been overwhelmingly positive. This game is worth playing currently and I have adjusted my recommendation accordingly. Please see my original two reviews below for additional information. 













______________________________________________________________

April 2022 Review:

My original review is at the bottom. The thoughts there are still true even after 2k hours. However, I am changing my recommendation to no because of the current state of the game (April 2022). 

Ever since the MMR update the game has changed dramatically. Every match feels precisely the same as the previous, only seeing a handful of the over 20 killer roster each match. Every game is an exercise in frustration, whether it be getting camped, getting tunneled, or seeing survivors just holding forward. Not running meta perks leads to "no fun allowed" scenarios, resulting in feeling forced to bring specific perks just to mitigate the risk of not being able to play the game.  

I have ZERO hope the devs will fix this fundamental flaw because of the history with balancing patches and feature introduction in this game. Instead of listening to feedback and adjusting things in a healthy way, the devs often double down on terrible fixes or nerfs that don't fix the fundamental issue with the things being adjusted. Whether this be perk changes, killer tweaks, you name it, the developers often miss the mark and would rather behave like children when the fans that love this game offer CONSTRUCTIVE criticism. I do not expect them to produce perfect patch after perfect patch but the current game lacks any kind a variety in builds (ironic considering there is over 100+ perks, over 20 killers, and dozens of maps in the game) and MMR has made every game a sweatfest of epic proportions.

I play this game because it is fun. The current product is everything but that and I cannot recommend jumping aboard this sinking ship. Proper competition may eventually reach the market but as of now this game is becoming a victim of its own success with no hope left in sight. 








______________________________________________________________

Original review:

I was hesitant to get this game at first because I couldn't quite understand what makes it so popular. Tried it for the first time on a free weekend and instantly fell in love. The game really captures the essence of being a hopeless survivor (when playing alone) or a brutal killer. Each killer has variety and a unique identity that defines them. Overall, this game is engaging and addicting, even if the community can be toxic at times.

Every killer in basically every match is either using Nowhere to Hide or Ultimate Weapon or even both which makes you scream and give away your position and the only thing to counter them is using Distorsion and/or Calm Spirit which take 2 perk slots from you instead of having actually good perks to either help you or your team to actually win the match.
Oh and also did I forgot to mention that generators are also close to one another just like hooks??? If you happen to repair generators in the perfect pattern so the killer will be left with 3 generators next to each other you are absolutely fxked.

- There are also some areas of some maps which have either 1 pallet or 1 window and dropping that pallet makes the whole entire area of the map completely useless and if you happen to have a generator there good luck trying to escape because there is no pallet or window near you to escape

Corpo BHVR keeps adding new overpriced skins, perks and characters which you have to buy with real money instead of balancing old ones, and the community is caustic but also unreasonably stupid. Just imagine looking up a political forum for discussion, except instead of people screeching back-and-forth about healthcare reform or something, it's about how your low-tier fun variety loadout is actually unbeatable homogenized S tier meta, and how 1 of the only 2 roles in the game is actually at an inherent disadvantage, so it's only fair for them to min-max with like $30 worth of DLC meta perks combined.

The game is balanced around every survivor having no voice/text chat at all, but there's a mode that lets you play with friends (which allows you to be in a voice call with them), thus allowing survivors to gain an unreasonable advantage while invalidating 40% of the loadout options based around coordination with people half-way across the map, meanwhile BHVR refuses to acknowledge the existence of voice calls outside the game by refusing to enable any form of mid-round text or voice chat for survivors playing with randoms.

55% of the killers in the game are "perk killers" who you just dump a bunch of grindy progression resources into for 1-2 of their perks to use on every character, since the actual killer is boring to play, or just does the same thing as a different killer, but worse. 35% are fun but badly underpowered. 10% of the killers are overpowered to the point that at higher ranks, you'll just see the same 5~ killers over and over, invalidating the whole point of having such a massive list of killers.

There are many other issues, and the last 70~ hours of me playing this game were filled with thoughts of "surely BHVR will fix one of the many 3 year old issues soon right?????". they won't. every update makes the game worse by adding more bugs or more shit you have to buy to keep up with the powercreep. There was a scandal in like 2017ish where one of the game's DIRECTORS tried to play an underpowered killer to prove a point about how they were balanced, and didn't manage to kill a single survivor. I go to the video today, i scroll down, what do i see? "[12 days ago] Thats why DBD became Killer sided that much"

Can't go through one thread devoted to this game without "BHVR makes the game survivor/killer sided, of course, survivor/killer mains won't admit it..." 
Oxford languages decribes a bigot as "a person who is obstinately or unreasonably attached to a belief, opinion, or faction, especially one who is prejudiced against or antagonistic toward a person or people on the basis of their membership of a particular group." At the risk of sounding like an asshole for even using the word "bigot" to begin with, 80% of this game's community are ignorant bigots drowning out any hope of a pleasant social interaction with someone not on your side of killer/survivor. The way the progression system works, instead of getting (as a made up example) 5 survivor perk points, and 5 killer perk points per round, you get 10 perk points, so you're encouraged to invest all your perk points into one role, therefore reducing the amount of people who equally play both roles. This game teaches you to hate people whose shoes you can't step into.

I've never really enjoyed playing arena style games, but started playing this after watching a friend and I am kind of hooked (no pun intended). I can't quite work out whether I prefer being a survivor or a killer, but either way it's an enjoyable experience that gets the heart racing a bit. As a total noob there is a lot to learn, but the learning curve seems to be a small one as I haven't really struggled as either role just yet. It's interesting to see how many streamers are playing it too, and they are always friendly if you pop into their chat after a match to say hello. I've made quite a few acquaintances through it already. If I have one criticism it is purely the amount of DLC's that I now want that will cost me even more ¬£¬£¬£ but really, that's just my own little FOMO thing on show.

Edited to add - the gameplay is very addictive and I regularly find myself saying "just one more match" only to play for several more hours. I genuinely never expected to have this much fun in the game at all. Also, who was I kidding? Killing people is way more fun! lol

Bought this game twice because I really enjoy hating it. Xbox 2000+ hours and 500+ on PC. In the past it was fun with so many interesting perk builds to try out, but after a while skill based matchmaking had it so I was against the same 3 people every day with the same exactly annoying perks. Since then, they have nerfed a lot of fun interesting perks on both sides because they were too overused and good, which I don't mind, but I do feel as though this game is passed its prime. They haven't released an interesting, viable, and unique killer with a different game loop since Deathslinger. I think this game is very unforgiving to new players, but fun once you get the hang of it. I'm certain Proxy chat would be a great addition to this game both for beginners and the sweats to add the experience of getting to meet your team. Regardless they continue to update survivor perks and Items to make it more fair, but the game is a 4v1, there is always going to be some unfairness if one team decides to play a certain way. I'd personally rather see the devs spend their time creating cool new unique content and perks that are all viable rather then spending time revising and ruining old perks due to complaints. Simply there's no way to really make both sides (Surv Mains and Killer Mains) content with perk patches and time would be better invested in more quality for new content. Id still recommend the game especially if you have friends to play it with, custom games are always hilarious, and running surv squad is always fun for atleast like maybe 2 games.

Personally, the first time I played this game I hated it. It was HARD dying a lot in the beginning, but once you get the hang of it the game play itself is so much fun! I play killer when solo and survivor with friends (occasionally solo as survivor w/randoms) They recently added bots for when people disconnect and they seem to be adjusting the bots because they have gotten better. There are some technical issues with the game where you have to go out and come back in sometimes - but it's not so bad that it makes me wanna rage quit.. but needs some fixing there (happens on occasion not often). I love being able to collect survivors/killers and costumes plus killer and survivor charms that you add to your characters for your own personalization. Many costumes take a while to save up for and many costumes cost irl money with auric cells in game. All in all though, this is a fun game and I have spent COUNTLESS hours playing it and it's even better with friends! I look forward to the future of this game and all it has to offer!

500 hours edit: what can I say. The game is really fun and takes a while to master both survivor and killer play styles. My Opinion

Dead By Daylight is a fun game that can be played solo or with friends. the game is split into 2 roles, survivors which are all fundamentally the same & killers which have unique abilities and play styles. each character will have 3 unique perks which can be taught to others once that character reaches level 50 and prestige's. this allows you to create fun and interesting perk combos. but the annoying thing i find with Dead By Daylight is you start with roughly 1/3 of the content at the start (under the assumption that you bought ultimate edition, if not you start with less) and at least 1/3 of the characters are licensed which means you NEED to spend real money to get them, with others characters being unlocked by collecting shards (which can take a LONG while. it is possible to get the perks of licensed characters for free in the "shrine of secrets" but from what I've seen so far, there's only 1 licensed perk per week so you could be waiting a while.

final thoughts

As fun as i find dead by daylight i can't deny the fact they push for pay 2 win. so if you do decide to get this game, get a feel for it first. dont spend money right away. there are still good characters on either side with killers having crowd control (trapper), range (huntress), speed (hillbilly & nurse) & stealth (wraith). and survivours having perks like sprint burst (extra speed) and dead hard (small window of invincibility). so get used to the game and try play with characters you have, you might find you like them and that can save you time and money. and sure you can spend your money how you want but i feel like you should only spend money on licensed dlc's, as everything else will be free after you play for long enough

Might be the first 0/10 I think I'd ever given something. The only enjoyment you'll get from this literal shovelware is the modicum of a sense of teamwork you'll get when playing with friends, from the abysmally unbalanced game design that obviously had 10 minutes of work put into it at most, to the intentionally obtuse and boring perk system that replaces actual depth with endless amounts of worthless crap that affects nothing to a point where it's noticeable.

The matchmaking times are ridiculous, even with a team of 4 survivors it'll still take at least 10 minutes to find a killer to play against, who'll cheese you and make the game impossible to win because of the aforementioned 10 minutes of game design that a monkey with a typewriter would be ashamed to shit out on a bad day.

Don't even think about wasting your money on this unless you have a large friend group with a lot of patience who just want a way to enjoy each others' company, if I didn't I would've refunded it (and any and all times I open this game again will be at their behest).

PS: It gets marginally more enjoyable once you realize how vapid and shallow the gameplay actually is, it just boils down to knowing things like how close you have to be to vault over obstacles etc, playing as a survivor is the only bit you can even pretend to enjoy because of how heavily biased it is in favor of playing killer, if, for whatever reason, you accidentally press the "Play As Killer" button, you'll feel absolutely nothing when you win and in the exceptionally rare times you somehow don't sacrifice all 4 survivors you'll feel like a moron (which might explain why the "people" who play killer for fun and not just when they have a +100% blood point bonus to slightly speed up the absolute grind that is getting new items are so sweaty and toxic), but it's still 0/10 movie tie-in shovelware whose target audience are unassuming boomers who recognize the characters and will play it once and then forget it exists. Spend your money on literally anything else because this is still the worst game I've ever played in my entire life.

PPS: if you bought Chucky I hope you got AIDS for Christmas

1000 hours in i can tell you this, all builds are fun and playable unless of course your ping is above 63ms. 
Got tancity, flip flop and power struggle? well guess what the pallet drops, doesn't stun the killer but a GHOST throws the pallet on top of them. 
Got lithe and resilience for fast vaults? guess what doesn't matter cause your ping is above 63ms. 
Getting camped but you don't have deliverance? DONT WORRY! You are either going to second stage before you can unhook yourself with anti-camp or die before you can. 
Getting tunnelled the entire match? DON'T WORRY! Off the record, DS totally don't get disabled in end game when it matters anyway. 
Just know if you manage to play well despite all of these things and are actually enjoying yourself, that you can't do too well in chase, because if you do the killer will get mad and target you until you die. You cannot run sabo builds, or you will get bled out because the killer gets mad. You cannot run chase perks, because the killer will get mad. You can't run gen rushing builds, because the killer gets mad. The only thing that is socially acceptable in this game is diversion of course, because throwing a rock to trick the killer after sitting in their terror radius for 4 years is fair and balanced. 
But what is fair, as killer of course, is surge, pain res, dead lock and pop. Very fair and balanced. Don't worry!

dbd is an interesting game. new content is added to this game constantly, and they have amazing collaborations; however the community is horrible. toxic players who leave or throw matches for fun just ruin the experience. the game used to be so much fun but now its just a sweat fest filled with players who play as if money is on the line. survivors can be faced with killers who will only focus on you or just camp you for an easy kill, or even both. killers can be faced with sweaty survivors who will constantly blind you, loop you to hell, tbag you at an exit gate, or just hide the entire game making it extremely boring. yes this can be a skill issue, but it wasnt like this before and it honestly has ruined the experience. dbd used to be such a fun game to play with friends, but now you can expect someone to be tunneled first and just spectate the entire game. you can still pick it up and try it if you want but i wouldnt waste my money on this. just go on youtube and look at how "pro" players play this game, youll want to stay away from this.
