[h1] Dead by Daylight [/h1]

[H1] 2020 Review[/h1]
Dead by Daylight... What a game. There is so much I want to say about this game but I don't know where to start. Dead by daylight is a very enjoyable game, which I believe can be backedup with the amount of hours I have on record (7.1k at the moment of writing this review). However, there is one major thing which brings this game down, and that is most of its community. While the game is very enjoyable at the most, it would improve the overall health of the game if the community came together as one, instead of attacking one another when the boot does not fit.

The community in Dead by Daylight is one of the most toxic playerbases I've ever come across, and this is because the community does not come together as one. Instead it is separated into two groups. You have the survivor groups and the killer groups. Both groups continually fighting against one another, and this has been like this ever since I started playing (in 2016!). Dead by Daylight is all online and it is this factor that contributes to the high toxicity that players see throughout the game. As players play and improve their performance, whether it be killing or surviving, they will begin to "rank up". There are 20 ranks between the killers and the survivors. Rank 20 being the starting rank and rank 1 being the finishing rank. When players first begin playing, they WILL see the dark side of the playerbase, however, as they make their way through the ranks down to rank 1, the community generally shows a brighter side.

[i] Please note the key word in that last sentence is [u] generally [/u][/i].

The one thing that makes the community so negative is when one side (killer or survivor) plays in a way that the other does not like. Both sides have their objectives. For the survivors, their [i]main objective[/i] is to escape. This is accomplished by repairing 5 of the 7 generators located around the map which will power 2 exit gates which will allow them to escape. As for the killer, their objective is to stop the survivors from powering the exit gates and prevent them from leaving by hooking them on meat hooks located around the map. While this does not sound too bad, most of the community take it as a life threat and will yell at the killer or at the survivors if they do all they can in their power to achieve their goal. There are many play styles which are looked down upon that create such dramatic events when a player chooses to bid by them. At some point, these "play styles" became "rules" in which, if a person "breaks" one or more of these "rules", then they will be abused in the after game chat. 

Survivors have a variety of tools which they can use to keep distance between themselves and the killer. These tools arrange from windows, which everyone can use - including the killers, except the killers cannot climb through as fast as a survivor can - and pallets, which is the survivors' main source of protection when it comes to gaining distance against the killer. While the survivors cannot be prevent from using the windows, their pallets are limited. Survivors can stun a killer for a short time with a pallet from which they can then use as a vault to get away from the killer in chase. However, if a killer decides to break a pallet once it is thrown down, it cannot come back. As a result of this, many survivors will preseve as many pallets as they can by looping them. This is known as [i]Pallet Looping[/i] and is a "rule" in which killers say survivors should NOT do as it makes the game a lot harder on the killers. If a killer is in chase, and a suvivor is looping them around a pallet, the other survivors can complete 2-3 generators by the time the killer has caught the looping survivor. This is why killers say survivors should not pallet loop, as pallet looping is a major "waste" of the killers' time.

Camping and tunnelling are two "rules" in which survivors place against the killers. In Dead by Daylight, camping is when a killer puts a survivor on a meat hook and stays protecting the hook, ensuring the survivor cannot be saved. This is frowned upon from the survivors as survivors believe that every game should be a "fair" game. This means that if a survivor is placed on a hook, the killer should not be within 32 metres of that hook unless they are in chase with another survivor. This is because, if a killer is camping a hook, it makes it a lot harder for the survivors to rescue their teammate. While many survivors will continue to repair the generators instead of attemping to save their teammate when being camped, other survivors will stay around the hook, waiting for the killer to leave, and if the killer does not leave the hook and the hooked survivor dies, then the killer has "breached" the "rule" of "no camping" and they will be abused in the after game chat. Tunnelling is when a killer targets one survivor until they die. If a survivor is on the hook and they are rescued and the killer comes back and decides to go for the survivor who just got rescued instead of the survivor who did the rescuing, then the killer will be "bashed" in the after game chat, as tunnelling is heavily look down upon.

For the best experience when playing Dead by Daylight, I [b]HIGHLY[/b] recommend closing the chat box. This is because the players DO NOT care if you are playing your first game. If you play in a way that affects another player, they will abuse you in the chat. As I said previously though, only when you are starting out will you see the dark side of the community, as the community is generally a brighter side at the lower ranks.

[h1] Do I Recommend Dead by Daylight?[/h1]
The answer is YES!

After reading all of that, you may be questioning whether or not you should go through and buy Dead by Daylight. My answer to you is yes! Do go through with buying it as the game is amazingly fun! While the community is not the greatest, you can still have loads of fun slashing people, hiding from killers, and most of all, surviving with your friends.

What's better than dying alone? Dying with the people you love!

So let's get it! 

- Purchase Dead by Daylight!
- Pick your side: Are you a Killer or a Survivor?
- Pick your play style - Will you lead your team or are you a sole survivor?
- Pick your character - Will you slaughter them with your chainsaw? Will you surprise them with your invisibility? Or will you chuckle at the sound of your prey's leg snapping in the closing of a bear trap? 

I invite you to join me and 50,000 others in a realm that belongs to The Entity in The Fog of the unknown....

The game itself is fun, but the way some things surrounding it are terrible. I had gotten into the game a few months ago, bought it at full price not expecting to play it much and only play a couple of times with friends, but then got addicted to it and played up to almost 200 hours. Then, a friend and I both got banned over stupid mistakes that shouldn't keep us out of the game. We've tried appealing, but the customer support is bad. It's one thing to have a lot of people playing your game and to have to take your time responding, but it took weeks for them to get back to my appeal only to tell me they were still looking into it. Then, because I had received a family sharing ban (which I was completely unaware of, because despite what the games website will tell you, it did not explain to me if or why I was banned), I was told I couldn't get unbanned unless the person I shared with could get unbanned. I was then told by my friend that his ban was permanent and that they were not going to undo it, so now neither of us can play the game. We really do enjoy the game and never meant any harm, and are more than willing to spend money on it again, but it's hard to look at the game in a positive way when you put so much time and money into it only to be treated like crap.

This game used to absolutely be legendary. It was a game that you could sink thousands of hours into with friends and could enjoy thoroughly. 
Killer used to be challenging,survivor used to be fun. 

They patched this game with patch 4.5 in 2021 to have major changes to movement and visual "updates", which was the start of them stripping away its character. 

The lighting in this game went from being iconic, scary, dark, and atmospheric to absolutely horrible, chalky, bright, and as non-immersive as a horror game could be.

If you go back and watch Dead By Daylight content from pre-mid 2021, to now, you can absolutely see exactly what I mean.

This community used to be so diverse and big and even though there was a toxicity, it doesn't even compare to how toxic it is now.
Sure there were moments in game as killer that made me want to slam my keyboard,but now,this game makes you feel nothing.
I feel as though every time I play killer now the survivors give up,and every time I play survivor, I do not even want to continue the game as two of your teammates are usually disconnected or dead from being disgustingly tunneled at 2 generators. 
I cannot sympathize for killers and give into their constant pity party when I played killer during arguably the most survivor sided metas during the game.

You used to face full teams of actual broken perks constantly, larger maps, with a way smaller viable perk pool.
Now I can stop the survivors right in their tracks by blowing up their generators across the map by hooking a survivor,even though I have had no input on what the other players are doing.
The way killer plays now you aren't even encouraged to have fun and chase survivors, just mind-numbingly win the game slowly against opponents that don't even want to be there.

The whole community is broken at this point. If you hear positivity about this game, it is usually someone trying to get you to come watch their stream where they sit there and lie to themselves that they are having a good time while they are panhandling online about a game that died 2 years ago realistically. The player count might be higher, but this community is dead. No one likes this anymore, and if they say they do they are absolutely lying to your face. Unless they are a killer main that sucked at this game before it literally started holding killer's hands like an actual toddler. 

If you don't believe me now, go ahead and waste the time in your life investing your time in this game and community and you will come back to this review and realize that you could've done literally anything else in your life. 

This game will never be back to it's golden days at this point sadly, I've held out hope for too long, but it's done.

I loved this game. At some point, this was a mini cultural staple in gaming. So many people on my friends list have thousands of hours and have basically given it up. So many content creators are jaded on it. So many people arguing online about this game that literally none of them have fun on anymore. 

Just save your time, please.

Very good game! I will put out some warnings though. This game has one killer going after four survivors. Sometimes the survivors win, and sometimes they don't. There is this thing called Tunneling which means when the killer goes after you right after you got off hook and they haven't hooked someone yet before they went back and killed you. Camping, Camping is when a killer just stands right next to you're hook so no one else will come or when they do, they can get killed. This is only allowed on the first survivor.  Working with survivors. I think this explains itself. Survivors working with the killer. Same thing. T-Bagging, Crouching up and down taunting the killer. This isn't really bad or needs to be reported about, it's just a warning for people who get angry easily. Survivors Disconnecting before they lose. This is less common than the others but is something that needs to be reported. Survivors or Killers hacking. Of course, needs to be reported. IF YOU THINK SOMEONE IS HACKING FIRST CHECK THEIR PERKS AFTER THE GAME TO SEE IF IT WAS A PERK. IF IT WASN'T FELL FREE TO REPORT. I think that is it. How you report people is by waiting til the end of the match and going on their name and moving you're mouse, joystick, or tapping on a thumbs up and down sign then select a report that fit's what you want  to report. Thank you for reading, and please enjoy the game. THESE ARE JUST WARNINGS OF WHAT COULD HAPPEN IN GAME DEAD BY DAYLIGHT IS FULLY AWARE OF THIS HAPPENING.  REMEMBER THIS DOESN'T OCCUR IN EVERY MATCH.

Dead By Daylight is a game I've played semi-consistently with friends since the year 2022, and with the constant updates, patches and content, it is a good game. With friends, this game is brilliant, and is a good laugh whilst you all struggle to hit skill checks and loop the killer. However, I find that the solo experience for this game can be lacklustre, often feeling more irritating and annoying then fun. And that's just the survivor side of the game.
Playing as killer is simultaneously rewarding and annoying, with matches either feeling like they were too easy or you never had a chance to begin with. Not to mention the constant struggle between balancing killer perks and survivor perks, with both sides constantly feeling the imbalance that often lingers heavy within matches.
But past all of this, all the complaints, the game has lived and thrived in the asymmetrical multiplayer horror genre, and for good reason. It has a dedicated fan-base, a great community and brilliant collaborations with other horror titles. 
Overall, whilst Dead By Daylight is a good game, I'm not sure to what degree I'd recommend it to the average solo player, perhaps keep the game as something to have in mind during large steam sales and pick it up with your friends as you all learn together how to survive the unique mechanics of every killer.

Rating: (9/10)
Overall great game if you pay no attention to meta builds and whiney survivor or killer mains in comment sections or reddit. Play your own game. There's thousands of combinations of perks, add-ons, and synergies at your finger tips. Probably the most fun in solo play is finding the perfect combination of perks from other killers that amplify a different killer's power or play style. 

If you are a solo player, expect to not always escape or kill all 4 survivors every game. It's the nature of it. You will get camped and tunneled out for no reason most of the time, wear that like a badge and move on to the next match. If you get ran around, looped, outplayed, and tag teamed by flashlights just understand those matches are few and far between. There's usually a way you could have played better unless the tileset is extremely unfavorable for your killer. 

If you are playing with friends, this game really shines.. Fun drinking nights, troll builds, griefing the killer with swarm tactics and well coordinated dives.. There's so much to look forward to even at low MMR. 

Speaking of MMR.. Forget worrying about ranks, this used to mean things back on release but now are just signs of monthly playtime. If you're always efficient-- prolonging chases, repairing gens, and rescuing teammates you'll be rank 1 in very few games.

Find what makes it fun for you or you will end up frustrated and put this game down, because it will always be unbalanced maps, unbalanced perks, and unbalanced killers.

FOR THE LOVE OF GOD PLAY THE GAME CASUALLY AS A FUNNY PARTY GAME WITH SCARY KILLERS AND DO NOT FALL INTO THE TRAP OF PLAYING COMPETITIVELY FOR EVEN A SLIVER OF A MOMENT YOU'LL HATE YOURSELF A LOT AND THE SUNK COST FALLACY WILL TRAP YOU IN THE GAMEPLAY LOOP. The game is not new player friendly and I'll stick to this statement because plenty of players have optimised the fun out of the game when it comes to playing it. People not even near the MMR they think they are in playing as if they're in a tournament and the tribalism between both survivor mains and killer mains is WAY TOO TOXIC. Let me try and break it down for you and paint you a picture and I hope this helps in making an informed choice on getting the game. As it stands currently though the game is more survivor sided purely due to the fact that core aspect of the game being hide and seek type of game with barely any info shared between players conflicts with how groups of friends normally play which is over voice chat, which means survivors are actually both under-powered (solo) and overpowered (team play)

Tribalism - Survivor mains 
They're whiny for sure, but statistically this is bound to happen as it's 1 versus 4 but man survivors are pretty delusional. Those that play competitively will kick a person learning to play killer while they are down, they take ANY win as them being good at the game forgetting that an asymmetric game really just depends on RNG and the reactions of every player. Plenty of times there are those people who set arbitrary rules to how killers should be killing properly even if at times those rules put killers in a spot where they practically can't do anything and post game they can be very toxic to even their own teammates. I've had teammates who could not function for 2 minutes after being injured following me for heals when the killer is on their tail AND CAN SEE THEM MY GOD LOOK BEHIND YOU! And then they act like everything they did was perfect and it was just the killer being toxic when the killer was alerted by them all the damn time because they didn't put any effort in surviving like a survivor SHOULD. 

Tribalism - Killer mains 
God competitive killer mains are actually the whiniest babies I've seen and no not the people calling for nerfs to perks or reminding us that the game is survivor sided every minute but there are killer mains who genuinely are mediocre at the game, but want to play competitively, but are not seeing any progress in their gameplay so they stew in the forums and discussion boards complaining about survivors literally doing ANYTHING?? Killers have accused me of genrushing and tryharding when I don't have any items or gen perks on let alone META perks?? Killers constantly whining not even about toxicity (but I'm with them there) but about being STUNNED? do you want the survivors to stand still? I've seen people complain about looping and being blinded like looking at a wall or perks that remedy the stun time don't exist. Complaints from people who clearly do not test or even experiment with their builds because the discussions and forums have become a killer echo chamber. 

Plenty of people playing competitively see the balance of the game in a black and white manner. Survivor bad Killer good, but fail to realise that survivors both hold plenty and no power in that the strength lies in communication, meanwhile the game is set by the killer who when applying pressure well can come out with a clean sweep or close at least. The game is asymmetric too so it will never be fully balanced and people don't want to admit that it's in a much better state than it was years ago. BHVR is slow with balancing but they aren't the worst, but you see streamers overreacted setting off a chain reaction within the playerbase and can just SEE people don't actually think for themselves when they parrot their opinions. Yeah so the game is very competitive now but please don't set out to play it in that manner, even if you're tough or can endure it's FUNNY when you don't take it seriously, break the ice and chat to people, emote, have fun but still try to survive. It's a video game at the end of the day. Not recommending for your sanity, but give it a try if it's on sale, the game is littered with stupid amounts of micro-transactions so the grind for anything good is where most of the play time comes from with some people.

Ingredients
2 cups strawberries, hulled
1 Tbsp granulated sugar
¬Ω tsp vanilla extract
3 egg whites, room temperature

Instructions
Lightly grease 4 6-oz. ramekins and pre-heat oven to 350 degrees.
Place strawberries in blender or food processor and puree until smooth. You should be left with about a cup of liquid. Blend in sugar and vanilla extract.
In a large bowl using a hand mixer, beat egg whites until medium peaks form (in between soft and stiff).
Fold strawberry puree into the egg whites.
Divide mixture between prepared ramekins and place ramekins on a tray so you can easily transfer them to the oven.
Bake for about 15 minutes, until souffles have risen and are turning golden brown on top. A toothpick stuck into the souffle should come out clean.
Serve immediately as souffles will begin to fall quickly.

I've split this review into a short and a long version. Obviously I'd still recommend you to read the long version, but the short one contains everything you need to know.

[h1] Short version [/h1]

Don't bother getting into this game. Nothing but frustration and stress await you. The only reason I still play this game is because of friends - Crashes, tons of hackers, and a toxic community make it very hard to have fun with this game right now. Add to that a developer with a thoroughly incompetent balance team who does nothing against scummy or overpowered gameplay tactics, only ever applies bandaid fixes to the massive and widely kown balance issues instead of adressing the problems themselves, and do very little to close the sometimes extreme power gaps between certain killers and you've got yourself a game that'll leave you unsatisfied and frustrated more often than you'll have fun with it. From my experience, a lot of people who still play it regularly only do so because of friends or because they're chasing the high of that one good match in twenty. Its a shame because this game CAN be very fun at times, but the sheer amount of factors that have do be in your favor for that to be the case just make it incredibly inconsistent.
I'd say wait till the balance team gets their stuff together and finally makes the changes required to make this game better, but after playing this game for 5 years I can safely say that will never happen.
So better just keep your hands off of this game altogether.


[h1] Long Version. [/h1]

Let me preface this by saying that when I say "the developers", I'm talking strictly about the balance team. The composers, The Texture- and 3D Artists, etc and generally the rest of Behaviour Interactive are doing a great job. Its only the balance team I have a gripe with. With that in mind, lets continue.

[b] [u] Power gaps between killers [/u] [/b]

One of the biggest problems with Dead by Daylight is the sheer difference in power between certain killers. There are killers who are widely considered to be very strong or at times even somewhat overpowered/unfair, while others are so weak that they have a significantly lower win rate on average. This is a problem, because a lot of the changes the devs make to "balance" the game are usually general changes, meaning they apply to every killer. So while a survivor nerf may make weaker killers stronger, that also goes for the already strong killers. On the other hand, a survivor buff may mean that the weaker killers suffer even more than they already do. From a balance standpoint, you can see why this might be a problem. Sadly, its a problem the devs do little to nothing about. Meaningfull buffs to weak killers and nerfs to strong killers rarely ever happen, even if the entire community collectively agrees that they are needed. The devs often try to justify this with some questionable statistics, but in the end most of these statistics ignore a huge variety of important factors and often go directly against the experience of the entire community. Yet the devs remain stubborn, insist that they know better, even when its painfully obvious to even the most inexperienced players that they don't.

[b] [u] Solo Queue vs "Survive with Friends" [/u] [/b]

The balance problems don't end here though. There's also the difference between Solo Queue (SQ) and "Survive With Friends" (SWF). (For those of you who don't play the game, SQ is when you play alone with random people, SWF is when you play together with people from your fried list.) SWF is widely considered to be much stronger than SQ because it is possible to properly communicate with and coordinate between one another via Discord or TS, and you can pick reliably good players to play with. With Solo Queue, this isn't possible. You're at the mercy of your teammates who often make very questionable decisions, your communication is limited to only 2 emotes and (thanks to the horrible matchmaking) you'll often get matched with teammates far below your or the killer's skill level. As you can guess, this can make for some very frustrating matches and is the reason why SQ is usually considered the weakest role in the game. Its also a problem because similar to killers, every survivor nerf that makes SWF weaker also affects SQ, and vice versa. The community has made a plethora of suggestions to change this (mainly more ways to communicate) and bring SQ and SFW closer together, but the devs once again continue to ignore them. This an ongoing trend as you'll soon realize.

[b] [u] Horrible Map Design [/u] [/b]

There's also the problem of the map design. What I mean by that isn't that the maps don't look pretty, but that they're horrible from a gameplay standpoint. Certain randomly generated map tiles (often referred to as "loops") are stronger than others. Some are so strong that the killer will have a very hard time catching a good survivor there, others are so weak that they're nothing but a mild annoyance to the killer. The problem is that the maps are randomly generated, and very often you'll find multiple very strong tiles strung together in one part of the map while another sometimes lacks any tiles at all. As you can probably guess, this makes for some very frustrating moments as you're basically at RNGesus's mercy. As a killer you're often forced to leave survivors in one part of the map because you have no chance of catching them without throwing the game, and as a survivor you'll often find yourself in so called deadzones where you can't do anything. There's also maps with an objectively horrible layout from a gameplay standpoint, some of which are either extremely confusing to traverse or can offer massive advantages/disadvantages to one side. Your performance as a killer is often linked directly to the map you get.

[b] [u] Scummy Tactics [/u] [/b]

Then there's the scummy tactics. There's a whole onslaught of scummy or overpowered tactics players of both sides can use to turn a match into living hell for the opponent, some of which can completely suck any fun out of a match for one side entirely. These tactics are known to the devs and some of them have been around since the launch of the game back in 2016. Yet the vast majority of them still lack any real base-game counters, and the only way to have a reliable chance against them is by bringing certain perks. 

[b] [u] The neverending Bandaid Fixes [/u] [/b]

This brings me to my next point: The Bandaid Fixes. What do I mean by that? The developers rarely ever adress the problems themselves and instead release perks that are counters to that very specific problem. The thing is, there's only four perks slots, but countless situations that require specific perks.
Let me visualize this for you.
Imagine you've got a hole in the wall of your apartment and the developers are your landlord. Naturally, you tell them about the problem. Now what the developers of this game do is instead of stuffing the hole, they put a painting over it. That in and of itself is already questionable, but fine. Better than nothing, right? Now imagine you have 15 holes in your apartment, but the landlord only gives you 4 paintings and tells you to deal with it. Then you've got yourself Dead by Daylight. Except said paintings are usually locked behind paywalls. No, I'm not kidding. This has become a big problem, and the devs have been continually ignoring said problem since the launch of the game 6 years ago. 

[b] [u] Conclusion [/u] [/b]

I could go on like this for a while, talk about the ever-increasing amount of hackers and game crashes, or the horrible grind, but I'm running out of characters so I'll keep it brief. Dead by Daylight is a horrible unbalanced mess that I wouldn't recommend anyone getting into anymore. It can be fun under the right circumstances, but more often than not it'll leave you frustrated and unsatisfied.

[b] TL;DR: Don't buy this game. [/b]

A prime example of what happens when a company prioritizes PR and profit maximization over long-term game health and cybersecurity.

Like most games that attract profit, DbD also attracted the wrong kind of attention. Namely hacking and cheating. 

In 2019 the game transitioned into a part P2P - part Server online model, with the dedicated servers having virtually no cybersecurity checks and only Hosting the match.

Since then the company had their developer build leaked to the public, implemented MMR and tried to promote the game as an "esport", and past 2020 and through the pandemic the cheating instances went through the roof. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Current situation as of the time of this report (Winter 2023):

1) By intentional decision of the company, the game has released with crossplay on certain platforms, which
led to thousands of accounts being created by bots and distributed by hackers to players that want to keep cheating.


2) A whitelist queue has been implemented in the backend ONLY for -affiliated content creators-, to lessen the chances of running into cheaters when streaming (by not matching with smurfs/pre-banned players).

At the same time, several streamers are making content with "comp players", who are little more than the front-face of the cheater community of the game.


3) Multiple groups and sites of hackers have surfaced that distribute cheats in the open. 

Cheaters using speedhacks / lagswitch-teleporting / generator speed hacks (even with no related perks or items) are everywhere. "Subtle" ones try to hide it behind objects/walls and out of line of sight, others do it blatantly.


4) Since Fall 2023, players and streamers have again been getting queue sniped and targeted.

Additionally, several cheaters stream themselves openly showcasing and distributing such software, in certain streaming sites that refuse to ban them.


5) Finally, the company openly refuses to implement a replay system for reports, requiring players instead to run recording software at all times and file reports with video evidence directly to the company's site via a convoluted process.


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion: DbD is a game plagued by recurring cheater waves, with the company behind it claiming "they are racing against hackers to block cheats as soon as they can" (they are not, or are unable to keep up).

Unless BHVR either implements a robust anti-cheat, or switches into a full server-hosted game model, DO NOT INVEST IN THIS GAME. Neither licenses nor gameplay are worth dealing with cheaters in 2 out of 3 lobbies.

Yes, it is that prevalent, especially in heavily affected servers like EU, LATAM, SE Asia, and recently with increasing frequency in US East.

This game has changed a lot since I have written this review, so I wanna update it.

Surprisingly enough, playing survivor in no full squad is not a pain anymore. You can see on the UI what your teammates are doing and when a player leaves, bot takes their place. And to everyone's surprise, the bot is actually decent.

On the killer side the game is kinda the same. Some killers are still OP, some really bad, but you can't really judge BHVR for this.

Matchmaking in this really is really weird honestly, back then it was easy to say if you play in good or bad lobby based on rank, but that was removed and hidden MMR took it's place. It is sad that playing the game and getting your desired rank doesn't feel so rewarding now, because it doesn't matter anymore, all you get from it are extra Bloodpoints.

Even with the disappointing matchmaking change, I feel like BHVR did a good job at improving player's experience by balancing a lot of things that needed to be adjusted and giving solo survivors QoL changes. For new players it's still pain having to grind for specific meta perks, but once you play the game for a while, you will have much more available options for alternate playstyles. If you want to touch a licensed character though, be ready to spend more bucks.

TL;DR: DbD used to be scary but has consistently been updated to "improve meta," the indirect result of which has been a diminishment of the game's horror themes. As a result, every new update has been a direct downgrade in terms of both aesthetic and general game-play. No one seems to know how to fix this and honestly at this point, I don't believe a fix is actually possible. Also the developers are so fragile it's offensive.

When DbD was released, it was a very dark game; not just thematically, but visually as well. The darkness of the game along with the originally very narrow field of view of its three killers contributed heavily to a stealth-based meta. This style of game-play, along with the dark atmosphere, was much more intense and thematically in line with the game's horror aesthetic. Today, however, we can see that the game has devolved into a brightly-lit , goofy, "run in circles" simulator where perks as well as a substantially larger quantity of pallets have been added in order to enforce competitiveness at the cost of theme and atmosphere. Hiding is still possible, of course, but with the enormous FoV that killers currently have, along with the fact that most maps take place in brightly lit environments, stealth has taken a back-seat to looping in terms of usefulness; the game's horror aesthetic suffers immensely for this. 

Endurance and the perks which enable it have additionally created and enforced the idea that getting hit by a killer is often not a big deal, further removing the game from its horror roots.

The addition of 'survive with friends' wasn't inherently bad. Many people had requested the feature and it was honestly cool that the developers listened to the players. However, as the game was not initially built for SWF, many of the perks had to be re-balanced in order compensate for the occasional usage of voice communications; this re-balance has still not reached a point resembling satisfactory. Combined with skill-based-matchmaking, SWF makes it inevitable that you will reach a point, especially as killer, where the game simply is not fun. The primary game-play loop, similarly to the game's perks, was not designed to be engaged with VC and to this day, four players with voice communications have an immense leg up on every killer solely by utilizing these two functions in conjunction. This issue unfortunately combines with the former two and compounds the issue of Dead by Daylight's loss of identity.

As the game has continued and new characters have been added, a number have found it harder to fit in to the cast when compared to others. Trickster, Skull Merchant, and the Singularity, for example, are far from the typical person would describe as "horror."

Finally [spoiler] I hope, [/spoiler] the addition of charms is cute. Cute is not scary. A fair quantity of character skins fall into this category as well and I'm wondering at this point if the developers have simply given up on the idea of this being a horror game.

Dead by Daylight has been on this downward slope for a long time and, unfortunately, the largest amount of damage was done so early-on that a reversion to the original "meta" for lack of a better term would essentially require the creation of an entirely new game in addition to the deletion of the current one; obviously this will not happen. Though, never in my life would I have imagined the spooky game where psycho killers and ghosts hunt you in an old abandoned junk yard would turn into 'spinning in circles while a waifu-bait k-pop star machine-guns knives at you on a fluorescent space planet in the middle of space daytime.'

...I guess "press [F] to pay respects." The game is still fun sometimes but even with [spoiler] and oftentimes because of [/spoiler] these mountains of added content, DbD is a frustrating and hollowed-out shadow of its former self.

The moderators appointed to manage the discussion forums also actively treat people like they're 5 years old. I was banned for a month after calling someone a "turd." I don't see how anyone associated with a game this violent could be that fragile.

Very fun game. If you enjoy horror movies this game can play like a horror movie at times. Lots of survivors and killers to play as, the licensed characters are amazing to see all in 1 game. Even now years later and they're still working on the game and adding onto it, fixing issues and balancing constantly. It can be niche but I'd say give it a go. Specially if you get 3 more friends to play so you can all be vs a random killer player. Or if you have enough to fill a 5 man game, You can play private matches and take turns playing killers. It's even more fun in private matches since they were kind enough to unlock the best version of every perk and item in the game for you to use in private games so you can even test builds out and just enjoy annoying you friends. Just look up "Jump Scare Myers" or "Doctor impossible skillcheck build" and you will hear them rage at you and you will just laugh all the while.

Where do I begin? You'll find that most killers will disagree, but they probably do not play survivor much. Killers have the ability to stack perks that give them unfair advantage, to start. Like blocking our only defenses like pallets, and windows to escape. They even block hex totems and gates. They can stack aura reading abilities and speed boosts. Also, hex totems. Some killers have ranged weapons along with the ability to catch up to survivors if they fail with their attack. Some perks or offerings are really unfair. Like having a mori that can kill you without being injured or hooked at all. Hooks are so close together that some of the perks or offerings to help eliminate hooks don't have any effect. You still won't get close to struggling out of their grasp. There are so many flaws with this game, but it doesn't matter because the developers only focus on cash grabbing on DLC for mainly killers and stupid things like banners and icons. This game has gotten ridiculous and I'm wondering why I even continue to play. I've noticed others have felt the same way because lobbies are having longer wait times because no one wants to play survivor. I wish there were changes to make this game feel even. Especially on smaller maps. 

Side note: Some of the level designs are clearly underdeveloped. Having gates on one side or extremely close to each other. Gens being clumped together and sometimes all on one side of the map. Also, minimal pallets on some maps. Glitches on seeing your progress on self healing. Problems with skill checks in general. But mostly when you are on a generator. Whether you're getting on one or off one, it will set off a missed skill check.
